description:
Excellent!
We chose the paella in black squid ink and it was done perfectly, complete with portions of crisped rice the way a good paella MUST be prepared. 

Their gambas was perfect as well. cooked in the prawn's own juice with abundant garlic. We had to resist eating too much bread dipped in the sauce, to leave room for the paella.

Everything was great! including the service!
author: Rico C.

description:
I was craving tapas so badly and was happy I stumbled upon this spot on Open Table. Made a reservation for 2 on a Thursday night. I like the back of the restaurant more so we requested to sit there because it's cutely lit with Christmas lights. Adds a nice date night ambiance. 

We tried the mussels, fish empanadas (this was a special), the rabbit stew, and the mushrooms. Everything was absolutely delicious and so flavorful. The mussels were probably the largest and juicer I've ever had. All of the sauces for these dishes went well with their complimentary bread. Prices are reasonable and comparable to other tapas places like chachaha. Our server, Juan, was so sweet and informative of the menu.
author: Lexi R.

description:
We enjoyed our meal out Alegrias. I would say our overall experience was a 3.5/5.0. Our meal consisted of: 

Drinks: 
Sangria - very enjoyable. 
Starters:
Manchego Flambeado - this was delicious and on point.
Patatras Aioli - also delicious and on point. 
Mains:
Paella à la Valenciana - the chicken, shrimp and chorizo was tasty but the shellfish tasted off. 

In terms of the atmosphere, the restaurant had a nice homely feel to it, but I'd say the music could have been turned up a little. Our waiter was very pleasant/ friendly too.
author: Darren F.

description:
Stumbled upon this place during 4th of July. We're going to watch fireworks and came early to se ure parking and viewing spot. With that in mind we had ample time for dinner.

Walked through Lombard, passed on Bob's and a Japanese sushi. This was the third one... It looked small from the outside. Looks great on the inside. My wife was impressed with the food. We had Grilled Octopus, Rabbit, Paella calamari and pitcher of Sangria.

Overall this is a great find and will definitely comeback. It's now on my fav list.
author: SFoodie P.

description:
So delicious!! Manchego/rum on fire and apple crepe/rum on fire! I always love pulpo! We were there on Sunday and
It was not crowded. Service was good and the food came pretty fast
author: Erena S.

description: This place is now for sure the place to come when visiting San Francisco.  Great food, great service, great environment.
author: Mel T.

description: WOW, came to the city for a quick night and this place happened to be next door to our hotel...so glad we gave it a try.  We ordered 5 tapas and a dessert for 2 people.  It was more than plenty!  The iberico ham was melt in your mouth good and worth the $18 (most expensive thing ordered).  We had one of the specials which was clams and snails in a tomato based sauce, it was excellent...the snails were so delicious! The anchovies were good, not sure we would order again but it was nice to have something that wasn't overly dressed.   The mushrooms were a variety of types and had great flavor.  Paired with the flaming manchego cheese, they were great.  We finished with a Graham's 20 year tawny port and the creme catalana (basically an orange creme brulee), which was perfect.  Highly recommend.  I think with a beer and glass of wine our total was a little over $100...
author: Alicia V.

description:
As a former rabbit owner, I was never able to bring myself to eat rabbit meat at restaurants. Now that my family pet has gone to bunny heaven, I enthusiastically dug into the stewed rabbit dish at Alegrias and savored every bite. 

Unfortunately, the other dishes fell short, and I found myself drooling over pictures of other tapas restaurants on Yelp during my meal. The ambiance was also very stuffy...literally. I was dying for some fresh air or even a single breeze. At least service was good.
author: Suany W.

description:
TLDR - Solid Spanish tapas but the dishes lacked a wow factor in comparison to other tapas restaurants in SF

I've basically been slowly going around SF looking for the best Spanish tapas restaurant. Alegrias is a pretty small one sort of hidden away in the Marina. Compared to the other places I've been to, it's definitely on the homier side and it feels very family run. The restaurant is rather cramped inside and has more of a casual, intimate feel. It seems to get busy on the weekend, so make a reservation in advance if you can. 

The menu has a variety of hot tapas, a few cold ones and paella, and there's a solid wine menu as well. The paellas take about 30 minutes, but they time everything pretty well so that there isn't a long wait in between dishes. For 4 people, we ordered 5 tapas, 1 paella and 1 pitcher of sangria for about $130 after tax/tip.

The dishes and menu offering felt more traditional with none of that flair you sometimes get at more trendy restaurants. The food was pretty good but as a whole, I wasn't wowed. Definitely recommend the Croquetas and Empanadillas though.

* SANGRIA ($26 for pitcher)
One pitcher's maybe good for 6 of their glasses (which were on the smaller side for wine glasses). 

* EMPANADILLAS DE CARNE ($8.50) - 4.5/5
[beef, green onions, olives, raisins, herbs]
Comes with only 2 empanadillas, each of which are maybe 2 bites. They're really good though so I'd recommend ordering enough to have your own. The beef filling was sweet and delicious and the outside was crisp without being greasy.

* CROQUETAS DE JAMON IBERICO Y GAMBA ($9.50) - 5/5
[croquettes filled w/ minced jamon iberico & prawn]
Probably the best thing we ordered! This one comes with 4 croquetas, each of which was delicately fried on the outside and filled with creamy goodness on the inside.

* ESPINACAS A LA CATALANA ($8.50) - 4/5
[sautéed spinach, garlic, raisins, apple, pine nuts]
I'm convinced I should be sauteeing my spinach with raisins and apples now to add some sweetness. I was disappointed at how small the portion size was though.. Not really worth ordering in comparison to other dishes.

* PATATAS AIOLI ($8) - 3.5/5
[crisp fried potatoes, traditional aioli sauce]
If you love potatoes, you'll probably like these more than I did. They had a decent crisp to them, but otherwise I found them pretty average. I've had Spanish patatas at other places paired with a tastier sauce. The portion size was big and filling though.

* CONEJO A LA CAZUELA ($13) - 4/5
[stewed rabbit w/ vegetables & wine]
There were only 3 pieces of meat so the dish was disappointing for the price. The tomato broth was tasty but also simple, nothing super special in flavor.

* PAELLA A LA VALENCIANA CON CHORIZO ESPANOL ($29) - 3/5
[saffron flavored spanish rice, chicken, seafood, chorizo]
One of the more disappointing paellas I've had. The chicken was well cooked and the chorizo was tasty, but the seafood was a little overcooked and the rice lacked flavor and fragrance. I always look forward to the crispy rice at the bottom of the pan, but theirs failed to really produce any of that crunch.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Our first visit with "Alegrias"...
Let me just say, "Fabulous"...
Our waiter was "Juan", and truly a delight 
Our food was really delicious and we ordered too many items
Our eyes were bigger than our mouths  
You must give this restaurant a try
Even The ambience was calming and just so relaxing  
Really enjoyed
author: Judy K.

description: Love the food and the staff! Juan Carlos has served us several times, always a pleasure.
author: Omar M.

description: Excellent Spanish food and plenty of options for vegetarians in the small plates. In the entrees there is only really one option which is the vegetarian paella but it is so flavorsome you can't go wrong. This place has very cute ambience and is a perfect date night place. You almost don't feel you are in San Francisco after you enter. Check this one out!
author: Ruchi M.

description: When you walk into this quaint place, it feels like you're in one of these cute places in Sevilla or Madrid! From the service to the food, from tapas to dessert, from location to interior ambiance, this place is A1! It's not pretentious; it's authentic and cozy, even romantic. The 3 of us ordered tapas style which is the way to go, and every single dish was outstanding and authentic. Everything in Alegrias is well balanced. There is no Modern Spanish with a twist; this is Spanish food: original and authentic, and excellent as ever! Their Sangria is a must. Don't miss the empanadillas and tortilla española. I loved Callos a la Madrileña!... last time I had them that good was in Madrid, 5 years ago. Croquetas and gambas al ajillo we're excellent, and their calamari was just right. For octopus lovers, their octopus was cooked to perfection, not chewy. I'm visiting SF for 9 days, and I have already come back. I'm planning to go back before I leave.  The owner, Don Cesar, takes the time to stop at your table for a nice conversation. All desserts are great too. I can't say enough how good the place is.
author: Xiomara P.

description: I'm of Spanish descent and have had my fair share of tapas in the US, Spain and other parts of the world. Fairly traditional servings in terms of menu items and great service at Alegrias. I'm giving this place a 3-Star due to poor execution and blandness on the majority of the dishes, and steep price point relative to quality.
author: Alex B.

description: Very friendly and attentive staff.  Tried the special chorizo appetizer which had good flavor but a bit chewy.  Stewed rabbit was fantastic, as was the traditional paella.  Excellent citrus creme dessert.  Drink prices were a bit high though which bloated the bill. Stewed rabbit was actually cheaper than a glass of cava.  Very good espresso and cappuccino.
author: Tony P.

description:
Visited Alegrias for dinner after a hike. I would rate it an overall 3 star experience just because the food isn't anything to scream about.

The food: Bread is not warm. We ordered the specials for appetizers which was Octopus on potato and done really well. 

The Bocadillos (crab cakes) was OK.

Paella Valenciana was mediocre, the mussels and chicken had no flavor. Rice was more on the mushy side. 

We had a pitcher of Sangria but it wasnt mixed right so the first glass was watered down. It was no fruitiness to the Sangria despite the cut fruit in the drink. If you enjoy Sangria not sweet, this would be perfect for you.

Price was reasonable, atmosphere was a 5. Service a 5 too, we always had water and tables cleared.
author: Sara N.

description: The paella was too salty for my taste. Food was okay. Non of the tapas particularly stood out either. The place is clean and homely. Service staff was very professional.
author: Diane Z.

description: Paella was ok, octopus had nice texture but the seasoning was alright. Food was decent and ambiance was nice.
author: Kissy F.

description:
Alegrias is a quaint little restaurant that looks like an abuela's home. The walls were heavily decorated with picture frames. Space was tight, but clean and service was fantastic.

The best bite of the night was the croqueta with the aioli. Everything else was decent but not memorable. The empanadas were also pretty good, at least the golden crispy outter layer, the filling was a bit sweet. Similar story with the sausage as it was served with a fruit (probably pear, but it was hard to tell). I didn't quite care for the paella - we had the seafood and sausage one. I thought the clams were great in the paella but the rice texture was pretty mushy and lacked flavor. Just a heads up that their paellas take 30 min - so order it first if you want it, but I would recommend just sticking with the tapas.
author: Swan L.

description:
I went here randomly this past Friday evening. I ordered a bunch of tapas and was super impressed by the taste. I don't remember the exact names of the tapas I order, but all of these ones were delicious:

Crab Cake 
Empanada with Tuna 
Shrimp
Goat cheese 

I want to come back and try their Paella! This is definitely a good first date spot. It has that whole dim lighting romantic vibes things going on.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
The food and service is amazing! 

Food: We got the manchego flambeado, the grilled asparagus, and the vegetarian paella for dinner, and got the flambeed apple crepes for dessert. Aside from the grilled asparagus, everything was amazing. The grilled asparagus was a bit too charred for my taste, and probably the only reason that this restaurant is getting 4 stars.

Service: Our waiter - Alfonso - was awesome. He was happy to provide recommendations and was very friendly and attentive. 

Overall, I would definitely recommend checking out this place, and will come again.
author: Kavita P.

description: This is probably the best tapas restaurant I have been to and possibly the best service I've had at a restaurant in SF. Everything was impeccable and tasted incredible. Make sure to get the Jamon Iberico!
author: Matt V.

description: Came here on a Sunday night to celebrate my best friend's birthday. Shes a fan of Spanish food, specially sangria and she had the time of her life. We ordered way too much, but enjoyed every bit of it. For starters we ordered the garlic shrimp, patatas bravas, bourbon cheese and crab cakes. As for the main dish, we had the valencia paella to share and for dessert the apple glazed styled pancake. So good! We also enjoy 2 delicious jara of sangria! The people working there were extremely nice. The waiter was helpful when choosing from the menu and the owner (who is from Argentina) came and spoke with us. Recommended for anyone wanting to invite someone special to eat
author: Sophie E.

description:
It was my first time there and it was wonderful. It hit all the notes a great dining experience should. The interior was a comfortable setting. The staff was professional and kind. The food was terrific. We started with a pitcher of Sangria that was generous and very tasty. 

We started with a bowl of assorted olives that I must admit struck me as the best I've ever enjoyed. Then we shared three tapas dishes. Grilled asparagus with manchego cheese, croquettes of jamon and shrimp, and beef empanadas. Each dish was presented in a pleasing fashion with portions that were just right. It was obvious that the preparation for each dish was perfected by someone who over time had learned to get everything right. There was also a simplicity about the food that added to its elegance. Like the great blues man B.B. King who could play with a very slow hand but each note was perfection, Alegrias gustatory notes were perfection, too. 

We followed the tapas with a shared Spanish sausage and chicken paella. I appreciated that the waiter suggested that one was plenty to share for two rather trying for an upsell. The richness of mingled flavors in the paella really delighted us. It was generous with the seafoods, the chicken was moist and the Spanish sausage was a great accent added. It was cooked with just the right amount of caramelization at the edges of the pan. You know the stuff, the crusty really intensified flavors of the dish that you scrape every last bit off the pan. We ate every bite of everything. It took us to a very happy state of satiety but still wouldn't say no to dessert. 

Our dulce de leche crepes were oh so caramelly, both of the flavor of the DL and the crusty caramelization on the crepe from its time in the pan. We had a Spanish version of creme brûlée that had an orange accent to it. Loved it. A small glass of port went well with our desserts. 

Towards the end of the evening the owner/chef came to our table (and others) to inquire if we were pleased with our dinners. Very old school and refreshing! I was embarrassing myself by going on and on about how much I enjoyed dining in his restaurant. He leaned over close and asked me if I knew his secret. I said no. He said that he tries to make every dish in the most traditional Spanish fashion. He felt that too often chefs want to add their own twist to classic dishes. He wanted to present the most traditional version done with the perfection of that perfect B.B. King guitar note. Done that way maybe the only "twist" a dish needs. It certainly worked for every bite of every dish we had.

When the check arrived I was pleasantly surprised how reasonable it was for all we had enjoyed. By San Francisco standards it was a down right bargain.

So why am I, who has no relationship to this restaurant other than being a first time customer, writing this long review? Because family run restaurants like this are becoming harder to find all the time. They have a charm that goes beyond being just a tasty place to get some eats. It's like being invited into someone's home. Someone with traditions, pride and individuality that are unique to them. It's dining in a personal fashion. No matter how good a dining chain restaurant  is, it's still a chain. This is from the earliest traditions of restaurants and money alone can't buy it.

Alegrias has been there for 20 years; it's a treasure and deserves its community's support. Sadly, I'm just visiting from L.A. so I'm depending on locals who read this to keep Alegrias well supported. I'll do my part when I come to town.
author: Bruce S.

description: We ate here last Friday and have a marvelous dinner. The jamon iberico, a specialty, was excellent, nutty, cheesy, and you can almost taste the acorns! The spinach had a very interesting mix of spices, nuts and fruits. The best part, the flan, compliments of the chef because we were celebrating our 33rd wedding anniversary. I've had an aversion to eggs since I was 3. The flan came to the table and I had to at least try it. Outstanding. Thank you to the staff at Alegrias for making our anniversary extra special.
author: Pamela M.

description: 5 stars real Spanish (Spain) food. Went with a group of 7 the owner sat us and gave us a little special attention (one word SANGRIA) had 2 pitchers. Started with bread and oil then 2 different types of cheese one which was on fire OMG!!! We had frog legs, rabbit stew, potatoes amazing, seafood cakes (can't remember the name of them) and vegetarian empanadas. If that wasn't enough they brought out the main coarse both seafood (shrimp,clams,mussels,fish) and vegetarian Pyaya (sure I spelled that wrong) then a bottle of wine before desert which was an apple pancake type dish covered in rum and lit on fire AMAZING PRESENTATION !!!!!! Waiters were professional and knowledgeable with just the right amount of interaction. I advise everyone to make this restaurant a go to spot for dates (guarantee your getting lucky) I don't give 5STARS often but this place earned them all. If you go I hope you get David as your server although everyone was great. About $300 for everyone but well worth it for everything we got "if your broke this review is not for you" I salute Alagrias
author: Kharey R.

description:
Cute spot for tapas. We came here in a large group (12 people) and we're seated almost immediately (we had a reservation).

We decided to literally get one of everything in the hot tapas menu and one of each of the paellas.

Some of my favourite items were:
- the flaming manchengo cheese (have it with the bread they serve!)
- goat cheese in red sauce
- croquettes
- seafood paella

We also got a few pitchers of the the red sangria which were really good!
author: Tanay J.

description:
Best Spanish restaurant in San Francisco.
That should say it all.
author: Priyank D.

description: What a hidden gem. The restaurant looks fairly nondescript from the outside but once you get in, the ambience is perfect - cozy, warm and perfect for an intimate meal with friends. Every dish we ordered was on point. We had the jamon iberico, gambas, rabbit stew, and the empanadillas followed by the paella with seafood, chicken and chorizo - everything was excellent, well prepared and tasted fresh. For dessert, we had the flan and bread pudding which were also amazing. The only thing I was wishing was that the relatively small menu would have a few other Spanish favorites like pan con tomate or blistered padron peppers, but what they did have was wonderful. Definitely coming back again!
author: Ada C.

description:
We ordered the patatas aioli, empanadas, crab cakes and baked goat cheese. Everything was delicious. The potato's were better than I've had before at other places. The creme brûlée with orange was the best dessert. The arroz con leche needed to be sweeter.

Loved the romantic setting. Would go back.
author: Mariam H.

description: Okay, Alegrias is probably one of my favorite San Francisco dining experiences. We snagged a reservation for two on a Saturday night, and even though the place was packed, our server was really attentive and helpful. It was so difficult to choose what to order.  I chose 'Espinacas a la Catalana' and 'Empanadillas de Carne', sooo delicious. I must add that the dining environment was great with lots of cute indoor decor. Will be back he here when I return to San Francisco.
author: Michael C.

description: The restaurant​ is very cute, people are nice, and it looks like some of them are actually from Spain ;) I think that the dishes we tried were just OK, nothing special or anything I would want to come back for. We only tried several tapas. Their paella looked pretty good, and maybe next time we will order it.
author: Sophie N.

description: Came here last night with a group of girls who're mostly from out of town (including myself). Felt some pressure to pick a great place as the last meal in SF but I wasn't disappointed! Paella was soo delicious and seafood-y. Shellfish wasn't over cooked and rubbery. Side tapas were flavorful and tasty. Portions weren't that big but with the bread it was filling. Also the restaurant is rly spacious and was not packed for a Friday night. Definitely recommend !
author: Sunny R.

description:
Some of the best tapas I've had in a while!!! We came in with a group of 8 of us and had a reservation prior to arriving. The restaurant has a very cute and quaint ambiance to it. 

We ordered a bottle of wine and a round of beers for the table to start. After that - it was fair game to order family style for the table. Veggies on one side, carnivores on the other...everyone absolutely loved the food here. The quality, flavors and freshness of each plate was absolutely amazing - HANDS. DOWN. AMAZING.

The highlights of our orders were: The crab cakes, both the veggie and beef empanadas, and the potatoes w/ aioli. We did order the paellas (veggie and meat) but I don't think anyone was a huge fan of either dish. 

Overall, great service, excellent food and cute ambiance. I'm already dreaming and drooling over those delicious crab cakes....
author: Sonal P.

description: Cute ambience and very attentive staff! Overall, not my favorite tapas place in the city, but tasty food nonetheless. I found the paella to be a bit lacking in seafood, but still a solid establishment.
author: Tyler W.

description: The seafood & chicken paella was absolutely tasty! It serves two but I swear I can eat it all on my own!  Make sure if you come with a group to keep in mind the portions aren't large. The  spinach appetizer with pine nuts, garlic, apples and raisins was also good. I wouldn't recommend the omelette for dinner; it wasn't bad but it tasted more like a brunch/breakfast dish. Great intimate ambiance and I will definitely return!
author: Noor S.

description: Loved every dish especially the paella, aioli potatoes, squid, and mushroom dishes. The apple pancake amazing if you like that brandy kick. Also, the selection of wine is on point and very affordable. This place is such a hidden gem! Part of me wants to tell the world all about it but part of me wants to make it my secret fav place. It's family run and they are amazing and I only want more success for them so do yourself a favor and eat here! The service is great and the food drool worthy. LOVE it here!
author: Rose E.

description: This a great place to have a nice dinner with no kids. The ambiance is low key and the light is low. The food is delicious. The Sangria was very good as well. My friend and I ordered mushrooms and the potato dish in the picture. We also had the asparagus which was really good as well. So for a quaint and good food night out go here. Public parking is nearby.
author: Jeanine M.

description:
I don't eat tapas that much, but I really enjoyed the food here. 

I was hanging out with some friends in the city near Fort Mason this past Saturday, and when dinnertime came around (around 6:30) we wanted a restaurant that was big enough for our group of 9 and didn't have a long crazy wait. 

I thought it would be nearly impossible to find, but I turned to yelp (thank goodness for the "good for groups" filter) and stumbled across this place. I called them to inquire, and the lady who picked up my call was so nice as to prepare our table as we were walking there (it took about 10 minutes for our large group to leisurely saunter over).

My first impression of the restaurant when I first walked in was that it was very intimate and romantic. The inside is dimly lit and has a cozy feel to it. Most of the tables were occupied by couples young and old going for a Saturday night dinner date. We were seated in the back area where they had prepared our table, and it felt even more romantic in there because they had these strings of yellow lights strung up along the walls.

For 9 people, we ordered 3 paellas (each paella serves around 2) and 14 tapas dishes and that was a good amount of food.

For me the highlights of the meal were:

Arroz negro (paella): liked the squid ink paella a lot more than the other two paellas we got. The flavor was more subtle than the seafood paella but it still had really good flavor.

Empanadillas de carne: these small empanadas were served piping hot. The filling was very tasty and full of yummy meat juices.

Tortilla de chorizo: a potato omelette with onions and chorizo. It was my first time eating this dish but I found myself really enjoying it!

Setas al ajillo: sauteed mushrooms. I love mushrooms so I'm a sucker for anything with them in it, especially if they're done well.

For all the food we ordered, it came out to be around $31 per person after tax and tip. Not bad!
author: Dianna H.

description:
Truly a hidden gem. I've lived in the neighborhood for three years and didn't find this place until recently. 

A very cozy setting with friendly staff. Their tapas were great - especially their octopus! 

Good wine selection at an affordable price point. The paella was the only thing that didn't leave a lasting impression. It was a tad too fishy for our taste. 

I'm happy to have a Spanish tapas place close by, they will definitely see me in there a lot more often.
author: Tarun P.

description:
Cozy Spanish restaurant with mostly tapas.

Sangria was nice ($6).

We tried 2 "specials" pimientos piquillo (3 small red peppers filled with groind up lamb) and pulpo a la gallega (octopus on top of potato).
Both were ok.

The croquetes didn't hit me and I won't order them again.

The esparagos were either a bit old or over cooked for my taste.

3 or 3 1/2 for the food

5 for the nice waiter

4 for the old ambience
author: Vic M.

description: This place and the food are just amazing. I love the vibe and the great service. A lot of options in Spanish Tapas and good wine. I will definitely come back again:)
author: Pablo V.

description: Really great tapas.  My favorites are the oxtail stew special (a silky sauce and incredibly tender meat), the spinach (interestingly sweet), and the seafood paella
author: Annie M.

description:
I have been to Alegrias for several birthday and special occasions. This is a perfect spot for authentic Spanish tapas. Alegrias has continually impressed me and my entire family. Here are my highlights: 
1. The ambiance is very cozy and intimate. I love the personal touch with the unique decor on the walls, as well as the low lighting. 
2. The food is divine! My family is a big fan of the family style menu. My food highlights include the crispy fried potatoes, the Spanish style potato and onion omelette, and of course their famous Paella. The flambeed apple crepe has never disappointed and always raises an "wow!" from everyone at the table.  
3. The service has been nothing but fast, attentive, and welcoming. 

I look forward to coming back one day and celebrating more special occasions!
author: Isabel K.

description:
Patatas Aioli (Crispy potatoes) are a must-have. One of the best ones I've eaten - rank as good as Plow potatoes in my book.
Manchebo Flambeado (cheese flambe) - not worth it. It's just oily, melted cheese which is nice on the eyes for the first few minutes when they sprinkle the alcohol and flambe it
Veggie paella - decent but a little overpriced for the quantity 

The old gentleman who seated us (owner?) was very warm and friendly. The service could've been better, we had to wait for a long time before we even got water on the table. The people sitting next to us seemed highly disappointed by the lack of prompt service and were given a complimentary dessert to make up for it.

Great ambience, good for a date night.
author: G J.

description:
Chose this restaurant for a cute date night  The ambience wasn't exactly romantic but it was intimate. Service was great, the server was friendly and prompt! 

The food was AMAZING! We ordered the empanadilla vegetarianas and the patatas alioli for starters and each one was delicious, flavorful, and filling. The main course is and the highlight of the night was the seafood and chicken paella. Each meat was cooked to perfection and was tender and juicy. The paella was flavorful and the best I've had!!!
author: Bobby C.

description:
5 stars for service, 4 stars for food, 3 stars for decor. 

My fiancée and I came here to enjoy her birthday. We haven't been able to explore the North Beach area, and Alegrias was a good opener. 

First off, our server was very hospitable. Made suggestions, complimented us on our wine choice, and was extremely attentive, but not hovering. 

Second, I would opt to sit in the room closer to the front. It's darker and has a more intimate vibe. Also, I think it has that authentic feeling of being in Spain. The room in the back (where we sat) is nice, but it's bright and I would say the furniture needs to be updated or rather upgraded. 

Wine list is good with options for people with varying preferences and budgets.  

The food was decent for Spanish tapas. We ordered the Gambas al Ajillo (not really prawns, but the SAUCE was amazing), Manchego Flambeado (MUST ORDER, if you love cheese), Patatas Aioli (staple item), and the Paella a la Valenciana con Chorizo Espanol (a bit salty, but the soccarrat was definitely the star part of the dish). For dessert we ordered the Flan, which I recommend ordering. 

All in all, we left drunk and full, so I'd say we were happy.
author: Patrick M.

description: My new spot for Spanish food. As a vegetarian it's hard to find places with a good variety of veggie options but this plus hit the spot. Veggie empanadas with a nice flaky outside and veggie paella with the nice crispy bottom. Yum yum yum. Also great wine options as well. Can't wait to go back.
author: Linda L.

description: There are better Spanish places around. If you've never been to Spain I guess you'll like this pace. Good was mediocre at best. We started with a plate each of jamon and cheese. Although good, it was not the Iberico de Bellota advertised. The cheese was good as well, the same cheese found at Costco, Trader Joe's and other places. We ordered chorizo, and were presented with a casuals of thinly sliced sausage with apples and onions that did not taste Spanish at all. The croquetas de jamon were a huge disappointment. Pasty thick with no jamon flavor. The gambas were drowning in a sauce that was superfluous with pimenton that completely masked any seafood flavor. For desert my companion ordered churros von chocolate, e pecking the light crunchy churros and thick pudding-like chocolate she had all over Spain. Instead she got a plate of leaden fried dough with cinnamon and runny cold chocolate. She made her displeasure known to the waiter, and shortly later the Argentinian cook came by with a bar of Valor chocolate to show that was what he used. He made excuses for every comment stating that if she didn't like the churros he would eat them himself.
author: ALICE l.

description:
Go for their flaming cheese!  That is an eye-winner and a specialty for a Spanish tapa!  I also did like their Shrimps in their house signature sauce!  It was delightful!

Their Empanada and White Wine Marinated Mushrooms were good, but wasn't the all star spectacular dishes on tapas!

Service was wonderful and they set the mood with live music being played!

It's a great date place to bring a special someone due to its glowing dinner setting!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Easily made a reservation the day of for a Saturday at 6:30pm. We walked in with half the tables occupied but it started to fill up around 7pm. 

We ordered the Paella A La Valenciana, Patatas Alioli, Calamares Fritos Con Alioli, Sangria, and the Apple crepe with rum sauce (dessert on fire). I really enjoyed the Patatas Alioli and Sangria and the rest were good. Very flavorful and enough for two people. 

The atmosphere was cozy and the staff was very friendly. It's a great date spot and there's also space in the back for groups. I would definitely visit again.
author: Jane Y.

description:
It's been awhile since I've been here because I moved out of town, but I have always LOVED Alegrias. The ambiance is lovely and intimate, and the owners and staff are lovely. Many of the  decorations have been brought from their trips to Spain. 

Growing up in a Spanish household (mother is from Sevilla), I am picky about what some restaurants call Spanish food. This is the only place I brought my parents where they said "Oh yes, this is "real" Spanish food!"

Croquetas, empanadas, espinaca, tortilla espanola (someone called it an omelette in their review and that's just wrong lol - it is a popular tapa in Spain, not a breakfast food), the cheeses, chorizo and omg the rabbit....all amazing.  Another review said the bread wasn't warm....I've never been to a tapas bar in Spain (and I've been to quite a few) where the bread is warmed. Just putting that out there. And the Flan and Crema Catalan....delicious!

A lot of reviews complained about the paella. I actually haven't tried it here - I can't seem to pull myself away from the tapas. 

Weekends do fill up so a reservation is a good idea. I miss coming here. It's a special place for me.
author: Esperanza N.

description:
Still a good place for dinner and you can park across the street at Lombard Street Parking.

Brought friends and family here when I came into town.  We tried lots of different plates but I particularly love the mushrooms and paellas.

Bookmarked and will definitely come back
author: Kayla N.

description:
My boyfriend took me here on Valentines Day because he knows that I love Spanish cuisine. It's dimly lit, romantic, and intimate, so love was definitely in the air that night. There was a prix fixe menu, so we got the lobster croquettes, gambas al ajillo (garlic/white wine prawns), lamb stuffed piquillo peppers, jamon serrano, escalivada, and the CALLOS A LA MADRILENA (Note: I thought I'd be adventurous and order the rabbit stew, but they were sold out that night so I'm assuming it's good. Still on my list!). I love me some Spanish food, but I particularly love this place because they offer a lot of dishes that they don't serve at other Spanish restaurants. Everything we ordered was delicious, but it's the callos a la madrilena (Madrid style tripe) that has me coming back to this place. That, and to my pleasant surprise, a waitress that I met at El Torito was serving us that night and it was great to see her again. I stop by this restaurant to say Hi because she's a sweetheart.

Not a lot of restaurants serve this kind of Madrid style tripe in all its yummy tomato sauce glory, so when the craving strikes I go straight here. The last time we ate here, we also tried the garlic mushrooms and the jamon iberico & prawn croquettes, and both are yummy in my tummy. I'd definitely order those again. As an Asian, people find it appalling that I dislike rice, but I like some kinds of rice as long as its different. So we ordered the arroz negro, which is paella cooked in squid ink. It's very flavorful but also very filling so I was stuffed. I've also ordered the manchego flambeado as recommended by other Yelpers, which was cool to watch and to try, but it's not a must have.

To summarize, Alegrias is a wonderful Spanish restaurant, especially if you want to explore more authentic Spanish dishes (I.E. more than just jamon serrano, manchego cheese, patatas bravas, etc. *yawn*). Don't forget to order a pitcher of sangria or some Spanish red wine to get the full experience :)
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description:
This is a great family-run spot despite its difficult location smack dab in the middle of Lombard Street.  It's right across from a large parking garage (Lombard between Fillmore and Webster, enter from the alley behind - parallel to Lombard),

The tapas dishes are a throwback to our time in Spain - authentic, well prepared and fairly priced.  The dishes are easily shared between two to four people, and sharing is key - the three of us ordered two items each and it was too much - we left food on the table.

The wine list is carefully selected as well - tip, the best values are by the bottle, not the glass, so just bite the bullet and order the whole bottle!  Some excellent, unique choices can be found here - branch out and try something new - Viura, Macabeo, etc. etc.
author: Dave C.

description: We started with the sautéed peppers, mushrooms, goat cheese, and empanadillas which were all good. We had the paella with chicken, seafood, and chorizo, which tasted like old seafood. When we mentioned this to our server the chef came out and berated us on not knowing seafood. This was extremely rude and we left immediately.  I do not recommend this restaurant due to its service.
author: Jenn A.

description: I enjoyed the setting. It reminded of my trip to Barcelona, only the seafood was not as fresh. I went there with a group of 10 and was offered their prix fixe menu.  It was $40pp which included paella and about eight tapas.  It was a nice sampling of their menu however I felt that it was a bit expensive for the quality of food. The service was good and the ambiance was quiet and relaxing.
author: Torch T.

description: We go here often and love it...especially the sangria and calamari...not to mention the paella
author: Kay H.

description: Thrilled they suggested Spanish Tapas and we ended up here. Service was phenomenal and every dish was delicious and unique, seasoned to perfection with lots of sauce and all you can eat bread for dipping. We brought in a bottle of local Pinot and it was a perfect match for all the flavors. We ordered assorted Spanish cheese and Iberico ham, stuffed piquillo peppers with lamb, spinach with pine nuts, apples and raisins??, gambas!, frog legs (oh my), and the chicken, seafood and chorizo paella. Desserts were to die for, I thoroughly enjoyed the caramel crepes so much that I didn't get much of the bread pudding that my friends devoured! I'll definitely be back!
author: Aimee P.

description:
I had gone to Spain a year or so before this restaurant and it is a great representation of authentic food that you would receive in Madrid. It surprised us a lot the outside looks a little dingy and run down but you go inside and the ambiance is unbelievable: dim lights, spanish style paintings and rugs, and very homie. The wait stuff was very on point and quick to serve.

I would recommend to start with the flaming cheese with bread (watch out don't eat it too fast or you may get burnt), the vegetarian and carne ensenadas are very good and small enough to share among two people, and the Tortilla de Chorizo is a spanish style omelette and tops the meal off with its authenticity and texture.

I would recommend it for smaller groups and dates.
author: Kunal T.

description: Quite an enjoyable and cozy place.  The fried patatas were crispy and crunchy.  The tortilla omelette was also a hit.  The paella was good enough to fill up the rest of the belly.  Great service and welcoming staff.
author: Stevezee C.

description:
GET: 
--Frog legs. Excellent. These were the star of the dinner--very flavorful and tender, with a nice crisp in the outside.

Decent, but probably would not order again:
--Gambas al Ajillo (shrimp in tomato-based sauce). Flavorful sauce, however you need to drink with a spoon along with the shrimp in order to get the flavor.

PASS on:
--Arroz Negra (squid ink paella) (entree). I normally love anything squid ink. This, however, was way overdone and incredibly dry--so much so, that I couldn't even stick a fork into parts of the paella. Poor execution aside, the flavor was also lacking--as it was with the majority of the other dishes...
--Croquettes filled with Spanish ham and shrimp. 4 pieces, about twice as big as a jalapeño popper. Filling was very mushy. Came with a sauce that did not pair well--sauce was like a non-spicy spicy mayo. Considering the lack of flavor and unappealing consistency (and color--brownish inside), I would have preferred pre-frozen jalapeño poppers.
--Bocadillos (crab cakes) with mild jalapeño cream sauce. Very mild--can't taste any jalapeño in the sauce, and it was in desperate need of seasoning. Crab cakes were also mushy inside, though the outside had a nice crisp, similar to the croquettes.

Overall a very homey authentic-feeling Spanish restaurant, but food was disappointing. Chef walks around and chats with patrons, which is nice. His recommendations were the frog legs and shrimp.

Without the frog legs, Alegrias would have been 2 stars for me. The Valencia paella was not good, however another party (who pronounced it "pa-ella", rhyming with umbrella...), said it was good.  Could be that I chose the dishes very poorly, however with the majority of the dishes being severely lacking (and at the pricy range of $8-12 per tapas-sized dish), I find it hard to believe that our meal was not representative of the menu as a whole. I probably won't be returning, unless I'm in the mood for multiple orders of frog legs.
author: Vanessa O.

description: Ordered paella, fried calamari, crab cakes, asparagus, croquet, beef turnover. All were good and reminded me of the times when I spent vacation in Barcelona. Worth a visit.
author: joe l.

description: Love!!! My new favorite tapas and Paella restaurant. We had the grilled calamari which was so perfectly cooked and sooooo fresh (this was not on the menu so I am assuming they will only have it if there are fresh supply) The Paella is the best in SF!! Mushroom in white wine sauce . The atmosphere of the place is so relaxing and calming. Two things that stopped me from giving it 5 stars are the portion of the Paella - small compared to other restaurants and the Sangria wasn't strong enough but if those two things don't bother you, then this is a 5 for sure.
author: Ana L.

description: Delicious tapas for dinner with my wife.  Small place with attentive staff and delicious food.  We had a nice romantic dinner together.  Would definitely come back here.
author: Steven B.

description: We celebrated our first year anniversary at this restaurant and were so pleasantly surprised and enthused to try as much as we could on the menu. This is the best Spanish tapas place I have found in the bay area since moving here 3 years ago. The stewed rabbit, tuna empanadas, crispy potatoes and citrus creme brulee was the best. The Paella Valencia was wonderful. Will definitely be back as soon as possible! Thank you to the owners for the passion and taste they have endowed their recipes with!
author: April L.

description: Food was amazing! Totally authentic and the ambience was very intimate and inviting. Sangria was on point and everything we ate was immediately devoured with "mmmm's" and a second order. Service was great too. Our waiter was attentive, sweet, and patient! Great dining experience and we'll definitely re-visit when we're back in town.
author: Ashley S.

description:
I am vegetarian and i loved this place . 4 of us went to this place . We all had a Glass of sangria , which is better to get by pitcher. Ordered the patatas bravas, a potato based appetizer as well as the empanadas. We finished with the vegetarian paelle. So much flavor, just the right amount and perfectly cooked vegetables . I love this place and will definitely take my vegetarian friends again . 

Ambience and service is good too :)
author: Vasini G.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the Bay Area, quaint little venue space, and amazing and authentic food. Must try.
author: Erik B.

description:
The 4 of us came to try Spanish tapas.  BFF's hubby didn't care much for the food.
The restaurant looks small from the outside but there is a 2nd room with a lot more tables. 
The outer room has a more romantic look and feel.
We shared a pitcher of Sangria, $23 which was really good.
We ordered 2 paella dishes after selecting from the menu as they do take over 30 mins to prepare.
The starters were:
Valenciana chorizo, $29, very expensive for what looks and tasted like a frittata. I wouldn't order again.
The Jamon Iberico, $15 came with deliciously but unfortunately, very thinly sliced ham which had a sweetness to it, much better than Italian ham.  There were only 6 slices to the dish.
Croquetas, $9.50 came with 4 pieces, about the size of your middle finger and aioli dipping.  This reminded me of a crab cake stick.  It was OK but no wow from me.
Empanadillas carne, $8.50 for 2 pieces which they cut into halves.  I would try this again.
Esparagos (asparagus) with cheese topping, was very good. $7.50.

Of the 2 paellas, I liked the Valenciana chorizo the best, $27. It was a small pan, enough for 2 but pushing it if you are trying to share for 3 unless it's eaten as an appetizer.  The paella marinera, $27 was also good, had good amt chunks of white fish, prawns, clams and mussels. I found the mussels had a fishy taste, as if it wasn't fresh. One in particular tasted bad and I spit it out.  They cook the paella such that a crunchy lower layer would form.  We could not finish the paellas, so we took them home and the flavors were even better the second day.  Service was good.
author: Ry T.

description: Haven't been there in a few years.  My wife and I used to go there more often when we lived in the city.  Very pleasant atmosphere and very good wait staff.  Overall food delicious, but one appetizer, I forget which, was just soso.  Sangria is absolutely delicious.  We're looking forward to another meal.
author: Jay L.

description: Great restaurant. The food is delicious. The waiters are awesome and super knowledgeable about the food and the wine. I love the ambiance and decor. I've gone a couple of times now and recommend it often to others.
author: Christina R.

description:
Very Cozy !! 

Been to other Spanish restaurants and this one is a bit more spacious, the service was great our waiter was super nice :). It's nice to see everyone in restaurants kept busy never saw anyone just standing around. 

Our food was delicious ordered: 

Empanadillas de carne, espagarros a la parilla and for main dish paella a la valenciana con chorizo . 

If around the area give this place a try!
author: Carol M.

description: Outstanding food and service. It is so rare to find a restaurant where the food is so good and you can actually have a conversation.
author: Toby H.

description: Great intimate spot that works well for a table for two or even a large group. I came here for a birthday for a party of 15 or so, and to our surprise, Alegrias has a "family style" option. We ended up opting out of it, because the crowd wasn't feeling too hungry, but I will consider it another time. All the food was very delicious. I especially remember liking the Jamon and shrimp. The paella wasn't as amazing as I have had in the city though. They had good service also.
author: Nikita K.

description: Yummy paella!!! Celebrated a friend's birthday here and the service surpassed exceptional. Our waiter was full of jokes, smiles, and laughs. I really wish I could recall his name but this was a couple of days ago.. so if you're in town or would love to go out of your way to visit Alegria's, not only will you get the awesome food but the people here are amazing at what they do. :)
author: Mischelle D.

description:
To start, we had delicious 'empanadas de bonito' and "paella Marinera" for
main course. Juan Carlos is a great waiter, speaks Spanish, and enhances the restaurant environment. To drink, we had "Estrella Galicia." We recommend it strongly.
author: Adriana S.

description: Paella negra is just an uncooked rice with black coloring and few pieces of small squid. Very disappointed, not worth the money I paid
author: Flordeliza S.

description: My husband and I stopped to eat here while in San Francisco. We had pitcher of sangria, it was enough for 2 wine glasses each and was fantastic! We ordered the Manchego Flambeado came to our table on fire, which was a great presentation and went great with the bread they serve. We shared the paella with the chicken seafood and chorizo, so delicious and was plenty for the both of us!! The staff was friendly, helpful and professional. We were served quickly and were sitted at the table we requested  (by the window). I will definitely come here again when visiting San Francisco!!
author: Marisol S.

description:
For the best paella ever
Algeria in San Francisco is the place
Love it:))))) We have been coming here for 16 years!! The best sangria we have ever drunk! The service is good and great for big group dinners too. I strongly suggest potato cubes with source and shrimps with garlic sauce!!
author: Ofer A.

description: My friend and I got there pretty early so the restaurant was super quiet. I felt I had to whisper. It got busier of course and I felt more comfortable. The server we had was really nice and was attentive the whole time we were there. We didn't order much but what we did order was great, especially the setas. Good sangria. We stayed rather late talking but they were fine with it. Good experience overall.
author: Carmen M.

description: Super nice place and proper traditional spanish food. Croquetas, jamon serrano, calamari, flan, crema catalana.. you name it! Everything delicious. We will come back to try the paella! Also, I requested a flan with a candel and even without asking my name, they knew it was my request! A super enjoyable experience.
author: Alex S.

description:
Nice, quiet, tapas place. Came in early on a Wednesday night and had a nice evening.

Our server, Juan Carlos, was perfect. Gracious and attentive.

We ordered a pitcher of Sangria which was plenty (almost too much) for two.

The menu has a good selection. We opted for the Empanadillas de carne, Jamon Iberico, and Tortilla Española to start. I would rate those in that order from most favorite to least (although the tortilla was just fine)

We ordered the Paella Valenciana which had a wonderful flavor. Rice was perfect as was the seafood. Be sure to squeeze some lemon over the paella.

For two people, the bill was $87, so it's a bit pricey, but it was good food. 

Decor is somewhat old fashioned, but good made up for it.
author: Arr V.

description:
I don't understand what all the outstanding reviews are about. My friend said it smelled like a convalescent home as soon as we walked in LOL. That pretty much ruined my appetite and for me, ambiance is a huge factor. We ordered a few hot tapas-prawns and the croquettes from what I remember. Fortunately, the prawns were decent and not gummy. We also had some sort of Spanish omelette-decent.

I wouldn't recommend coming here at all.
author: Shana B.

description:
I went there for a first try with two friends visiting from LA. We never try Spanish so just give it a shot. It's Saturday night at 8pm. It's crowded but we got table in less then 5 mins. At night you might not notice but this place is kinda old. It's cozy and very family style that somehow made you feel comfortable and relax. It's not some fancy high-end restaurant for you elite yelper. Know what it is before you go. 

The food is good. We ordered Paella a la Valenciana, crab cake, fried calamares, steam mussel, shrimp in wine sauce and croquettes. We didn't order any drinks. The best is the Paella but it really need to take 30 mins. So you've to order that first before you go through the rest of the menu. The worst is the fried calamares. No seasoning and it's wet. The tapas potion is not big. If you've more than 3 person, expect to order at least 4-5 depends on how hungry you're. The paella is enough for 2 person maybe 3 so you figure. Then it comes down to price. 5 tapas and 1 pealla it cost us $100 including tips. It's $33 per head and it's considerable on the high side. 

Overall, this is a good place to hangout once in a while. Will this be my usual joint, maybe not.
author: Jason L.

description:
Classic Spanish restaurant and ambiance. It's not exactly a place I'll cross the city for but if you're in the Marina and you want to have a quiet or even romantic dinner and be able to chat over some tapas and Sangria you could do a whole lot worse. 
The service here is super friendly and attentive. It feels like a family run place. The only reason I gave 3 stars is it feels a bit run down around the edges. The food is good but not outstanding.
author: J F.

description:
Visited for the first time this weekend. Shared tapas with friends and overall had a nice experience. The decor definitely reminds you of Spain, and the staff
are kind.

We did wait quite some time for our order to be taken, but aside from that we received our food promptly. 

I enjoyed the Jamon Iberico and olives, as well as the paella. The rice could have been slightly more tender, but overall had great flavor and a variety of garnishes. 

I'd recommend this place for tapas and wine (their wine list is great!)
author: Hayley N.

description: Alegrias hosted our wedding rehearsal dinner and like every time I've been here before for any occasion large or small presented our group with delicious food, amazing service, and warm and inviting ambiance.  Thank you to Josephine and the entire Alegrias family for a perfect evening.  We look forward to coming back again and again and again.
author: J T.

description: This was a great hole-in-the-wall find, with authentic Spanish paellas and tapas. Their selection of sherry is reasonably priced. They even accommodated to my infant daughter (too bad she was fussy during the meal).
author: Anthony N.

description:
I'm a self-confessed foodie & wine nut. And must confess: the best meal I had in 2016 was eaten here last April at Alegrias. And when my best friend was visiting the Bay Area the past month, for his last night in SF I thought to take him here. This might also allow me the opportunity to pick up the canvass wine bag I'd left at Alegrias the last time I was here. Though, then again, what were the odds that the management would still continue to hold it for me, nearly ten months later? 

We came in the door, me somewhat tweaked from a 13 hour work day, and the yucky rush hour trek from the East Bay. But the ambience, along with the wait staff seemed as welcoming as I'd remembered it. 

I mentioned the green wine bag I'd left here. And then we ordered several of my favorites: the AMAZING roasted potatoes --who knew potatoes could be the star of their own show?; the garlic prawns; the frogs' legs--which may be the most deliciously seasoned fried morsels in existence; the calamari w/ the magic pink sauce so delicious that when the calamari had disappeared, you looked for something--anything-- through which more of it could be delivered to your lips; the slightly smoky roasted asparagus covered w /melted Manchego; a special: the fish and clam dish, whose sauce was so good the serving dish got wiped clean with bread. 

But just before the procession of glorious dishes appeared, our friendly waiter Juan came by and said he had a surprise. He was holding my wine bag.  And then he said he had a very special wine available tonight. (Which didn't make sense, since we had hardly made a dent yet in the gorgeous, and reasonably priced Spanish red already on the table).  He brought the "special" wine to our table. And I noticed this bottle had notes written on it that included such things as the wines' Parker score (94) and it's drinking window. I hear myself saying: "Gee, this is the kind of thing I write on my own bottles."  And then Juan said, "This IS your own bottle--you left it in your wine bag!" (This IS a family business, so don't be surprised if they treat you like family).

And in terms of the food, it was one hit after another; perfectly realized dishes. You sensed the chef had inherited recipes from a many centuries old culinary tradition. This was real deal Spanish cooking of the highest order. And my best meal of 2017 so far!
author: Gary R.

description: Definition of hidden gem. Nondescript location on busy Lombard St gives way to a truly old school Spanish interior. This restaurant truly delights with their always excellent renditions of Spanish classics. The food is consistently delicious, the service efficient and friendly and the prices reasonable. Even better, this is an increasingly rare all family run business. Amidst a sea of never ending new, 'must visit' restaurants in SF Alegrias is one of the few we can always count on to deliver - each and every time of over over 20 visits now.
author: Don D.

description:
I love Spanish tapas and I love Alegrias. Both my visits here have been phenomenal. They have an abundant assortment of vegetarian tapas and delicious desserts. 

We got a pitcher of Sangria which was some of the best we've had in the city, 3 tapas, of which 2 were excellent and the other was a tad too rich for us. We also ordered the paella, which was perfectly seasoned and simmered. After our entrees, we tried to eat the fantastic Crema Catalana but we're too full from cleaning off the other plates to finish the dessert. 

Would highly recommend Alegrias to anyone, especially those in the mood for an intimate evening with fantastic tapas.
author: Malika R.

description:
We picked this place based on reviews. Would never go to here again. We have had great Spanish/tapas before and this place did not live up to it.
Empanadas were greasy, paella was terrible. We wanted a dessert from their menu and were told he kitchen is small and very busy if we could pick something else like the pudding or flan that didn't need any preparation.
author: Tina H.

description:
I really like this family run place.  The lighting could be better (a bit dark which makes one a bit sleepy.) The tapas were brought out too fast altogether. But the food was excellent.  The gambas al ajillo (shrimp) and setas al agillo (mushroom) were fantastic. The sauce for these dishes were simple garlic sauce with rioja wine and it was delicious. 

I also liked the olives and hot chorizo dish with apple (but skip the apple themselves - better just for flavoring). Avoid the spinach with pinebuts (too dry).
author: Rebecca C.

description: Amazing authentic Spanish food! Friendly Family-run. Romantic, cozy ambiance and so accommodating. Highly recommend the machego flambreado, gambas, empanadillias, and of course paella (de Valencia, home of paella!). Actually, can't go wrong with anything on the menu. Please go try!
author: Danessa L.

description:
I came here for my birthday dinner this year, after scouring Yelp for suggestions of some quality paella in the city. 

The ambience is pretty decent, and the service was not terrible. The entire restaurant was pretty crowded, so I'll make allowances for any lags between our waiter checking in on us. 

The sangria did not impress at all, and frankly neither did the food. It was not horrible, but it wasn't very good or what I felt to be authentic. I found the chorizo to be so-so, and that is really the main ingredient I crave in Spanish dishes. The portion sizes are also tiny for the prices. For two people, we spent over $100 on one paella, two drinks, one dessert and two tapas. Kind of nuts, if you know what this stuff goes for in Spain. Also, the menu is SMALL. The only really pleasing dish was the rice pudding, which is something I grew up on and is pretty hard to mess up.

I might go back again, but I would not really recommend them until I have a better experience.
author: Melissa T.

description: This is an excellent place to come with your spouse, friends and/ or girlfriends. The food is amazing. The paella and the tapas are excellent. The people that work here know their menu. The servers are very nice people as well.I will definitely come back again!! You must come and try it your self!
author: Aida A.

description: 7/13/2015 and 7/15/2016 Coming from NY where we have all kinds of food,  we found this by chance just walking by. We came to eat here 2 nights within 4 days.  We ate mostly from the hot tapas along with all the specials. Everything was excellent. The owners Cesar, his wife and his daughter are charming, social, friendly and a pleasure to meet.  We  ate the roasted green pepper (special), the gazpacho shooter, the white anchovies and roasted pepper specials. From the menu, the Empanadas de carne, Patatas alioli (potatoes Brava) the Conejo ( Rabbit) Croquetas de jamon y gamba, callos a la Madrilena (tripe), Calamares,  setas al ajillo (mushrooms) crab cakes, Frog legs.  we ate the Chocolate mousse cake and the ****Flan with Dulce de leche. We had a pitcher of Sangria each night, and espresso.
author: Liliana B.

description:
I went here, for my husband's birthday dinner.
The food was very good and the house Sangria was delicious as well. The ambience is very appealing and it was not that crowded. I enjoyed the silent dinner with some good music :)
author: Neha T.

description: A wonderful evening, the paella "Valencia" was delicious, as was the bread pudding, and they came up with a dessert for my lactose intolerant wife. *****!! The total experience was excellent one cannot beat a family run business. We can speak from experience, as we come from the UK and have been to Spain several times. Highly recommended.
author: Emmerich W.

description:
This place is absolutely amazing, perhaps one of the best meals I've ever had!

My boyfriend and I shared a couple of tapas including jamon iberico (delicious and salty), chorizo, bocadillos (crab cakes), manchego flambeado (cheese doused in brandy and set on fire), and sangria. Everything was delicious but in hindsight, we could have picked something else besides the chorizo.

The sangria was delicious and smooth. My boyfriend said it was the best he's had since studying abroad in Spain. The crab cakes were just about the best thing I've ever eaten. There were 2 crab cakes in a creamy jalapeno sauce... that sauce was heaven. It was smooth and subtlely spicy and I sopped it all up with bread.

I loved the decor and the service was excellent. As if I don't love San Francisco enough already, this little place is reason enough for me to move here permanently.
author: Helen D.

description:
I've gotta say yelp really disappointed me tonight... 

We came here and got the chicken, seafood and sausage paella (seafood is very fishy and a lot of the rice was stuck to the pan so we didn't get to eat much), the mushrooms were good and we liked dipping the bread in the juice, the crab cakes were okay but the portion definitely could have been better, the spinach was pretty good, the olives are really hard to screw up so those were fine, and the mussels we didn't like at all - again really fishy. The sangria was a nice addition to the meal though. 

For what we paid we definitely could have gone to much better places :(
author: danielle a.

description: Fantastic tapas menu.  Staff are friendly and helpful.  The mushrooms are one of their specialties and are out of this world good.
author: R S.

description:
Stumbled across this place last night whilst staying a few blocks away in a hotel during our San Fransisco visit.
A very authentic experience with friendly family hosts and a lovely ambience. 
We ordered all the specials and a seafood paella-all were fantastic. The lamb stuffed peppers and paella were the standouts for us. Our two young children were very satisfied with their meals also and loved the deserts (particularly the thin crepes with caramel cream). Hope to have another meal here when next in town.
author: Philip R.

description:
Have come here 2 times since my last review, and this place continues to impress me, both with waitstaff and cuisine. There's never a wait, which is surprising because of how good it is. I brought a large group of friends here and my family when they were visiting, and the tapas and paella are so, so good. I've got my order down for about 5 people: calamari, potatos with aioli, crab cakes, frog legs, mushrooms, gambas al ajillo, tortilla de chorizo, and the seafood and chorizo paella. The crab cake's sauce is out of this world, and their aioli is very special. Pitchers of sangria = necessity.

Only thing - when I came here with a bunch of girls after a few cocktails, we felt like the loudest people in the restaurant, though we were talking in normal voices. It's very quiet!

Can't wait to bring visitors back again
author: Sarah B.

description: Both time the foods were decent but nothing really popped out for me. The wine was okay as well. Perhaps I'm just not a big tapas fan.
author: Tiff W.

description:
Appearance with my wife, daughter, in-laws and brother in-law brought the owner sharing stories and warm hospitality.  
We loved the paella a la Valenciana con chorizo, which we had not tried before. 
The special white tuna empanadillas delicious and I ended with mousse and cortado again.
author: Edward A.

description:
My boyfriend and I both have several dietary restrictions, and we asked the waiter muy many questions about the ingredients in the dishes. He got the chef to come out to speak to us; the chef was extremely friendly and patient with us and gave us the full scoop on the dishes we wanted to order.

The staff here seem genuinely kind and helpful. Me likes.

The seafood paella I ordered was quite good though admittedly not the best we have tasted, but the kindness of the chef and the staff more than made up for that. They were also generous in pouring the wine - another plus. 

One of the best things we had were the appetizer olives. The flavor was unlike anything we tasted before but highly addictive. I'm not supposed to have vinegar currently, but I couldn't help myself and ate too many delicious olives.
author: Eva G.

description:
I've been to Spain many times now and I've covered a good one third of the country now eating my way through with abandon. Now even back before you had the trendy upheaval of small plates/tapas places, Alegrias existed. It used to be hard to get the cuisine and this one of the few places that offered proper renditions of tradition. On a weekend you'll probably hear music via a Flamenco guitarist, and you'll order a bunch of plates of hearty fare. Just reading the following makes me hungry:

Tortilla a la Española -
Classic Spanish potato and caramelized onion omelette

Gambas al Ajillo -
Prawns sauteed with garlic, parsley and white Rioja wine

Chistorra a la Cidra -
Chistorra sausage sauteed in Spanish cider with onions, garlic, and poached apple.

Mejillones Alegrias -
Steamed mussels in a white Rioja wine, garlic, and parsley sauce

Setas al Ajillo -
Mushrooms sauteed in garlic and white Rioja wine

Cazuela de Queso de Cabra -
Oven cooked goat cheese on a bed of red sauce

Callos a la Madrileña -
Tripe in traditional Madrid style

Espinacas a la Catalana -
Sauteed spinach with garlic, raisins, apple, and pine nuts

Patatas Alioli -
Crisp fried potatoes tossed with a traditional alioli sauce

Calamares Fritos con Alioli -
Fried calamares served with alioli sauce

Conejo a la Cazuela -
Stewed rabbit with vegetables and wine

Chistorra, callos, and the fact that they have Iberico de bellota is worth it alone. The rest of the fare is just as tasty though more common. Atmosphere and service is lively when they have a full house but can also be quiet on other days. There are few places that hold to older Spanish traditions like this. So if you want that style of food. I'd say head on over.
author: Kim N.

description:
Great Tapas!

There's a lot of selection, and the inside is very cozy.  I had the tripe, rabbit, and crab cakes.  They were delicious!  Rabbit was surprisingly ungamey.  Crab cakes were nicely fried.  The setting is very intimate.  The portions are a little small, but the taste was great.
author: Andy V.

description:
Nice people, warm setting, good menu, great service, excellent food!

We're going to Spain soon and are on a quest to get familiar with tapas and paella. This is our second Spanish meal in two weeks and tonights was far superior to last weeks. 

With only the two of us, we were limited to two tapas, one paella and one dessert. 

Empanadillas Carne - 5 - very flavorful filling with a light pastry.

Pimientos Piquillo (special tapa of the day) - 5 - well seasoned lamb and veg filling.

Paella Valenciana with Chorizo - 4 - excellent clams, mussels, prawns. Needed "bark". Next time we'll know to ask for it and they cook it a little longer on the stove.

Panqueque Manzanas - 4 - non-traditional dessert of apple crepe flambéed with rum and served with vanilla ice cream.

We also had a glass of Sangria (4), Ice Tea, Café con Leche and a Cortado. 

We'll be back soon to try more tapas!
author: Dexter D.

description:
Don't get me wrong, for a place on the otherwise ugly Lombard, Alegrias was charming and intimate. Service was great. But the food... really not so.

We ordered an array of tapas to share and not one was amazingggg, but overall quite average. Both of us dining have spent a good amount of time in Spain so maybe this explains why.

If you're looking for an easy reservation, and a cute place, with good to ok food, try it out. But if you're really craving great Spanish food, try Zarzuela on Hyde, or if you can get a reservation, definitely go to Coqueta on the Embarcadero.
author: Rachel L.

description:
The atmosphere in this restaurant is very down-home country, like a farmer's house in rural Spain and less like a festive tapas bar that you may be expecting. The food, though, is fantastic. Our favorite things were the calamares fritos con alioli, the cazuela de queso de cabra, and the bocadillos de cangrejo (crab cakes). The calamari were perfectly cooked in such a light batter, and the sauce to dip them in was super-savory. The baked goat cheese dish is always one of my favorites at tapas places, and Alegrias's version was tops. The crab cakes were cooked perfectly as well-- and we sopped up all the sauce with the bread pieces we had.

The only skippable thing we tried were the empanadillas vegetarianas, the vegetarian empanadas. They just sort of had a strange flavor I wasn't into-- but the pastry was excellent!

We also treated ourselves to sangria and chocolate mousse for dessert. The sangria was some of the best I've had, very well-balanced and full-bodied. And the mousse? We talked about it for days after.

This place is definitely a bit of a splurge, as the term 'small plates' aptly describes the portions here. We'd come back for the food-- but it would have to be a special occasion.
author: Allison M.

description: Great paella, but I'd recommend going somewhere else for dessert.  We tried the squid ink paella and the seafood paella, and both were amazing.  The tapas were also pretty good.  however, the two desserts we tried tasted a little funky.
author: Cici A.

description: Amazing food, wonderful ambience, and excellent service. There are not a lot of places in SF that serve authentic Spanish tapas and Alegrias is absolutely delicious! The seafood paella and the octopus tapas are a must!
author: Ayngi B.

description: From start to finish my girlfriend and I had a wonderful dining experience. We had our anniversary dinner here and could not have picked a better restaurant. Great tapas. Even better service. I highly recommend this place for a quality date night out in the Marina. We even found parking right around the corner! We will be back.
author: Isaiah E.

description: Authentic Spanish (not Mexican!) cuisine.  I went specifically for the paella Valenciana and was not disappointed.  It took 35 minutes to prepare - just right to make sure all the rice was properly cooked.  The chef/owner came out and asked if it was as expected (I did tell the waiter not to present the dish until it was properly cooked).  We had a long and friendly discussion on all things Spain - delightful man and excellent conversationalist.  The tapas and sherry were both excellent and the wine list good and not overpriced.  Will return.
author: Richard C.

description: Came here for my birthday dinner with girl friends and enjoyed all of the dishes! The Sangria was delicious as well. :)
author: Michelle C.

description: Great service and great food. Good place to go with a group. You can share 5,6 plates with 5 people.
author: Keiko O.

description: I love Spanish food so I made a reservation here for my birthday. We were a large group and the staff took really good care of us! The service is great. The restaurant is dimly lit and has a very intimate feel to it - it would make a cute date spot. The food was delicious, and I can't remember how many sangria pitchers we ordered but I do remember we kept ordering them because they were super yummy. The delectable paellas were my favorite! We ordered several different kinds and they were all amazing. The tapas were good, and a decent portion too. The only thing I would say is that the desserts we ordered tasted strange, so maybe go somewhere else for a sweet course. All in all, they made my birthday dinner a very pleasant experience!
author: Maisa M.

description:
Awesome tapas restaurant! Quaint, magical, romantic with nice decor/ambience! 
Highly recommend for a nice quiet evening with excellent food and great service.

We had all the vegetarian options - empandilas, mushrooms, spinach, lentil soup, manchego cheese flambe, asparagus, veg paella. Everything was excellent! 

Must-visit...checkout the wall paintings when you are there, apparently I was told the owner draws/paints...reminded me of Dali.
author: Mihir M.

description:
I love this place! Their sangria is so good, fruity but gives you a good kick!
I love their shrimp, fire cheese, and just about everything!
author: Mary T.

description:
PERFECT for large groups. Came here for a 12 person dinner and we ordered a la carte. They were so speedy that we were out of there after 1.5 hours (this included about 6 carafes of sangria).  Super cheap, super delicious, definitely great for groups.

The potatoes Aioli were the best i've ever had . we literally ordered 6 bowls b/c the first 2 went in 10 seconds.  Great paella as well. Croquets were decent and so were the mussels. Overall no complaints from our group!!
author: Alice Z.

description:
Pros:
- Their beef empanadas are pretty good
- Service was good - granted there were only 2 tables being served

Cons:
- Their beef empanadas cost 9 bucks for 2. They are tiny. 
- All their portions are tiny. I understand they sell "tapas" but they should use that as an excuse to charge like a normal plate and be cheap on portion sizes
- All the dishes I ordered were below average. I can cook better Spanish food. 
- I've been to Spain, and compared to food there. This place is a 2/10. 
- Too expensive for what you get.
author: Alejandro S.

description:
I contacted the owner Ceasar a few days before my wife's birthday in order to setup a big birthday dinner (25+ people). Ceasar was amazing. Extremely friendly and professional. They were able to accommodate all of us within a short notice, something that is not very common in SF. 

We opted for the Tapas + salad prefixed menu which was more then enough food. They were very generous with the food and the food was delicious. Everyone really enjoyed it. 

Overall, I would come back here for such events or even small dinners anytime. The service, food and everything was top notch.
author: Jad Y.

description:
Went to this place with the expectation of the food similar to what I had in Jaleo in DC downtown. The food was not close to Jaleo at all. The food here was ok. Nothing memorable. We had Gambas al Ajillo - the only item which was really good. Manchego Flambeado was very very rich. Paella a la Valenciana was not good at all. It was bland and flavorless. I think i had expected too much from this dish but I didn't like. May be this is how it's served in Spain.. I don't know..

Would I go again?? I don't think so.
author: Hemal K.

description: We ordered so many tapas, I had no idea what I was eating, but they were all amazing. I'm not usually a fan of sangria, but theirs was delicious. For desert we had a couple crepes. The crepe with dulce de leche was so so, but the one with rum, which was flaming as it came to the table was terrible. It was pure rum, hardly cut with anything else and way too strong. Either it wasn't made right or it was just plain bad.
author: David R.

description:
Good they managed to squeeze us in on a busy Saturday night when every other place had a wait time of 45 min at least.

However this place is expensive for the average food and tiny portions.

The sangria was watery and bitter. Didn't like it.

The paella was average. I have had better in Castro street mountain view. The worst part was asking us to scrap off even the burnt paella at the bottom. It definitely wasn't the best part of the paella as the chef insisted. Ruined the entire paella for us.

The  complimentary bread was cold and olive oil was below average.

For the location and ambience, the chef can do better.
author: R B.

description: I'm here now and I'm so impressed with hospitality of the chef and waiters. The food is fantastic! I highly recommend the spinach dish, cuddle fish special and crab cakes.
author: Maya B.

description:
Outstanding Spanish spot for tapas and excellent paella. Nice quiet setting for an easy unrushed meal.

A bit inconsistent in the service - one server said we could not order a 2nd 1/2 glass of wine, the next brought it cheerfully. Why say no?  It was a bit annoying, but not enough to avoid this great little place.
author: George S.

description:
When I walked it, the first thing I thought was.. "Damn this is such a romantic atmosphere. I would want my wedding reception like this" hahaha!

White and brick walls filled with paintings, ceramic plate displays, tile art, and white Christmas lights! Fluffy white cloth draped from the ceiling giving it that "tent" feel. 

This food was okay.  It wasn't anything too special compared to the other tapa's I've had.
