In all, a reliable place for a decent meal and a solid go-to when you don't feel like thinking too hard about where to go for dinner.
author: Les M.

description: Horrible service. Food was okay. We made a reservation, got seated, then sat there for a good 20 minutes, then finally someone came with water and took our order. Food overall was decent, nothing amazing. Our water was finished half way into our meal (food was pretty salty) and the waiter did not pour us more water. We instead watched him poured water for everyone around us.  By the time he looked over to us, we already finished our meal and just wanted to leave. Then of course it takes them another 10 minutes to get us our check. Time was wasted, food was average, dying of thirst, 1 star.
author: Quynh N.

description:
Been here several times now and I think it's safe to say that I love it. I've done dinner with family, girls night out, casual lunch.. and its always deliver. 

I love eating tapas style and able to munch around on all different kinds of food. In case you're from "middle of nowhere Ammurrica, " tapas is eating in small plates, appetizer-like. The food was great and they have a selection for those looking for veggies, sea food, some fried goodies and cheese. In all occasions we've order pitchers of sangrias and MY, OH MY... It was really good.  Do it!

The prices for tapas range from $6- $9, I've been there with a party of 5 and out bill came out to only $115 and we got to try about 7-10 plates and  paella. Speaking of paella, it's delicious but I've had inconsistencies. Sometime is really yummy and sometime it lacks something. 

Customer service is good, I've had maybe an incident or two but minor things. Like the waiter forgot to bring out an order of tapas.. but for the most part they are good.
author: Abby O.

description: This is a nice, almost homely place. Our server was extremely friendly and took his time explaining the house specials to us. The crab cakes with the creamy jalapeno sauce were great. We had the vegetarian Spanish style turnovers with the leftover jalapeno sauce from the crab cakes, which was a pretty good combination. We also tried their house special of the baked codfish tapas, which seafood lovers will like. I'm generally a fan of paella, and the seafood paella here was good. It was loaded with seafood. Personally, I would have preferred it a little less loaded with seafood and more rice, but I'm not complaining much.
author: Sahil S.

description:
I recently returned from Cambodia where I bought some cheap saffron at the Night Market Angkor Wat...I was inspired to try and make Paella.
Armed with my saffron I went to the 99Ranch and picked up some chicken thighs, squid, clams, shrimp, peppers and chorizo from next door at las Montoyas.
I also watched a Martha cooks episode and she said to disperse or mix in the saffron with cognac and a dash of coarse salt.  The Martha recepie left the thighs whole and she added string beans and peas...this however did not appear correct having searched for the perfect paella while in Barcelona.
My friend added artichoke hearts as his secret ingredient and I added green olives.
My pan was pretty tasty and achieved the desired socarrat when finished off on the stovetop...my saffron tasted woody.  
My friend finished his pan in the oven where the clams opened up perfectly.
Bottom line...
Try the paella here...I liked it and they had a seperate seafood or a meat paella.
author: Cee G.

description:
I came here by complete accident once, walking down Lombard with some friends, one of whom had lived in Spain and knew what to get. Its also one of the yummiest meals I've ever eaten. 

We ordered about half the menu, a bunch of wine, and consumed it all. Its such a happy blur...
author: Catt G.

description:
quaint place on a busy street in the marina...the waiter had quite the quirky and hospitable character...

the plus of the night was definitely the fried calamares...and the special of the night (red pepper stuff with lamb)..the paella was a bit too moist for my taste, and the empanadilla was on par with other places..

docking points for not bring bread, even after asking for it...had to ask twice to get it
author: Long C.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised.  I've walked by this place a million times, and never thought twice about it.  I went with a very large group (around 15 people) last night, with a fixed menu due to the size.  The restaurant is understated, romantic, and has a very comfortable ambiance.  The food was really solid.  What I liked about it was that we had a big group, and everybody had several tapas that they really liked.  Plenty of vegetarian options, which aren't my thing so much but went over well.  I thought the calamari, shrimp, and new potatoes were excellent.  The vegetarians in our group went wild for the olives provided on the table, the mushrooms, and the omelettes.  Sangria was good, and the refills for our fixed menu were extremely generous.  My glass was never less than half full.  They were very accommodating to our large group, but I think that it would be just as good a choice for a romantic date night.  

While the vibe was definitely "tapas", it had a more elegant and intimate feel than many other tapas places I've been to in SF, many of which are noisier and have a more communal/"fun night out" vibe.

I would definitely come back.
author: James S.

description:
Yum!

The paellas were fabulous!!  We had the Paella Valenciana with Chorizo and the Paella Negra.   They were both great, especially the black paella.  Very good!!

Tapas:  grilled asparagus (good), jamón ibérico (very good), pimientos padrones (very good), tortilla española (very good), chistorras (very good)

The ambiance was quiet and nice, the decor is elegant and pretty, the staff friendly and prompt.

I really enjoyed Alegrias and would go again; in particular, for their paellas.
author: Rita F.

description:
First time eating Spanish Tapas, so I was looking forward to this dinner.

Dishes that stood out:
1) Empandillas - Good 
2) Mussels - juicy and soft texture.  The sauce was good too.


OK dishes:
1) Spanish sausage - forgettable and couldn't taste the apples
2) Shrimp - nothing really stood out

Good service, medium level pricing, expect to pay $30-40 per person.  Portions were small, but it's expected for Tapas, so fill up on the bread!!
author: Ben S.

description:
Found this on yelp and decided to give it a try with some friends and ended up being a perfect evening. It is done up with a Spanish feel and you really like you are in another country. 

I recommend starting with the Sangria which make the food taste a little better as well. All the tapas that we had were delicious. Tried a bunch of different ones and ended up repeating a few, the sausage and potato fritters.  Dessert was heaven! I don't think you can go wrong with the food here.  The only slight negative was the service which could have been more attentive. 

Recommend going here with some friends and plan to stay for a few hours and enjoy good drinks, food and conversation.
author: Sunil R.

description: Great tapas.  Jamon Iberico. Have yet to try their paellas.  Super reasonably priced Spanish wines.  Excellent, sweet service.  It feels like a family-run place.  Go.
author: Nate P.

description: Wife and I had reservations for 6 pm but arrived at 5:30, we entered and informed an elderly lady who more than likely was Nora. She greeted us with a rude and obnoxious attitude to say the least. We ordered the Asparagus Tapa, it was overcooked and disgusting. We did take notice that when caucasian patrons entered she greeted them with an overwhelming cheerful smile, SF is a multi racial city she had better get used to it and if she continues this racist demeanor she can bet her lucky stars that she will be out of business in just a matter of time! Will inform clients, family and friends not to patronize this establishment.
author: Ray D.

description:
great restaurant 
I love the squid ink pella the most
good service
author: Ross Z.

description:
My party of 7 came here for dinner.  They do take reservations, it wasn't busy that Friday night we went.  We had our table in the back close to the kitchen.  

We pretty much ordered every single tapas off their menus.  It comes in small portion, perfect for 2.  It seems like they are all about garlic and spices which made every single dish a winner.  Try them all the frog, the lamb wrapped in red bell pepper, the mussels were extra succulent, the ham, marinated olives, the shrimp, the calamari, the potatoes - they were all good, must try dishes.

We had the sausage and sea food paellas and their lamb specials as entrees - we kept digging and everything one.

Sangria is smooth and mild.  Yes, I'd recommend it.

Service was fantastic but became touch and go towards the end.  We were enjoying each other's company and was staying longer than anticipated maybe, but it wasn't busy.  I had requested for water twice and was ignored.  Is it because we already paid our $350 bill?  I'd think we deserve good treatment all the way.  Whatever the reason was for a less than perfect at then end, still is not an excuse.

We all had a grand time and food was great.  I'd go back...
author: Pam S.

description: What a cute place!  I went with 3 friends and we all LOVED everything we ordered.  Even the bread and olive oil were delicious.  And the desserts were amazing... even the coffee was exceptional.  Seriously, you can't go wrong with the food here.  The service was really nice and the prices reasonable.  Note, this is an older restaurant so it has that kind of charm.  It's a great place to bring anyone over 35.  I can't wait to take my dad and enjoy that delicious food again!
author: Elena I.

description:
I went here because the Argentinian knows the owner, Cesar. He ordered in Spanish so I have no idea what I was getting into but food and drink just kept coming and I kept eating. 

Saturday night and the restaurant was busy but not so packed that we felt rushed. Cesar told us that business was insane after they appeared on Check, Please but it's leveling out with occasional spikes when their episode airs. Cesar is absolutely charming and was a real treat to speak to.  The darling caricature drawings of girls on the wall, all were done by his daughter.  She's a lucky girl because her father speaks very proudly of her as well as his son, who is also an artist. 

The waiters were attentive and accommodating, the food was excellent, and the ambiance was lovely. Hopefully when I come back the next time, boquerones will be back on the menu. Yum!
author: Chum L.

description: Fantastic top quality Tapas.   Not much else to be said, everyting from start to finish was excellent.  Go.
author: Johnny C.

description:
Simply delightful dinner with great service and a classy ambience. 

Aunthentic Spanish cuisine! The Paella was to die for! Sangria was very refreshing and even my girlfriend who doesn't drink enjoyed a few gulps of it.

Definitely worth a try, you would not be disappointed!
author: Philip K.

description: Had a nice little roommate dinner here. It's pretty fancy looking considering the price. Highly recommend for a date. The food was pretty good, it was a little while back so can't remember specifics.
author: Michael J.

description:
We came to Alegria's to celebrate a friend's birthday. On a Thursday night, I was expecting it to be packed but it wasn't too busy. It's the perfect place for a date-night or a quiet dinner and last night there were a lot of couples there. We felt bad because we're a bit of a rowdy bunch when we all get together and we didn't want to ruin their dinner, haha.

Alegria's serves tapas style. We were served bread for starters and they had extra virgin olive oil for dipping. We ordered:

-Patatas Alioli; fried potatoes in an aioli sauce, really crispy and the sauce was delicious
-Bocadillos de Cangrejo; crabcakes in a creamy jalapeno sauce, melt-in- your-mouth good!
-Tortilla a La Espanola; potato and carmelized onion omelette, this was our favorite of the two omelettes, the sauce on top is awesome
-Tortilla de Chorizo; potato, carmelized onion, and chorizo omelette
-Manchego Flambeado; cheese flambe with brandy, great presentation and the cheese was really melty and creamy
-Gambas al Ajillo; shrimp in a garlic and wine sauce, garlic and wine sauce was tasty and perfect for dipping with the bread

We all shared the tapas and our favorites were the patatas alioli, bocadillos de cangrejo, and the gambas al ajillo. We did like both of the omelettes but the tortilla de chorizo, while pretty good, was a bit of an overkill. The crabcakes were definitely one of the best I've had and I'd recommend ordering a couple plates because they only come in two's. 

For dessert we shared the panqueques de manzana and some kind of cake with a raspberry sauce but I can't remember what it's called. The panqueques were sweet and you could really taste the rum and the apple.

Service was great! Our server was very knowledgeable, attentive and explained everything on the menu. 

Alegria's is a great for sharing and trying different tapas. I definitely want to come back for a date-night!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I have always enjoyed my visits to Alegrias for their delicious food and quaint, Spanish ambiance. Tonight was especially great because my birthday dinner with 16 guests took place there...

From planning the event through carrying it out, the Alegrias experience was fantastic. Because the group was more than 10 people, we were required to partake of the Prix Fixe menu which has two options:

1. Salad + 9 tapas for $28.00+tax+tip
2. Salad + 9 tapas+paella for $36.00+tax+tip

Our group went with the paella option and we couldn't have been happier. Even one of my guests who is a born and raised Madrilean said that the food really tasted like we were in Madrid. He especially loved the tortilla espanola. The tapas were fresh off the grill/stove/oven and delicious: patatas aioli, shrimp, mushrooms, sausages, olives, tortilla espanola, etc. The crowning jewel was the exquisite paella - just the right texture and taste. Everyone in the group loooved the food and we had so much that they still gave us a big platter of paella to go. We were stuffed...

The sangria received rave reviews from the crowd as well...

We also had superb service with the owner (Cesar) and the waitstaff constantly checking on us and attending to our every need. Cesar chatted with me several times on the phone as I planned the event and really made sure that every detail and need was covered. He was professional, friendly, and very welcoming to me and our group. 

To recap: Delicious food, beautiful ambiance, great service! I would have another event here in a heart beat and highly recommend that you do too!
author: M B.

description:
Impromptu birthday dinner for a couple of months  back but there were quite accommodating!

It wasn't too busy when we entered the restaurant and definitely gives you an upscale romantic mood immediately. Alegrias is a quiet setting with many tiny tables all around. My date and I sat there for quite some time chatting and enjoying each other without any rush or pressure.

We ordered a full bottle of Rioja (which was beautiful to its last drop), Manchego Flambeado (Manchego flambe'd with Brandy), steamed mussels, and a Paella a la Marinera (Seafood Spanish rice).

The Manchego was nicely done and had strong flavors with the brandy and not bitter at all which was a big plus.

The Steamed mussels were salivating and perfectly prepared, robust and full of garlic flavors. Delicious.

The Paella was not overdrenched in sauce, had fresh seafood and came burning warm.

Mmm! I couldn't want but to try more but I didn't have enough space for any more food. We finished out bottle of wine and went on our way.

The place is a little bit out of the way for me, but definitely romantic and quiet.
author: Winè C.

description:
Food recs:  Tortilla de chorizo, Patatas fritas

Cost:  Takes credit, slightly more expensive than what I think the food should be worth.

Service:  Friendly, timely, relaxed but classy environment

Overall:  Most dishes had a lot of olive oil which made them taste similar to each other.  Would come back to try the Jamon Iberico, but nothing else.  Only recommend ordering from the tapas menu.  A more accurate rating of this restaurant would be 3.5 stars.
author: Angela T.

description:
A tapa place. Portions are small but everything was tasty. Sangria was just an average

The Calenciana Chorizo Paella was very good. A very quiet place good for date. However it is very crowded so our chair always got knocked by servers walked by.
author: Gigi L.

description:
This is my 2nd time here.   The first time the food was great!. 

This time I think the food was well prepared, but my date asked for a bunch of things which I didn't like.   Deep Fried Frogs Legs?  Well, I tried it, I'm not a fan.   I don't like deep fried things much anyway.

We had a great time.  The service and seating was very good. 

I would have liked it better if I ordered some other tapas from which I had, but I can't say that any of them were bad, just not to my liking (Yes, I picked 2 myself and they were new ones which I haven't tried and they weren't what I was expecting, but looking at the menu, exactly as they described)
author: Bill K.

description:
Alegrias stole my virginity for tapas. Three years ago, I had my very first tapa dish here and I thought it was the best thing ever. 

It was Eugenia G.'s birthday, in which, she held a small and intimate celebration at this cozy restaurant. Being clueless (at the time) to this cuisine, I was open to anything on the menu. A few members from the party did the ordering and I was having much pleasure tasting each dish that was brought to our table. 

Since then, I did venture out to try other tapa restaurants. Every now and then I would even come back to Alegrias for more rounds of their dishes but after trying new places, I've come to realized that Alegrias is good but not great. 

They have a moderate selection of cold and hot tapas, and they also serve entrees. I usually order a few tapa dishes, followed by a paella to share. 

Some of my all time favorites from their menu: 
- Jamon Serrano: Imported Spanish cured ham 
- Cazuela de Queso de Cabra: Oven baked goat cheese on a bed of red sauce 
- Calamares Fritos con Alioli: Fried calamares served with alioli sauce 
- Paella a la Valenciana: Classic saffron flavored Spanish rice with chicken and seafood 

I guess it's true when they say "You will always find new interests, but you'll never forget your first."
author: Jenny K.

description: The food and wine was amazing! Great place and wonderful ambiance.
author: Alexa N.

description:
My friend and I have come up with an alternative word for mediocre... Alegrias. If only it can be added into the dictionary...

I have never witnessed a restaurant more barren and mediocre. I went there with a friend and it turned out to be memorable for being particularly unmemorable - awkward service, sub-par food, and a rather sinister ambiance. 

Our waiter was much older with a condescending demeanor and a countenance that could surpass that of Robert De Niro in Meet the Parents - unwelcoming and irritated. He also maintained an abnormally close distance to the two of us that we always felt a bit "watched." Yes, definitely creepy. 

The food wasn't horrible or inedible, just very plain and flavor-less. We tried to justify it by thinking we might have ordered poorly but we ordered at least 6 items on their menu and not even one was particularly noteworthy! We ordered the prawns, mussels, the crisp fried potatoes, fried calamari, crab cakes and the seafood & chicken paella. I suppose out of all the items, the better ones were the crab cakes and crisp fried potatoes. Everything else was a completely unmemorable miss. 

Lastly, the ambiance is clearly authentic but somehow ends up feeling a bit sinister. I think it must have been a combination of the creepy waiter, the completely red theme and the fact that we were one of the only ones in the restaurant on an allegedly busy Friday night. 

So although it probably wasn't the worst experience ever, you're better off checking out one of the other million tapas places in the city.
author: Priya S.

description: Little pricey for what it is but if you are craving some real Spanish food this is the spot.
author: Kathryn H.

description: A very romantic place for date night! Really good Sangria and the crab cakes were devine!!!
author: Kiran J.

description:
Since I live in the neighborhood, might as well try this place.   I saw a few good reviews and thought why not.

Very quint, delicate, intimate setting.  Very cute romantic ambiance.  We were seated immediately and ordered sangria cause yelp said it was good.  (Again-Yelp is right!)

Dinner (small plates so order lots):
-Bocadillos de Cangrejo - Crab cakes served with a mild creamy jalapeño sauce (really small)  Great sauce though!
-Paella a la Marinera - Classic saffron flavored Spanish rice with seafood (amazing!  Great Paella)  Very generous with the seafood and packed with great flavors!

-Red peppers stuffed with Lamb - I don't know the name of this dish but I heard amazing things about it.  It was no longer on the menu but was featured as a special.  So I had to order it.  SO WORTH IT!   One order only came out with three peppers.  I ordered an extra because it was so good!  I also asked for more bread to wipe up the sauce. DELICIOUS! 
 -Sangria is a must.  Comes in a pitcher and was gone by the time food hit the table :)

Great experience here!
author: Ying F.

description:
What a pleasant surprise!! I had heard from a friend about this place and didn't have high expectations for it. The atmosphere is kinda rustic and maybe a little dated but the food - wow! My friends and I ordered about 6 tapas and shared a paella - absolutely delicious and will be coming back.

We were a bit disappointed in the Sangria though - it seemed either watered down or non-alcoholic... We had two pitchers and didn't feel a thing. Believe me, I'm no alcoholic or anything but I thought something was up...not even a slight buzz from the stuff. Sooo, get some wine!
author: Leanne S.

description:
Don't know what the 4 stars are all about

Went their last night
Sangria's are average
Had the rabbit appetizer which was descent
The chicken chorizo paella was average 
The lamb chops , not on the  menu , were good

Service was average and was not seated in a corner even when the restaurant was empty and scoffed up $100 for two people which I thought was a bit overpriced for the food, ambiance and the service.

An average overpriced meal is how I would summarize it
author: Vaibhav S.

description:
Great Sangria!  In an awesome pitcher as well... only $20!
Went to dinner here with 6 other friends and everything was fabulous!  We ordered a couple dishes each and were still able to share everything between us.  
We ordered paella con chorizo, shrimp, empanadillas carne,  grilled asparagus (just ok), crab cakes, patatas alioli, and all the specials which included shrimp in an incredible sauce, frog legs and the croquettes of the day.  
Servers were attentive and helpful, lighting low, good ambiance for our group.  
I would go here again, love tapas dining!  It's the only way to try everything I want!
author: Megan S.

description:
More like 2.5 stars.

Came here on a Friday night for tapas and beyond 2 medium sized groups, the place was pretty empty--probably a sign. The ambiance was romantic, the sangria was spot on (a pitcher for $20), but the food was...bland. 

We ordered: 
Empanadillas de Carne ($7.95)--the turnover dough was crispy, but the combination of veggies and beef didn't have that pop of flavor that I was expecting.
Tortilla de Chorizo ($9.95)--more of a spongy, flat omelette. Disappointing because chorizo has so much potential.
Manchego Flambeado ($7.95)--imagine cheese, in a bowl, on fire! 
Bocadillos de Cangrejo ($9.95)--two generic, small, crispy crab cakes. I was looking forward to the jalapeño sauce, but I didn't get any sort of jalapeño 'kick.'

The service was fine. Would have been better if we were offered water. 
My suggestion: go elsewhere.
author: Briana F.

description:
The Good-The Tapas were pretty tasty

The Bad-The squid ink Paella was pretty lame and small for 21 bucks..a bunch of dark rice w/some tasteless calamari rings..obvious that the attention to detail was lacking.For a Spanish restaurant it should have been stellar......

The Ugly-Service was OK but I shouldnt have to ask to have plates cleared when Im spending 100 bucks for dinner!
author: james m.

description:
We had reservations for a party of 4 at 8:30 on a Friday night.  We only waited 2 minutes before we were seated.  Our server was very patient because we had a picky eater in our group who didn't mind expressing out loud her dislike for "this" and "that".   She was a package deal if you get my drift .. *ahem  (friends wife) ahem*

Patatas alioli $6.95:  I'm accustom to having the aoli on the side to dip the potatoes.  I was afraid that their method would result in soggy  potatoes because they toss it in the sauce ahead of time but to my surprised it was still crispy. 

Fried Calamari $9.95:  I agree with the other yelp reviews.  The batter was rather gummy.

Gambas Al Ajillo $9.95: Wasn't memorable.  The Spanish wine they used in the dish gave it a weird after taste. 

Valenciana paella with chorizo $22.95:  Really good but for the price it was smaller 
than what I had anticipated.  However, It's a good thing we ordered 3!  This was their saving grace.  I wish there were more crispy bits at the bottom of the pan.  

Manchego Flambeado $7.95:  Theatrics aside it was just ok.  The brandy they used for the flambé wasn't the greatest. 

Panqueque Mananas $7.25: It's a dessert that's ... yup you guessed it flambé.  We ordered it to share but I don't have a sweet tooth so I passed and had a cup of decaf coffee.

After all said and done it came out to about $150 with tax and tip. I would not return.
author: Sun T.

description: The Food was excellent, I recommend the tripe! I loved the Manchego cheese flambe! :)  the servers were friendly, just when you maybe thought they weren't being attentive, they would do something to make up for it, like replace your used dishes with fresh clean ones. I drink water like crazy, so... I don't expect places to have it filled immedietly. I also tried several spanish beers, one I preferred, the other, my friend preferred. So... maybe you should try each one to see your favorite pick. I regret not trying the sangria after reading the other reviews. The decor is great, nice and calm, beautiful lights. Nice date place.
author: Elisa M.

description:
A girlfriend introduced me to this spot and I'm sooo grateful that she did!

Such a quaint, intimate, restaurant with its dim lighting and white linen tablecoths.  I love the ambiance and the mixed crowd - all ages.  

Their staff is professional, friendly, and knowledegable.  Tapas style delectables and all were delicous - empanadillas, fried calamari, steamed clams/mussels, crab cakes, paella, to name a few.

Great for a small group or an intimate dinner for two!
author: Diana M.

description:
I am never disappointed  after dining here at Alegrias; I leave with a smile and a full belly every time. From the attention to detail in the decor, the hospitable staff, delicious items, to the casual / cozy / romantic atmosphere - this place is a favorite of mine.

The menu is extensive and pretty authentic in its offerings. For those of you who have limited/stubborn ordering patterns, this place will definitely open up your eyes to try something new. 

Some of my favorite dishes are:
-Tortilla de Chorizo
-Gambas al Ajillo
-Pulpo a la Gallega
author: E E.

description: what a really good place, from costumer service to the decort  and food , no doub that in alegrias you will find a really good food at affortable price, i will come back to this place with me family!!!!!!!
author: Luis A.

description:
Found this on yelp. Was looking for something to eat after work. It's right off Lombard and easy to find. When we entered I thought it was very quiet. There were only a few other couples in the joint. 
We were seated promptly.
We decided on a selection of tapas instead of a main course. The tapas we chose were:  the assortment of cheese ( I highly suggest this, it was a good amount of cheese for two people, we got three different kinds and it was all new to me and my boyfriend! ), We also tried the snails & clams in red sauce, very good and tender!  Loved the flavor of the clams and the sauce was great to use for dipping our bread in afterwards. We had the rabbit stew tapas also, which was a little bone-y but very very good. I loved the flavors in the stew.

I thought all of our food was very flavor full and delicious!

Lastly, we had the flan for dessert. I love flan, but it was similar to any place you'd get flan at.. 

I wish I would of tried the paella.
author: Katrina M.

description: This is bar-none my favorite tapas restaurant in the Bay Area. I try to eat here at least once every 2-3 months. Favorite dishes include the croquettas, the veggie paella, and a couple of off-menu items that the chef makes for the regulars. The cherry on top: it's family-owned and the staff is incredibly friendly and professional. I absolutely adore them.
author: Kate S.

description:
Great place and nice food! 
My friend and I shared a Pealla and a tapa(didn't remember the name but tatsty) in a sunday night, such a nice dinner we had. The food was delicious and the service was really really great. All people there are friendly and welcomed. Also like the decor and atmosphere there, a warmly familiy-like restaurant.  We will definitely be back! 100% recommend!
author: Diane L.

description:
Hmmm... So This place loves up to it's yelp reviews. Definetley a 3 star, maybe 2.5 from end.

The tapas were good... The paella.. not so much.
The seafood was a little dry in the paella. Although the vegas empandas and shrimp croquettes were delicious.

The ambiance its the catch... looks like grandmas cabinet..lol
not as hip as it sounds. Kind of has an old italian resturant feel to it..

Parking is tough. Service is good. Drink options very few (non-Alcholic)

um... yea I wouldn't go again.
author: Muneera M.

description:
What did coach used to say -- "let your game speak for itself"?

Alegrias has got game. I was shocked to find such great food located on Lombard St (aka the 101 highway). Their Spanish cuisine is terrific and hole-in-the wall atmosphere was refreshing. This no-frills dining experience is all about killer tapas (and paella!) and wastes no time trying to impress via ornate decor or posh anything. Like I said... refreshing.

I have had the paella and a slew of tapas. The gambas, paella and the tortilla were all memorable, but everything was pretty delicious. A new neighborhood favorite for sure!
author: Peter C.

description:
Nice atmosphere and good food.

The staff was pleasant and very attentive.

We had the tapas and a paella some of the tapas were a little different than other Spanish restaurants I've been to but not in a bad way.

The paella we had was perfectly cooked but it could have used more saffron and less tomato it had a nice authentic crust by the outside of the pan and overall was delicious.
author: G C.

description: Uber romantic and cozy setting.  Generous portion sized tapas, but heavily fried food. The fried calamari in light colored batter and alioli dipping sauce (Calamares Fritos con Alioli) was so artery clogging tasty.  The poached octopus dish (Pulpo a la Gallega) was the first dish in a long time that reminded me of being forced to eat flavorless chunks of poop lookalike liver as a kid because it was "good for me" (obviously still need therapy for this).  Thoroughly enjoyed the Tortilla a la Española (potatoes and onion omelet), but was so full by that point that I could not try the Empanadillas de Carne (beef turnovers).  Might go back and try other dishes.
author: Peg S.

description:
Went here as part of the perpetual search for great paella. Turns out a lot more is happening here, too, to wit:

1.Empanadillas de Carne: these can be found with many seasonings, depending on the country of origin, but what a winner this one is! The lightness and delicacy of the crust, together with the richness of the filling, makes this version a must.

2.Escalivada (grilled eggplant/onions/peppers):  exotic with a light flavor of smoke from the grilling, plus the gentle sweetness added by the oil/sherry vinegar combination. Best bread topping yet!

3. Pimientos del piquillo rellenos con cordero (peppers stuffed with lamb): the peppers are similar to those found in a Mexican relleno, but softer in texture and more delicately flavored. The lamb stuffing was very rich, but not with the characteristic lamb aroma. This will thrill some and disappoint others. I personally love grilled lamb chops with the taste of olive oil, sage, and garlic, and lots of lamb aroma, and I still loved this. In other words, I think this dish will please most everyone.

4. The staff: everyone was attentive, friendly, and knowledgeable about the dishes on offer. The owner/chef met us on the way out and solicited our feedback (we had raved about the empanadillas and I guess the word got out). He's a super guy if you get to talk to him, and clearly (justifiably) proud of his culinary achievements.

5. Oh yeah, the paella: We had the Marinera (no sausage or chicken). This one's all about the fish. Very slight saffron character in the rice, shrimp very fresh and minimally (correctly) cooked, fish and mussels super fresh and imparting the brine and mineral of the sea to the sauce. Wow. Great purity of seafood flavors, which is in my opinion not possible with chicken or sausage in the mix.

Hence, 5 stars. Thanks!
author: Leonard S.

description:
This restaurant is the closest you will get to authentic spanish food in San Francisco.

Sangria: To die for.

Paella Valenciana con Mariscos: I could have the entire thing myself. 

Callos a la Madrilena: It's so good I get depressed once I finish it because I want more.

Flan: Divine.

Everything is good.

The ambiance is lovely, perfect for a date. The owners are charming people props to them for the quality of their restaurant.

I only wish the portions were a little bigger ;)

Best spanish restaurant in the bay, I dare to say.
author: Hannah M.

description: The tapas and location are right. The ambiance and furnishings could use a refresh.
author: Aubrey O.

description:
This is where M took me for our first date. Being half Spanish, he should know what he's doing. Yet, being a little ob-nob foodie, I still had lingering doubt about this man. 

Until I tried the dishes, of course. 

It was a beautiful experience. Warm, earthy, simple, and delicious. I felt like I was in some country side home in the Spanish hills. They took me to a different world. And poof, I'm a regular. 

We order the same dishes every time. Croquetas fried to perfection with the most amazing creamy jalapeno sauce. Juicy, meaty empanadillas de carne. Tortilla a la Espanola was fluffy and filling. The stuffed peppers was much better than anywhere else I've tried. 

Love love love this place. It is intimate, warm, with food how your never-had Spanish mama would make. 

And I will forever be the Duchess of this place. That's right!
author: Fiona S.

description: Dim Sum for lunch and tapas for dinner. That's a lot of small plates. Good selection of yummy hot and cold plates. We had a salad, a rabbit dish, empanadas, spinach, and they were all very good. Very intimate setting with efficient service. A great find.
author: Mike M.

description:
Alegrias offers great food and also a warm and cozy atmosphere.

We were sitting at the table near the street window. I enjoyed that table since it felt a bit more private than in the rest of the restaurant. 

We tried several of the tapas plates, from meat to seafood. They were all excelent. For drinks, we tried different red wines that were not so great.

It is also pricey, like always with tapas restaurants.
author: Brian C.

description:
We came here as a large group for my friend's birthday.  Parking can be tricky, but if you're patient (stubborn) enough, you could end up with a spot right in front like I did :)  The space is intimate but not crowded, dimly lit, and it's kind of rusticly charming.

There's a group menu for 10 or more, or you can get creative with the various small plates, instead.  We opted for the group menu and a couple of pitchers of sangria.

Unfortunately, the sangria wasn't as strong as I'd hoped.  We started with bread, olive oil/balsamic, and aceitunas (olives).

The first course was a salad with candied pecans - pretty standard.  Then came out all the tapas...

1. tortilla espanola - warm, but needed some extra salt and pepper if you don't like the aioli
2. chorizo espanola - sliced thin, flavorful, perfect for eating with your hands
3. escalivada (grilled eggplant, peppers & onions with a sherry/vinegar reduction) - slightly oily, but the balsamic reduction was amazingly sweet and concentrated
3. setas al ajillo - sauteed mushrooms, kept warm in a little casserole dish
4. gambas al ajillo - sauteed shrimp that were super sweet and not overcooked
5. espinacas a la catalana - spinach with an added sweetness from raisins and apples
6. patatas aioli - too bad I'm not an aioli fan
7. chorizo with apples - so much flavor!

You close with the paella, which is filled with calamari, chorizo, mussels, clams, and chicken.  With a squeeze of lemon, some extra salt and pepper, it tastes extra satisfying when you're craving carbs at the end of the meal (especially after a ton of sangria).  I wish it had a crust on the bottom, though.

They were nice enough to let us bring in our own cupcakes for the birthday girl without extra charges.  Service-wise, they were really good about clearing extra plates from our table.  The food wasn't overly greasy, and the selection of menu items are very traditional but were done pretty well.  

For all the food, sangria, tax/tip, it ended up being $54/person, which I thought was super reasonable.  This was also probably the first time I walked out from a tapas placed stuffed!
author: Marilyn T.

description: Very friendly servers. The free bread was disappointing. The small plates were good. We ordered the sea food paella which was decent. All in all, a decent place to dine with easy reservations but nothing particularly stood out as outstanding.
author: Rubail B.

description: Ok, but didn't have that wow factor. I'd recommend the rabbit stew though ...
author: Shirin E.

description: Loved Alegrias! High quality food and good wine. The environment is really beautiful and they pay attention to the details. I felt Europe flavors in SF!
author: Alessio D.

description:
Tapas were very delicious. Will definitely come back for these.

I'm afraid I've had better Paella.
author: Felix B.

description: I've been to Alegria's four times already and I just LOVE their tapas!!! I also love their sangria!  I've been to another place in the Mission and Alegria's is far superior as to quality and flavors!  I think they have the BEST bread pudding ever!!! I've ordered it every time and it's been delicious!!!!!  I'm planning to go two more times to take my two friends out for their birthdays and I can't wait to go back!!!!!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
My husband and I love this place. It's a tiny, slightly hole in the wall-ish type Spanish tapas place, but the food is fantastic and the service is decent. We have liked everything we've tried off the menu, but our favorites are the goat cheese, the potatoes, and the spanish tortilla. 

I think, however, what I really like about this place is this one dessert - the dulce de leche crepe. With oozing caramel wrapped in paper thin pancakes and burnt, crunchy sugar on top, I think it might just be my favorite dessert in the city. 

FYI, we have also brought our 18 month old son here on multiple occasions and it has never been an issue.
author: Beth D.

description:
Ok we went to this place since it got so many reviews. I thought the food just tasted OK for the price. But the SERVICE WAS GREAT! We didn't like the Callos and they let us return that for the sausage. So the 3 start I'm giving is for the food and not for the service.

We got :
Vegtable paella: 3
chorizo with apples: 4 
Empanadillas de Carne: 4 
Callos a la Madrileña: 1 ( I just don't like Tripe!)
Pitcher of Sangria: 4
But I saw it got so many good reviews for Paella and i thought the Paella was just ok. I think the Vegtable Paella in Cascal, Mountain View is much better! 
But I have to say the service was excellent.
author: Mina D.

description: Delicious food! It reminded me of my trip to Spain. The chef was so nice and came out and talked to us about food, Spain, travel and so much more! I am certainly going back again.
author: Katherine M.

description: Great place! Came for dinner on a Friday night with no reservations and was lucky enough to score one of the few remaining tables. The restaurant certainly feels authentic- the decorative tiles make you feel like you're in a quaint tapas bar in Spain. Split a very affordable and very tasty bottle of Rioja, and enjoyed about a half dozen or so different tapas. Sad that they were out of jamon, but the delicious mushrooms, croquettes made up for it.
author: Meg D.

description: Tried this place last night for the first time and really enjoyed it. The service was great and the sangria was good (not too sweet). My boyfriend and I shared 3 tapas and a paella, perfect amount of food for the two of us. Paella had the nice crusty/burned rice on the bottom of the pan. The croquetas were delicious as well! We will definitely go back again.
author: Meghan B.

description:
GREAT SERVICE!
 
but i wasnt impressed by the food. it was fine, and i might go back again.. but not until i try some other spanish spots in SF. I have to say so far this place is above avg compared to other spanish resto's but its not GREAT. 
and really quiet. If you wan a quiet getaway definitely give this place a try. I personally like more 'happening' places.
author: Shadi N.

description:
I've driven by this place a million times on my way home but had no idea what a gem it was!
I was invited here for dinner with Tanya T, her BF and her dad and was pleased with my experience. 
We tried several small plates..among my favorites were the octopus and the pork loin. The service was impeccable...friendly and attentive.
I look forward to going back and would recommend the place to anyone seeking Spanish food.
author: Mimi T.

description:
If this is authentic Spanish Cuisine, then, I am disappointed about what the Spanish or Basque culture has to offer to cuisine.  Quite sad given that my own ethnicity is part Spanish and part Basque.

Before I slam this restaurant regrettably for being pretty lousy, I will preface by saying the service was superb and the staff was very friendly.  But I do not spend $90+ for two for nice and friendly people.  Hey if you want smiles and friendly and hospitable service, you'll get a bargain at this place; a bargain if you don't really care about what you're eating.

For appetizers, my good friend and I had crab cakes which were not bad (hmm, I had no idea that crabcakes were Spanish/Basque cuisine.....)  The accompanying tartar-ish sauce not bad but a little too McDonald's "Special Sauce" to my pallette.

But, for the main dish, I had the combination paella valencia something or another and it was horrible.  I love Paella and "Vigo's Authentic Valenciana", a cook on your own packaged Paella that you can buy at Safeway for less than $5 and takes 25 minutes to cook tastes significantly better.

Here, you pay $20 for this paella dish that is smothered with subpar prawns, fish (it had that "cold frozen refrigerated water" aftertaste to it), and far too many mussels and clams.  Because shells from clams and mussels are quite dirty and exude a polluted ocean water taste, the entire paella was completely ruined.  Oh, "but maybe they were farmed clams and mussels" you ask.  Sure, let's say they were farmed.  If they were farmed, they must've been farmed out of a sewage plant or somethun because they were horrible.

I guess I am fed up and tired with chef's in the SF Bay Area polluting great dishes with way too many mussels and clams.  It ruins the dish.  Two mussel shells and a handful of clamshells would have been fine.  Instead, the chef at this restaurant opted to fill the paella pan with about 30 clams and mussels which ruined the already grease saturated rice.  The overly greased and buttered saturated rice: that was also what was disappointing about the dish.

I've had paella in europe.  Even the paella I tried in a non-spanish speaking city (Some outdoor market in, HELSINKI,  by the Fishmarket near Esplanade) tasted way better than this crap.

My good friend and I had to walk 2 miles along Chestnut, Fillmore and Union Street to sweat out the toxins from the polluted shrimp tail shells, mussel shells, and clam shells.  The Chai Tea Late, from the empty starbucks we went to on Chestnut, barely sufficed in clearing my pallette of that horrid paellaean ordeal.

This is a word of wisdom to all San Franciscan Chefs:

Mussels taste horrible when served in excess.  Just two.  No more.  Have I made my point clear?

Sadly disappointed.  I doubt that I'll come here again.

That being said, the atmosphere isn't as horrible as the food.  Not sensational either.  I felt as if everyone eating there were eavesdroppers.  I find eavesdroppers to be unsettling like how I find too many mussels in my paella unsettling.

I am starting to skeptically think that there are no good establishments to eat at in San Francisco.  I hope that changes the next time I venture to the city.

Finally: the Malbec wine:  the first glass was short -filled and I was charged $9.75 for a 1/4 of a glass of Argentinian wine?  When it wasn't top quality Malbec? 

Just too many disappointments.  I'm gonna be more judgemental and harsher in my scoring of this place just because there are too many establishments around there for the experience to be even the slightest bit disappointed.
author: Tony U.

description:
Sangria was watered down and paella was not as flavorful I as I expected.  The rest was good: yummy calamari and very tasty potatoes :)
I would not go out of my way to go there, but if I happen to be around there I will go there again.
author: Unnona M.

description: Great place! Excellent food and the owners are lovely. The empanadas are awesome... What else an Argentinian could ask for?!?
author: Jimena P.

description:
I came here 3/26 for my birthday celebration, sadly after 2 pitchers of Sangria just for me, was still not buzzed and the people who were making comments that it's an asian party did not help.

Food: Was ok, my friend raved about the food so I decided to get a reservation here.  Maybe I'm used to food that has richer flavors, it seemed to be lacking a bit of flavor, especially the paella.

Service:  Service was awesome, they were really attentive and courteous.   Good thing they were totally ok with me bringing in my own birthday cakes.  

Parking: There's plenty of parking lots in the area, I parked across the street for $10, so that was reasonable, especially since that area gets really busy at night.
author: Omar L.

description:
Nice place...  Quite...  Good food and wine.  I use to go to Spain a few times a year and I just haven't found a place in the US that reminds me of those days.

I would go back if I were in the neighborhood.
author: Brian W.

description: A nice little restaurant. We had rabbit (Conejo A La Cazuela), frog leg (not sure which one it is on the menu, it was the special of the day according to the waiter), goat cheese in red sauce (Cazuela De Queso De Cabra) , and Paella A La Valenciana (with chicken and seafood). They are all amazing!!! Great service as well!!
author: Rain W.

description:
Party of 7 for an engagement/birthday party dinner.  This was such a fun place to go for a celebration since we had our own table in back AND although it was very busy we felt that it was really private,too. This means we could actually hear each other. 
The food was delicious.  My friend the mussel lover said that the mussels there were the best she's had in the city and prior to this she was a huge Isa fan.  Other noteworthy dishes include the flaming manchego, seafood paella, croquettes, tripe and prawns.  
I highly recommend this place for groups sized 4-8.
author: Sarah C.

description: Overall experience was great! Promptly seated (with reservation), waiters were so friendly and food was incredible. Best paella I've tried by far. I also recommend the crab cakes, ahh to die for!!
author: Yelenna P.

description:
Good Food
Nice Place
Great Friends

Just wish the Paella was bigger.....kind of small compared to other Paella I had.
author: Jess Y.

description: First time here...didn't know what to expect since it was my 2nd time to a spanish tapas place.  Everything was good, nothing to praise highly of though.  Dishes were all decent but the desserts were tooooo sweet.  We ordered the Chocolate Mousse and Apple Crepe.  I couldn't eat another bite because it was saturated with sweetness.  So overall, they get 4 stars!
author: Wendy T.

description:
More like 2.5 actually. 
I'm italian born and raised and spent many summers in Barcelona, Valencia and Costa Brava, so I had plenty of awesome paellas. 
I went to Alegrias on a Saturday, with reservation for 4. We were promptly seated and attended to. 
We ordered some tapas...very good!
We had empanadillas con carne, croquetas del dia and the grilled asparagus with Manchego cheese. 
But we had come for paella!!!
Luckly, the waiter had told us that one plate was going to be enough for two!! So we ordered one paella marinera and one paella valenciana. 
The rice was overcooked, dry and burnt at the corner of the pan... Tasted like it had been cooked well in advance than put in an oven way too long. The fish was allright, but the there was too much compared to the amount of rice and it too was very dry! 
Both paellas tasted the same, so most likely the rice had been cooked way before being served!
I did not have the sangria...I am pregnant and don't drink alcohol right now, but my parents that were with me said that it was ok...
Long story short... Good tapas, very bad paella. 
Will not return.
author: Tiziana R.

description:
3.5 stars

The tapas was good, but not amazing.  We enjoyed the Spanish ham, clams and snails, and sea bass special.  The paella, calamari and sangria were just "ok."

The atmosphere is old school and casual, service was fine.  I really just picked this place, because we felt like tapas and it's conveniently located in the Marina to hang out afterwards.
author: Cindy F.

description:
Disappointed.  Maybe we had too high of an expectation...having serious cravings for tapas, I left feeling unfulfilled - pity.

The storefront does not stand out but the yellow awning helps.  There are two different dining area - the front has some dim lighting while the back room only has the decorative string lights but surprisingly bright enough.  

We had our choice of tables and we picked one in the back dining room.  Once sat, we were left alone with the menu for the longest time without water, bread or a waiter.  When our waiter finally surfaced, he only asked if we were ready to order.  No "welcome", no "how are you", no "do you have any questions", no "tonight's special" since there are couple of items like the croquettes that are supposed to be different nightly.  

What we ordered:
glass of sangria for hubby - $5 - glad I didn't ordered.  Too sweet for my taste and not very flavorful

tripe - $8.95 - the tripe was very tender and we would have enjoyed it if there weren't so much chorizo and meat (chicken?) in there.  why do they have to add these items into the tripe?  

snails and clams in spicy red sauce - $9.95 - piping hot, this was tasty.  the snails were super tender.  

paella marinera - $19.95 - happy they serve paella for one but note there is a 30 minute wait.  It looks great with mussels lining the rim of the pan.  there were plenty pieces of fish, a little calamari, some bell pepper and some shrimp with peas - unfortunately, this was completely tasteless.  

lamb chops - $20.95 - there were four chops with some nicely browned potato, couple asparagus, some french beans and bell pepper.  the lamb was ok, good flavor but not as tender as we've had at other places.  a little on the greasy side.

I was too disappointed to even consider dessert, not to mention there really was no service throughout the evening.  

Next time we have a craving for tapas, we are going back to some of our favorite places.

Pass.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I tried this restaurant a couple of weeks ago.  The food is good and reasonable and the service is excellent.  It's a fairly big place with another room in the back for private parties.  We dined there on a Monday, so the place was not that busy.  It was intimate, quiet and a little romantic.

Located in the Marina district, it's difficult to find street parking but the good thing is there is a garage right across the street (convenient)!
author: Carmencita S.

description:
My parents' 36th anniversary was a very special occasion because quite frankly, withstanding 36 years of anything is just an accomplishment in itself , so we decided on a nice dinner out that didn't involve the suburbs or chains.  Their recent trip to Spain inspired an idea: TAPAS.  Between my Dad's diabetes and Mom's appetite that rivals that of Nicole Richie's, I thought it best to stay with small portions.  A search of TAPAS on the Talk boards and the general Search function yielded a wealth of recommendations.  Bocadillos didn't take reservations and I didn't think the elders would appreciate the raucous din that is Cha Cha Cha's.  So Alegria's it was.  And what a wise choice.  

Our waiter let me practice my substandard Spanish--I found myself saying "Mas despacio" or "slower please" and "Como se dice.." or "How do you say..." throughout our very stilted and time consuming conversation.  But it was fun and I thought he showed remarkable restraint--I'm sure he was silently saying, "Bitch.  Please.  Order already."

Our meal was authentically Spanish, as reported by my parents who had recently made a trip to Barcelona.  The sangria was good, though not the best I've had.  But the 10-year old madeira was amazing and worth its pricetag ($12 for a teensy glass, not more than the amount of a shotglass).  The dishes were classically tapas-sized small and our party of six had to order two servings of several of the dishes as recommended by our ever-patient waiter.  

My favorite was the empanadillas de carne which were crunchy meat-filled empanadas with lots of flavor and surprisingly light for being fried.  The calamari with aioli sauce was tender and perfectly cooked, as were the crab cakes.  The paella was moist and seasoned just right and with quality, fresh ingredients--chorizo, clams, shrimp and chicken.   I wasn't keen on the pinchos morunos--pork loin skewers--which were a bit on the dry end.  My desert, panqueques de dulce de leche--caramel filled crepes--too sweet and rich, I should've gotten it a la mode to cut the richness.  

All in all, a five-star experience for the memorable service, flavorful food and for my parents who, after 36 years, still manage to give each other 5 stars!
author: Joc V.

description:
My boyfriend was craving for a good paella, so I looked on yelp and came across this place. Overall, it was quite dead and very quiet but it could possibly be a nice place for a date.

We ordered the sangria, which I loved... Mmm just thinking about it makes my mouth water. We ordered the crab cakes which I thought was pretty good but the bf said it would have been better if they put more crab in it. We also ordered their potatoes... They were soooo good. I think I engulfed the whole plate by myself =) We also ordered the seafood paella, which came in a pretty huge portion. It was ok, nothing too special.

So overall, this place was ok... I would definitely go back for the potatoes and sangria =) This place is good for groups because it's tapa style and if you go in a group you can order a variety of things on the menu to try
author: Daisy W.

description: Really nice place with superb food. Great atmosphere. The seafood and chorizo paella was delicious, a perfect balance of seasons and spices.
author: Carly G.

description: I went to Alegrias with my girlfriends last Saturday night and we had an amazing time. Food was simply Delicious (papas al aioli is a MUST), wine was outstanding (delicated Argentine Malbec) atmosphere and service were fantastic, even the owner came to say hi and brought us some dishes. I highly recommend this place, great for a date. The got out-of-this-world dessert are on the unavoidable list too! You will not regret it.
author: Aly I.

description:
3 friends and I went here on a Friday night for a girls night out- we spent 3 1/2 hours at the restaurant ordering food one plate at a time and didn't get any nasty looks from servers who perhaps wanted us to free up the table.  The service was attentive and helpful without being overbearing and the restaurant had an excited level of noise, but was still fairly relaxed. 

Patatas alioli, bocadillos de cangrejo, empanadillas de carne, croquetas, gambas al ajillo, cazuela de queso de cabra--- all some of the most flavorful, unique, delicious food that I've ever eaten.  We finished the meal (and our pitcher of yummy sangria) with 3 deserts (my panqueque de manzanas came flaming!) that were a delicious blend of sweet and smooth.  

Overall, I can't rave about this place enough.  Come prepared to spend a little extra money but the food is all so good that if you are ready to treat yourself, you will not be disappointed!
author: Luthien N.

description:
Alegrias may represent the joy of tapas given the variety on its menu.  The paella was tasty with plenty of seafood, bits of chorizo and a remnant of saltiness.  Other highlights included the stuffed peppers with lamb and the marinated tripe stew was tender and flavorful.  Moreover, the steamed mussels, potatoes, chorizo assortment and sangria was solid.  

Service was good and the decor was quaint.  This place seems out of place in the Marina, but it's worth a visit to try its tapas.  Street parking may be a challenge, but it's doable.
author: Jenny L.

description: Didn't try much here but would say if you are a veggie, should give this place a try! It's amazingly delicious.
author: Hrishikesh R.

description:
I went here a few weeks ago with a group of friends. I was a little dubious at the outset -- the restaurant is on Lombard (tourist trap), the decor is a bit stuffy and outdated, and, there was hardly anyone in the restaurant!

Fortunately the food spoke for itself. I got two tapas.

1) Bocadillos de Cangrejo - ie crab cakes in a creamy jalapeno sauce. This was nothing too special but the sauce had a nice kick

2) Espinacas a la Catalana - ie spinach sauteed with garlic, apples, raisins, and pine nuts -- WOW, this was amazing. The flavors together were awesome, I've never had anything like this before and I keep meaning to re-create it in my own kitchen!

I probably won't go out of my way to go back, but the food was good, so if you're in the area and in the mood for tapas, give it a try.
author: Sydney L.

description:
We had a celebration yesterday with my entire family 10 of us!. Very nice decoration, food was OK, the sea food paella was missing some salt, the rest was  just ok nothing really GREAT ,sangria was good. 
Waiter was kind of in a bad mood, not really friendly, no drinks menu available and we had to wait for one, I asked for options for beers and seems like that was too much for him to tell me the options....bad bad bad ....there are some many tapas places in SF, I dont think I will come back.
author: Carlos E.

description:
We went in a large group for my aunt's birthday. The service was good and the ambience/decor of the restaurant is very nice. In all my experience at this place was very good and would definitely recommend this place to others.  I like to generally rate per item that we ordered which lets my reviews be more specific. This place had an interesting quality where even though some of the items ordered were average, the experience of the entire meal seemed to be way above average.

Sangria -- 3/5 mediocre
Jamon Iberico Pata Negra -- 5/5 very thin and delicous
Esparragos a la Parilla -- 4.5/5
Empanadillas de Carne -- 5/5 the meal was so tasty.
Empanadillas Vegetarianas -- 3/5 did not care much for the tomato base.
Croquetas del dia -- 4/5 ham and shrimp filling. 
Gambas al Ajillo -- 4/5 always a favorite.
Setas al Ajillo -- 5/5 this one had a rich sauce and was possibly the best dish of the eve.
Patatas Alioli -- 4/5 similar to garlic fries. very tasty
Conejo a la Cazuela -- 4/5 the meat was very tender.
Paella de Verduras -- 4/5 
Paella a la Valenciana -- 4/5 smooth taste of saffron and good seafood.
author: Sal P.

description:
Had a wonderful bday celebration here last Friday in a party of 11. The restaurant is located on Lombard St, so parking can be difficult, but we found a spot quickly. Upon entry, I was in love with the ambiance and decor. Candle-lit tables, wall hangings, and other details made it very romantic.

Since there were so many people at the table, we've decided to go with the prix-fixe menu. 2 pitchers of sangria, chorizos, mushroom, potato brava, spinach, prawns, paella, etc etc made me a very happy girl! Servers were always around filling our glasses with water or sangria, and didn't cringed when we split the bills so many ways. Price was reasonable too!

Our table obviously won the bday song competition, Brian V.!
author: Lois W.

description:
Alegrias is definitely one of the best tapas places that I've tried! For dinner we had the following items:

Chorizos Españoles (Assorted cured Spanish style sausages)- a nice sampling of different types of chorizos: I love cured meats so I was a fan. 

Empanadillas Vegetarianas (Vegetarian Spanish style turnovers stuffed with soy based vegi-meat, egg, green onions, olives, raisins, and herbs): This was one of my favorite dishes of the night. It tasted like there was meat inside even though it is vegetarian. Crispy outer shell, steaming hot sweet stuffing inside. mm

Mejillones Alegrias (Steamed mussels in a white Rioja wine, garlic, and parsley sauce) - similar to that of B44's, not particularly special. 

Setas al Ajillo (Mushrooms sauteed in garlic and white Rioja wine)- this dish was good, but nothing spectacular or particularly interesting. 

Callos a la Madrileña (Tripe in traditional Madrid style)- I've only had Chinese style tripe but I must say this dish was really tender and flavorful. Tripe was nice and juicy, not tough or rubbery. 

Patatas Bravas (Crisp fried potatoes with a spicy red sauce): not exactly spicy, but the potatoes were nicely browned and crispy. 

Pimientos del Piquillo Rellenos con Cordero (Spanish piquillo peppers stuffed with lamb): Another one of my favorites of the night! This was absolutely delicious, stuffed peppers at other places do not compare. 

Paella a la Valenciana con Chorizo Español (Classic saffron flavored Spanish rice with chicken and seafood and imported Spanish chorizo): very flavorful and was the right amount of juiciness (I really hate too dry or too wet paellas)...plenty of seafood heaped on top, bits of chorizo and chicken here and there. One of the better paella's I've had. 

Special for the day: crispy sauteed frog - Mmmmm, the frog legs were HUGE! First thing I thought was dang...those are some muscular frogs. The meat was super tender and juicy under the crispy skin. But poor froggies :(

Cute decor, Sangria was good but not quite as good as Cascal's. I'll be back next time I'm in the area!
author: Jeanne S.

description:
Talk about a charming little place. It reminded me of being in Spain all over again. Atmosphere, atmosphere is what struck me first. The wall decorations are fun to peruse and the lighting is delightfully subdued.

Let's now talk about the food. The squid ink paella was to die for. I only wish the platter was a little larger. My other favorite was the snail/clam tapa. The sauce was exceptional and fun to soak up with the bread. Rabbit tapa tasted stewy and the tomato sauce base was well seasoned.
Loved the calamari tapa. Wild boar jamon tapa was ok. 

All in all, an interest dining experience that was an adventure.
author: Frank F.

description:
We've been here several times before, but tonight was definitely a five-star experience. We came in and it looked very crowded, but they were able to seat us within 10 minutes, during which time, we met the son of the owner at the bar and he recommended a great spanish white wine. Our waiter was very nice and gave us perfect service. 

We ordered 2 appetizers, a crab cake dish and the piquillo peppers stuffed with lamb. Both are excellent! Our main though dish was the best! It was a Chilean Sea bass cooked with wine sauce and there were also clams and asparagus. It was so tender and buttery! Yum
Our dessert was also delicious. Panqueque Mansana, which means Apple crepes. It came smothered in a rich rum sauce with vanilla ice cream and it came a la  flambe style. 

The waiter and bus boy gave us great service and we were very happy. 

We have been here several times before, but it seems this time, we picked all the the right things. Other dinners here have been more of a four-star experience, but we really enjoyed it tonight. We'll definitely be back again.
author: Jade C.

description: This place was delicious.  Made a last minute res on Sunday on a whim and was not disappointed.  The place is pretty dated looking but in truth that was really the only flaw.  The service was lovely, attentive without being intrusive.  We split the paella ala valenciana and a few of the tapas and everything was delicious.  We look forward to coming back.
author: Lin C.

description:
Food: 4 stars
Service: 4 stars
Value: 4 stars

This was my first time eating here. As soon as I stepped in, I fell in love with its ambiance. I love the drawings and the decorative plates on the wall. Together with all the beautiful little decors make this place unique and homey. I also love the "romantic" lighting and the string lights they put on the wall. The place is perfectly lit, not too bright that it's losing the "mood", but not too dark that you can't see what you are eating. 

For tapas, we ordered Assorted marinated olive ($5.25), Snails and Manila clams ($9.95), Fried calamares ($9.95), and two specials of the day: Lamb ($9.95) and Sausage (forgot the $). Among these dishes, I love the lamb and snails the most! They were delicious! Unfortunately, the clams were overcooked and had sand in them... quite disappointed! But the sauce was really good as a dipping for the bread. The calamares was yummy too, but it was common and pricey for the portion. The sausage was not that good, tasted very similar to Chinese sausage but not as good. 

The House Sangria was excellent! It is THE DRINK when you come here. We ordered a paella with seafood ($19.95). The portion is a little smaller than I expected, but it tasted very well. The rice is perfectly cooked (unlike some places that make the rice too soft.).

My overall experience here was pleasant and satisfied. I highly recommend this place and will definitely eat here again.
author: F T.

description:
Awful! The only thing that was kinda okay about the place was the sangria. The food was lacking. Greasy, but lacking flavor (unless you count the salt). Potatoes brava was a mess. The potato texture was as if you left them under a heat lamp before adding the sauce and serve. Save your money and go to any of the other tapas places in the city. 

Awful! Save yourself the grief and avoid at all costs!
author: Rose T.

description: I'm very surprised that this place has an average of 4 stars on Yelp. Everything we ate was mediocre at best. The ambiance is kind of cute, I guess. Go elsewhere.
author: Amy F.

description:
I wouldn't say this place has the most amazing tapas food, but over all the food is decent. There are many places out in the city which offer better tapas than this.
Ambiance again is decent, service pretty good. The main entree portion wasn't really good size either. For $24, I would expect a  decent serving.
Usually I have noticed that the servers are very friendly in the city, but here the servers did not give the extra friendly pish. They did a good job but again I am used to servers being really warm in San Francisco. 
Over all pricing is on the higher end but guess that everywhere in SF. I would not go to this place again but only coz the food wasn't all that outstanding.
author: Rishi K.

description:
Came here last week with a TownHog coupon, and generally had a tasty experience.  The paella valenciana con chorizo was really, really tasty -- easily the best paella I've had in the City, though that's not saying much since we seem to have a dearth of decent paella.  We also tasted the pulpo a la gallega (octopus on potatoes), which was incredibly fresh and delicious.  Some of the most perfectly cooked octopus I've ever had.  The flambed manchego and the crab cakes were also tasty, but nothing incredibly special.

Slightly on the pricey side for tapas, with most dishes going for $7-$10 each.  The paella was also a pretty small portion for $20.  And since it's in the Marina, it's a little hard to get to unless you want to drive, in which case you have to go light on the sangria.  I enjoyed my meal a lot, but I won't be rushing back -- Esperpento in the Mission is cheaper, more accessible, and almost as good.
author: Matt Y.

description:
Cozy ambiance and great food, yet it isn't over-crowed, a good place to enjoy a fine candle dinner. The tapas are very delicate and tasty, a smart way to sample Spanish food.
Among our orders, Setas al Ajillo, Cazuela de Caracoles y Almejas and Tortilla a la Española are the best.
author: sherry g.

description:
Went this last weekend absolutely LOVED it! 

Great homey yet romantic ambiance... There were quite a few people in there and it still had a great vibe! 

First of all, Sangria was fantastic!! The best i've had in awhile! The Tapas we had were incredible! The Bocadillow De Cangrejo- Crab Cakes w/Creamy Jalapeno Sauce, Patatas Alioli, Tabla de Quesos y Chorizos Espanoles & Paella La Valencia con Chorizo Espanol were all fantastic! 

We tried two desserts that were very good as well...Flan, of course gotta have it and Panquque de Manzanas with Cafe con Leche....YUMMO! 

All in all the night was fantastic...great food, fanstatic beverages and service and everyone else we met in the restaurant was a pleasure to talk to. Great place to go!
author: Nicole C.

description: Hidden gem in marina. Have eaten here many times. Great food, great service and should be a go to for a nice quiet Spanish meal. They are always super friendly and attentive. Definitely a must try!
author: Max C.

description: Alegrias is a great place.  Their tapas plates are very large comparatively and the serving staff is nice.  The atmosphere is pleasant. I thought that the flavors of the food were pretty good but the bread does not come out hot and some of the dishes were bland.  The wine that we got was mediocre, and for a 40 dollar bottle, meh.  All in all i am happy that we went there but I think we will try another place next!
author: Bill S.

description:
I came here with a small group of pple for a friend's bday. I immediately noticed it had a very romantic atmosphere in that it was dimly lit with white christmas lights hanging all around the room and candles at each table (we sat in the back room). I really liked that. 

We ordered several dishes: Chorizos espanolas, gambas al ajillo, tortilla a la espanola, paella a la marinera, setas al ajillo, patatas alioli, and a dessert with flames (forget the name)

I liked:
1. patatas alioli = garlickey sauce on french fries
2. tortilla a la espanola
3. setas al ajillo
4. gambas al ajillo

I didn't like the paella...not very good even though I expected it to be better.

Overall, I wasn't impressed...I like cha cha cha's and andalu's better. But if I had a chance to go back in time, I would go here again. I go to restaurants for the experience too not just the food. The food wasn't amazing but it wasn't bad either.
author: Judy Y.

description:
I have been to Alegrias twice now and each time was better than the other! I loved the authentic Spanish food. It was the highlight of the dinner, but I don't want to forget and thank the staff for their wonderful hospitality at the restaurant. The decorations were incredibly beautiful, as I couldn't stop staring and making out the detail of each beautiful plate and antique key that was hung on every wall. I think this is my new favorite restaurant. Great for an intimate dinner or for a small group of people.
Oh, and I forgot to mention how incredibly and uniquely delicious was their Crema Catalana, which is a Spanish Creme brulee. It had a slight hint of lemon in it and the taste was to die for! Their chocolate mousse was also incredibly scrumptious!
author: Oksana P.

description:
disappointed, mediocre food, and spotty service. disclaimer: i'm comparing my experience to Joya in Palo Alto (i luv that place!)

i was a little late for our 6:45 reservation for 3 this past saturday, but it didn't matter because there were plenty of tables open. the setting was romantic, with the lights dimmed and great cultural decorations on the walls. yet it was still casual for us to not feel uncomfortable, as it was loud with conversations. 

we were seated in the back, and it took awhile for our waiter to greet us. we didn't mind since we were still looking at the menu. the menu itself was quite small, only 1 pg. we started out with a pitcher of sangria; they only had red, and there were only oranges. I'm used to having several kinds of fruits.. apples, peaches, etc. 

the bread came out quite late as well, and it was hard and cold. for tapas, we had the chorizos, mussels in white wine sauce, and the fried potatoes with alioli sauce. honestly, none of it stood out and was very plain and boring. maybe we didn't order the right stuff, but i figured everything on the menu should be great.

right before our paella came out, a waitstaff came to clear our plates. my bf had used both his bread and main dish plate so he was going to come out with a new one. he never came back. luckily we had an extra bread plate, so he just used that. we ordered the chicken and seafood paella, it was also very boring. it lacked taste and spice, and wasn't as much as Joya would have given. i actually saw a lady at another table put tapatio sauce in hers.

the only other time we saw our main waiter was to get the check, otherwise it was 2 other waitstaffs attending to us. even then, we had to ask for water 2x. i honestly expected more from this place. for the 3 of us, it was about $80+ including tax and tip. i won't be coming back
author: Nancy F.

description:
Such cute decor! It's the first thing you'll notice. Picture frames, ceramic plates and mirrors cover the walls and make for quite the charming ambiance. Food and service were both great as well. For our party of 4 we ordered:

- Sangria - good but a little sweet for my taste
- Peppers stuffed with lamb - the lamb and the sauce were delicious, but I wish they had used fresh peppers instead of canned/pickled ones.
- Sauteed mushrooms - simple but tasty
- Empanadillas vegetarianas - SO good and crispy! The filling was perfect and flavorful.
- Manchego flambeado - this flaming cheese was delicious and perfect with the bread they provided.

Dessert:

- Chocolate mousse with raspberry - really rich and decadent
- Don't remember the name but it was some sort of flambed apple tart with ice cream - a little too much alcohol in this in my opinion. And yes, we really like our food on fire.

Such a lovely dining experience. Can't wait to come back and try all the seafood options.
author: Lisa W.

description: Hidden gem!   The best Spanish food in SF.
author: Seth T.

description:
What a gorgeous find.  

Ambience - The lighting is nice and soft without being too dim, and there's usually a good number of people without it feeling like a "crowd."  

Service - very helpful and attentive, but not clingy. When you go the first time, they offer to explain the tapas "system" (for lack of a better term), and if you say you've been there before, they back off. 

Food - heavens to Betsy.  Went there first with the fiance (who's a bit of a picky eater), then on a double date with him, his cousin, and the cousin's lady - and both times, it was FANTASTIC.  Of course you've got to get the paella at least the first time you go.  As far as tapas, get the patatas aioli, the albondigas, and the stewed rabbit!!  The empanadillas de carne are tantalizingly delicious as well, but I must emphasize the "tantalizing" - there are two in an order, and you may be left wanting more.  Flavors are somehow at once exotic and homey.  Oh....and of course, wash it all down with some Sangria and go home happy.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I went  to this restaurant 3 times and will go again!:-) 
Love the atmosphere, the decoration, the price and most importantly the food. The Tapas such as Empanadillas de Carne, Gambas al Ajillo, Manchego Flambeado and main dishes are very good. The place is nicely decorated, and somehow a little romantic. It  can get a little loud so it can great for large group as well.
author: Alexa G.

description: Patatas alioli were great. Definitely order that if you come to Alegrias!  Crispy and flavorful. Also loved the manchego-topped asparagus (gotta try that at home). Rabbit stew was good, not spectacular) but filling. Decent empanadas. Let down by the chorizo platter (very disappointed they were out of the Jamon Iberico).  I did enjoy the ambiance as though.
author: Delan B.

description:
Went last night with my husband and 2 Cuban friends to Alegrias, Lombard St., SF.
I am Dominican and my husband American and I wanted some good Spanish food. The restaurant was nicely decorated and busy all evening. Owners are Argentinian so it would have been nice to have Churrasco on the menu.
Service was very friendly, and although they forgot one of my tapas, they made it up by bringing us a free dessert.
We ordered sangria and white wine. The sangria was nice and light. Our friends ordered tortillas with chorizo which they found dry and not to their liking. 
Some of us ordered the meat empanadas, which were delicious. My husband ordered the olives and the garlic shrimp, and a plate of sausages similar to chorizo with some vegetables, all of which were very good.
My ham croquettes (croquetas with jamon iberico and shrimp)  were the forgotten item, but when they came, they were very good.
The bill came to $80 for 4 people, including the wine, which we found extremely reasonable.
