The free dessert was bread pudding, beautifully presented, and all agreed it was delicious.
We drove from Concord and we wouldn't take the long drive again.This is a restaurant that I would visit again if I were walking around in San Francisco. Next time, we'd try the paella, but last night the tapas made us too full.
author: Adria P.

description:
I came here with a large group for my brother's birthday party and they did a GREAT job. 
 We had a set menu that was delicious and came out in a timely manner.  The flavors were authentic and the portions were right on.
The service was really friendly and knowledgeable. 
The ambiance is authentic and inviting.  I am looking forward to coming back to try out the regular menu.
author: Lolita D.

description:
Service was excellent, staff was courteous and accommodating.
Everything we ordered was delicious. Nuff' said :)
author: Yelper I.

description: SO YUM! This is the best tapas place I have ever been to. The goat cheese, potatoes, and omelet were unbelievable. My boyfriend got the prawns and said they were the best he'd ever had. It makes me sad writing this review that I know I won't be able to return anytime soon. Only weird thing about this place is the decor/atmosphere, not my favorite.
author: Stacy S.

description: Very happy with our meal at Alegrias.  The potato omelet was perfect, probably the best dish I have had in recent memory.  Lots of vegetarian options.  We also had the Spanish cheese plate, mushrooms, mixed olives, goat cheese with red sauce.  Service was friendly and reasonably priced.  100% recommended.
author: Matt C.

description: Good tapas. Good wine (though avoid the cab by the glass). Good service. Highlights food wise were the empanadillas and the flambéed manchego.  Wine wise, I thought the red blend was the best of the reds by the glass. We had the chocolate mousse and their take on creme brûlée for dessert. Both were awesome. Drag yourself off of the vaunted Chestnut St. and give them a try!
author: J.D. W.

description: Everything about the meal was ok, but not great.  We ordered the salad, cheese platter and fried calamari - all fine, but nothing too memorable.  We also ordered tripe, but the dish seemed 1/2 tripe and 1/2 sausage except the sausage was tough and chewy (and yes, I eat tripe frequently so I would know).  We ordered 2 paellas and the arroz negro was clearly the winner - better seasoned and flavorful.  The paella a la valenciana, except for the rice, was rather bland and possibly overcooked. Even the sangria felt lacking.  However, the ambiance is nice and could great for a romantic dinner or a large, but intimate party.  Alegrias could be a good change of venue and cuisine from more routine fare in the city, but just have tempered expectations.
author: Tim L.

description:
Great atmosphere, though it can get a little loud if the place is crowded.

I enjoyed the selection of food and everything we ordered was tasty.

Also noteworthy: the service was very good.
author: Joseph S.

description:
It's been a while since we've been to a Spanish restaurant, so my friends and I decided to try Alegrias. We went there on a Saturday night and since we had a reservation, they seated us right away. We ordered several tapas from the menu and a couple of Paella dishes to share. The food was really good and I'm glad we sampled many dishes.  

Our favorites:
Patatas Alioli - must try
Arroz Negro - very different
Empanaditas de Carne - so crispy
Panqueque de Manzanas - the rum did it!

Honorable mention:
Mejillones alegrias
Manchego Flambeado

Did not care for:
Callos a la Madrillena

I'd say, definitely come here is you want some good authentic Spanish food. We've been looking for a place like this for a long time. Besides the great food, the friendly service and romantic ambiance makes this place our top choice.
author: Elena C.

description:
I'm in a hurry and can't afford to procrastinate this well deserved review any further. So here it goes:

This is one of the finest Tapas restaurants I've been to in town. 5 stars go for:

1) Impeccable service - timely and well organized.
2) Extremely tasty meals that come in right size portions.
3) Beautiful decor and ambiance.
4) Sangria - delicious!!
5) Last but not the least - They accommodated 16 of us very comfortably on a Saturday night within a few days' notice!! Each and every guest of ours was very pleased with this place.

I definitely recommend Alegrias for that special celebration! It was my wife's first b'day with me since we met and I'm glad I chose this place over others. Beautiful!
author: Rajiv R.

description:
Cute place, eccentric and charming interior, tasty tapas. Went with some friends and the following was more than enough to share among the 4 of us:

Bread - No herbs or vinegar for dip, but the olive oil had a unique grape taste that was pretty good.
House sangria (red wine + oranges) - A bit watered down for my taste, but complemented the meal well.
Empanadillas de Carne - Awesome.
Gambas al Ajillo - The shrimp was nothing special, but the sauce was great dip for the bread.
Patatas Alioli - Very good.
Paella a la Valenciana con Chorizo Español - Best part of the meal. This was fantastic!
author: Dianna H.

description:
I really like Spanish tapas and I'm glad I got to discover Alegrias with my bestest girlfriends. We came here for a girls' night out to help celebrate our gf's birthday. 

We ordered almost all of the tapas they had on the menu plus paella and two pitchers of sangria. I loved all of the tapas we had: patatas bravas, pulpo, and some other delicious good eats. The paella was very tasty. I wasn't too fond of the sangria (since I'm not a huge red wine drinker), but my gfs definitely enjoyed it.

I would love to come back here. It's located in the Marina next to cool places you can hit up after. 

Cheers!
author: Jackie D.

description:
This tapas restaurant has two main rooms. The first room feels a bit nicer and cozier, so if you go or make a reservation, I recommend you request a table there. 

The decoration is fun, with all sorts of Spanish plates on the wall, and a rustic feel. 

We were in two, and ordered 4 tapas dishes (but I wasn't THAT hungry). The dishes are typical tapas size, which is nice to try out all the different plates. 

My favorites were the Baked Goat cheese and flambé manchego, which were cheese heaven!  The empanadas de carne were also very well seasoned, and has some olives which contributed to a very nice taste. 

The Sangria was ok, but very weak. 
 Finally, the service was really good, with everyone being really attentive.
author: Michel A.

description:
I ate here last night with 3 of my girlfriends and we feasted on scrumptious tapas & seafood paella. We tried so many dishes! Plenty for vegetarians to choose from and the seafood tapas were a hit. One of the owners helped us pick a fruity Malbec and the service in general was attentive. 
The place is a little outdated but would be great for a romantic evening or a celebration - the place was full with birthdays and big groups as well.
I can't wait to go back for some more Paella - it was full of fish and not heavy on the rice.

Delicioso!
author: Emilia D.

description:
Dropped in after seeing the yelp reviews and was pleasantly surprised! All of the Tapas were as authentic as the atmosphere which made you feel like you were in Spain. The Shrimp, Tortilla, and Papas Allioli were fantastic!

The Sangria was a little sweet but not bad, I would definitely eat here again!

Great for a Date!
author: Dustin R.

description:
I came to Alegrias on Saturday night with a new gentleman caller.  He had heard about it on Check Please Bay Area, and it's walking distance from his home, so we decided to try it.

The dining room  reminds me a lot of the smaller restaurants I went to in Italy and Spain.  Lots of knick-knacks and big flowers on the chairs, which added to the feeling of authenticity

We had Sangria and an assortment of tapas, including a cheese platter with chorizo, flambeed goat cheese (set on fire at the table!,) gambas and meat filled empenadillas.  Everything was very tasty, although perhaps next time we would order less cheese.  The flambeed cheese really stole the show, although I'd definitely recommend scarfing it up immediately.  It wasn't as good when we were finishing it up 15 min later.  The sizzling gambas were definitely another highlight.

All in all it was a good meal (and a great date, but I give new manfriend most of the credit for that.)  I'd go back, particularly if there were a long wait at Zarzuela.
author: Bailey D.

description:
Pros: The food -- I have never been to a restaurant where I want to go home and try to make so many of the dishes served. The service -- the waiter was great. He was always on top of things, made sure we had everything we needed, and never pressured us to leave.

Cons: Parking isn't that easy to come by if you're not willing to pay a few bucks for the neighborhood parking lot. Prices are a little steep for the amount of food. One tapa will be about $8-10 and you will need at least four or five to feed 2 people unless you have a small appetite.

I would love to come back here if I were going out for a night with the girls or a birthday celebration. Not sure if I would come back just to come back though.
author: Ellen C.

description:
This place has the best Sangria in town!  Who says so? ~~ My gorgeous sexy husband and I.  We absolutely love tapas and this one of the most authentic Spanish tapas place in town.  Alegrias brings back tapas and sangria filled memories of our vacation in Barcelona a couple years back. 

The last time we visited, I was having a very stressful day due to finals  at school and my projects at work.  Well - the mister and I decided to unwind by having a relaxing and delicious dinner at Alegrias.  It hit the spot!  We each had a glass of Sangria to start and several plates of tapas.  It was absolute heaven!  This is a nice place to bring a date or to celebrate a birthday.  My husband and I will definitely be back.
author: Christine P.

description:
We came here to catch up with close friends. Alegrias is pretty decent as a Tapas restaurant. We tried various hot and cold plates throughout the night and this is what I found.

1. Tabla de Quesos y Chorizos Españoles - Assortment of cheese and cured sausage imported from Spain

Really liked the cheese selection. The Chorizos could be better.

2. Empanadillas de Carne - Spanish style turnovers stuffed with beef, green onions, olives, raisins, and herbs

Quite good and flavorful.

3. Tortilla de Chorizo - Classic Spanish potato, caramelized onion, and Spanish chorizo omelette

A good space-filler item with their Alioli (Allioli) sauce. Not bad!

4. Croquetas del dia - Croquettes of the day (Prawn)

Not bad! Once again, served with Alioli sauce.

5. Pulpo a la Gallega - Poached octopus with potatoes, Spanish extra virgin olive oil, and paprika

I was not sure what to make of the octopus. Flavorless! Skipped!

6. Patatas Bravas - Crisp fried potatoes with a spicy red sauce

Hmmm! Bravas is my comfort item as such, I like prefer my potatoes to be medium size cut, crispy with a generous amount of sauce. Alegrias needs to stick to a more traditional approach instead of favoring differentiation.

7. Conejo a la Cazuela - Stewed rabbit with vegetables and wine

Yummm! The highlight of the night. Fantastic taste and texture!!!

8. Paella a la Valenciana - Classic saffron flavored Spanish rice with chicken and seafood

Good! Even better as left-over the next day! ...=)

9. Sangria

Sangria...Sangria! Not bad but you will have it better at Fresca and La Lola.

Overall, Alegrias has good service and a relax ambiance with an assortment of solid Tapas dishes.

=)
author: DAVID N.

description:
Tried this place last night on a whim because I happened to be in the area. At first it looked completely dead and we almost changed our mind and walked to Chestnut Street for dinner. Our reservation was at 7 pm and there were only a few other people there. Don't be fooled! Within an hour, the place was packed and we started to miss the quiet moments when we first sat down. 

We liked every small plate that we ordered, but some of our favorites were the omelette and the manchego cheese flambe! We ordered the apple crepe for dessert, but it tasted like a shot of rum (maybe we should have let it burn longer), so they gladly swapped it for the bread pudding.

Our wine was just okay. They did not have much selection from California, so we picked a spanish red that the server recommended. It was just okay but not bad for $38. 

Bottom line is I might come back...it's not one of my favorites, but it is a nice cozy place when you are on a date or with a group.
author: Lauren H.

description:
This place is alright for Spanish food.

They have some interesting tapas, but most of them are hot instead of having more cold options.

The paella is just so average, that there is nothing that pops out and says "try me again".

The sangria is decent, it has a good amount of fruit flavor to it, but it is not a reason to go back.

I would say give this place a try if you need a Spanish fix.
author: Steve A.

description: This is a charming tapas restaurant that is worth a try. The food is delicious! The service was a bit off, but our waitress apologized and said it was atypical. Even with not so awesome service, the restaurant is great.
author: Olya S.

description:
We went here last summer because of the great Yelp reviews.  We came back because it was as great as people said it would be.  I would highly recommend that you get the Paella.  For $20, you get enough food for two people.  

The tapas range from $7-$10 and a (small) glass of sangria is $5.  Enjoy!
author: Ami N.

description:
I went to Alegrias for my friend's birthday dinner last Friday. I made reservations for 8 at 8 PM, but we were running late, so I called in and they said it was not a problem to hold the table for us. The place was nice.. perfect for a chill dinner. The dishes were very reasonably priced at about $10 for the tapas and $20 for the paellas. 

We ordered the Paella a la Valenciana con Chorizo Español, which had a little more sauce than other paellas that I've tried, but still good. We also had Bocadillos de Cangrejo (crab cakes), which were very tasty. Yum! We got the Mejillones Alegrias (mussels with white Rioja wine) that were pretty small... very disappointed with this dish. 

My friends had the calamari, frog legs (looked yummy), rabbit, and chorizo omelette. We also got a pitcher of sangria, but we would have preferred it to be a bit stronger (what can I say, we love our alcohol... haha).

We also got a complimentary dessert (flan) for my friend's birthday. It was a nice end to a lovely meal. =)
author: Cheryl C.

description:
A decent place that isn't mind-blowing, but at least affordable. 3.5 Star.

First of all, I didn't know why I had such a hard time finding this place. I was technically walking around for 10 minutes trying to look for this place. Hah!

Good: Chorizos Espanoles has a rich flavor with a touch of spiciness. Conejo a la Cazuela, rabbit stew, was well marinated in the wine sauce, and gaminess went totally unnoticed. Cazuela de Queso de Cabra was quite heavy, but definitely great with bread.

Somewhat in between: Jamon Serrano, Bocadillos de Cangrejo - loved the crab cake, but not so much for the sauce, Cazuela de Caracoles y Almejas - similar flavor as the Conejo a la Cazuela, Paella a la Valenciana con Chorizo Español, Pinchos Morunos - juicy enough, but not spectacular, and Patatas Bravas.

Not so good: Pulpo a la Gallega - fishy, and definitely not the best marination in my opinion.

If you haven't been to this place, I think it probably worths your try. Definitely not the best around here, but it's reasonably good enough.
author: Edmund L.

description: Delicious and reasonably priced tapas.  What makes this place 4 stars for me is the variety of tapas.  You can easily please everyone but It is hard to choose so be ready to eat!
author: Brooke H.

description:
This place does Tapas right, great variety of tasty plates in an informal-ish atmosphere at prices which aren't through the roof.

When we first got seated we were slightly unsure about the place, it was quiet empty and the decor and feel didn't stand out.  So I figured we might have picked the wrong place for the night; though once the meal was over I realized how wrong I was!  Great selection of tapas with all kinds of meat, I particularly enjoyed the frog legs and rabbit dishes.  The fact that the place was empty-ish allowed us to make even more noise.  Not sure why this place appears empty or dead at times, perhaps the restaurant has too much seating or we went on an off-night.
author: Prakhar S.

description:
Alegrias has a very warm feeling to it, just enough lighting to make the place a soothing experience.  Small plates always works out for me since I can try more without worrying about over eating. 

We started with bread, olive oil/balsamic, and aceitunas (olives). The bread was delicious and I had to remind myself to go easy on it, since it was going to be a long night of a ton of delicious food.

It was my first time trying Conejo a la Cazuela - Stewed rabbit with vegetables and wine. Hmmm!! It did have an after taste for me but I will remember the flavor. The fried Calamares was really good. I enjoyed the whole lighting off goat cheese. The night ended with Paella and my favorite was the one with Spanish Chorizo. I relished every bite of it. Check out there Wine list for sure, they did have a great selection which went well with the Paella.

Service was excellent and I certainly appreciate the time servers spent on describing food.

Please do not forget to get your own Flan. You simply cannot share it.
author: En J.

description: Good food and service.  A romatic atmosphere.  Great Sangrea, but no mixed drinks.
author: William N.

description: They have the best sangria ever! Great place for Spanish tapas. Good service as well. Food was all right... you need to be open to trying new things in order to truly enjoy it. The paella is delicious though!
author: Sonia S.

description: Delicious food, went for Valentine's Day so it was prix fixe menu. The service was very quick, but I think that is more due to the fact of the limited menu and having food prepared. The decor was a little cheesy and I think they could upgrade they're tableware and dishes. I would like to come back and try again to see how it compares to Valentine's Day.
author: Arianna W.

description:
An interesting little tapas place in the Marina. The first thing to strike me was the decor.  I felt like I had stepped into someone's little country home basement with dark lighting, old linoleum tile floor, metal chairs with old dark red and floral patterned covers - a little disconnect with the type of food and ambiance I usually associate with tapas.  That being said, the service and food were decent but not special enough for a return.   Sangria was unfortunately weak and watered down.  

With a party of 8, we got to try a fair portion of the menu.  Cold and hot tapas ranged from $7-10 each, with entrees and paellas around $20 each.  Individually each dish was pretty good, but a lot of the same flavors (as you can see, garlic and white rioja wine sauce was quite the constant ingredient).  

Be sure to order your paella early -- we had two orders of the Paella a la Valencia con Chorizo Espanol - delicious flavorful moist saffron rice with mussels, clams, chorizo, chicken.  My fav dish of the night.  For tapas, we shared (from tasty to not-so-tasty):
- Manchego Flambeado - set on fire tableside and just as delicious as it was entertaining
- Oven cooked goat cheese in a red tomato sauce - I love goat cheese, but this may not be for everyone
- Empanadillas de Carne - tasty standard with delicious beef filling
- Steamed mussels in white Rioja wine sauce - yum!  
- Mushrooms in garlic in white Rioja wine - yum!
- Prawns in whie Rioja sauce with garlic and parsley
- Tortilla a la Espanola - slightly dry potato and onion omelette
- Croquetas al dia - filled with a weird paste of supposed serrano ham & shrimp.

I'll continue trying different tapas joints before coming back here.
author: Heather s.

description: My daughter and I had dinner here before a concert and were in foodie heaven! Small plates (tapas) are so much fun to share we had the eggplant, crab cakes, cheese flambe (soooo good), and empanadillas. We couldn't resist having two desserts...the excellent rice pudding and another flaming dish...the panqueque a'la mode!! We'll be back!
author: Jan C.

description:
The sangria, VERY GOOD! lets just get that outta the way. I enjoyed it, not too sweet.
The setting of this restaurant is very intimate, with the lights dimmed low and a lot of small tables. Very good date place in my opinion.

quite honestly, i can't remember the names of the foods i ordered, but I can describe it pretty well or give the general idea of the name:

The Paella with chorizo, sooo delicious, full of flavor and not skimpy on the clams, mussels and shrimp. very very good!

Pulpo is very tender and not "fishy" at all. I personally love anything octopus, but some may say this is meh...but i enjoyed it. It is served over golden potato rounds.

I forget the name but it was basically a potato omelet   

The empanadillas with chorizo was the only dish I was really disappointed about. It tasted like a giant fried tostino pizza roll......It was probably the size of 6 rolls, so i guess thats alotta pizza roll. I can definitely do without this one. But everything else was very tasty.

though i didn't like one dish, overall experience and food was still good, excellent sangria and a great place for a date. they take reservations but the place doesnt get crowded. I went at 7pm on a friday night
author: Calvinn W.

description:
A solid all around Tapas restaurant that comes up just short for me.   That being said, it's a nice change of pace from the typical Marina restaurant. 

For starters, I really loved the cheese and sausage plate.  It's not the first thing that comes to mind when you think Spanish cuisine, but all the options were tasty and offered a unique flavor and spice level.   As others have mentioned, the sauteed spinach is a winner and I also loved the rabbit.   I don't remember the sangria being particularly good, but maybe it was an off night.  

Bill climbed close to $100, which seems like a lot for a couple having dinner.  I can see paying that much for a stunning romantic atmosphere, but you don't really get that here.  Anyhoo, worth checking out if you're in the neighborhood but wouldn't go out of my way.
author: John H.

description:
Met a large group for a Sunday evening dinner. I had no idea what I felt like so my date ordered all the dishes for us. We began with the escargot and clams in a garlic marinara sauce. The escargot was just the right amount of saltiness and chewiness. The rest of our meal was composed of stuffed peppers with lamb and drizzled with aioli, a potato and chorizo frittata, baked goat cheese in a tomato sauce, and copious amounts of bread. Oh, wait, I cannot forget to mention the dessert of caramelized apples over a crepe with vanilla ice cream. Awesome coffee too.

I was horrible company because I became so involved in my food that I barely spoke a word. I'll look at it as me having had an intimate conversation with the chef... ;)
author: Maureen S.

description: We were looking for a tapas place tonight for dinner and  Alegrias came up so we thought we'd give it a shot.  I had never heard or seen it before but we had a good time.  The service was very friendly and the food was good.  We ordered a ton of different tapas and my favorite was probably the garlic shrimp which were very tasty.  The wine selection was good as well.  The interior decoration wasn't exactly my style but it still worked.
author: Blake B.

description: Cesar is the owner and he and his wife are second to none. We didnt even have to order, his recommendations were spot on. Truly a hidden treasure in SF! Would go again and again
author: Vero M.

description:
We came here for a girls night out and had a great time. They serve very delicious pitchers of sangria and have a great variety of tapas. We had a vegetarian in our group and she didn't have any trouble finding something to eat. There was a great variety of items and everything tasted great. I really like their papas fritas.

The service was excellence and the price was very reasonable (even including drinks).
author: Alisa S.

description: Came in early, but got a table with no problem. My husband & I were very impressed. Staff let us know about specials. Order three tapas, lamb chops and arroz negra (paella). The food was just right. Lamb chops like butter! Paella was so flavorful! For dessert had the flambe perfect way to end the meal! I wanted to try everything on the menu... Defenitely coming back for more!
author: Maria D.

description:
Overall, this tapas place was pretty good, and worth trying. The service was friendly and $7-$10 per plate seemed reasonable. Street parking was tough, but there is a garage across the street- entrance on Moulton. 

Cazuela de Queso de Cabra (baked goat cheese): B+
The Croquetas del dia (shrimp and prosciutto): A- (loved the aioli)
The Sangria: B+
Gambas al Ajillo (garlic prawns): C (I like garlic, but it overpowered this dish)
author: Bryce M.

description:
So, last night I was tempted back to the world of eating land animals by a serrano ham and shrimp croquette (croquetas del dia). After 18 months of no meat, I gave in and they were AMAZING. In fact, most of what I had was very good. 

Sangria: A
Crabcakes: A+
Gambas Ajillo A-
Patatas Bravas B-
Empanadillas Vegetarianas A
Flan A++

A nice quiet tapas place - not your typical loud Mission haunt. In fact, if you take a date here you won't have to yell at them - imagine that!
author: Katherine B.

description: What a lovely spot for dinner! Sangria is fantastic, as are the potatoes, mushrooms in garlic, and paella. Everything that I've tried so far has been outstanding...and I'll be back.
author: laura f.

description:
This was a excellent choice for a tapas diner before heading off to the SF symphony for the Halloween B&W movie.  The food was amazing, one plate after another and the Paella a la Marinera was awesome.

Really surprised at the menu prices and with the good sized portions.  Some tapas restaurants in SF are a little crazy with their portion sizes (meaning small) with a big price tag.

Larry (our waiter) was very knowledgeable with wine selections, the menu items and  pairing.  We can't thank him enough especially since we were in a little bit of a rush that night to eat and get to the show.

Thanks Larry for all the great suggestions!  We'll be back for more for sure.
author: Christopher R.

description: This is a great place for a date. It's dim and romantic with decent Spanish food. The service was excellent but we were there early on a Saturday evening and were one of the only patrons there. Overall not wowed by the food but not disappointed. If I was going for romance I would pick this place. Otherwise I'd rather go to Zarzuela or Lalola.
author: Lauren N.

description: Good little neighborhood joint owned/operated by a nice Argentine family with not too much personality.
author: Anthony D.

description:
very authentic.  The chorizo and  tortilla española  took me back to my time in Spain.  

Sangria was also excellent.  After a few glasses, we were of course fluent in Spanish again.  To our surprise, the waiter also spoke spanish (w/ the spanish lisp and everything).

Oh I can't forget the sole reason we went there, the Paella.  With many variations, you won't leave disappointed.   

also, if you can't find parking there is a lot across the street that is only $2/hr.
author: Nolan R.

description:
What a great place.  We made a reservation and were seated promptly when I ate there this past weekend with a group of 6.  

The sangria was great, the tortilla espanola was delicious (we ordered seconds) and the vibe was friendly.

The paella, empanadas, patatas bravas and tortilla were all highlights.

Price was very reasonable for all we ate and drank.  Recommended!
author: Aaron T.

description:
we were walking from an event at the fort mason and yelped a nearby place to eat. this place had great reviews so we thought to give it a try. i wish i made my reservations on opentable but i forgot :( 

we came on a wednesday evening so the place was not packed at all but the service was still good. its a cute, romantic little restaurant that has two rooms, so can fit small and large groups. my friend and i ordered: 
- gambas al ajillo - prob my fave. the shrimp and the sauce was delish! great for bread dipping too
- manchego flambeado - just presentation itself was enough to have me order it cause its on fire! 
- empanadillas carne - this was just ok

the plates are small as most tapas places. i think its prob better if you come with a big group b/c you'll get to try more things. we weren't too hungry and probably ate too much bread. overall the food was great
author: Jen S.

description: Tapas and Paella are both excellent. Fast and helpful service, except I would avoid the mushrooms, which the house will recommend.
author: Matthew K.

description:
The customer service here is very very good.
The food is also good though I have had better, but this is still one of the best in SF area. Definintly try their Paella. Also ask for their cheese and wine selection.
author: Lance C.

description:
The atmosphere is classy and relaxing.  The food is great.  Full of flavor and each of the tapas are different.  Plenty of vegetarian options as well.  
Favorites: Tortilla a la espanola, manchego flambeado, patatas bravas.

Sangria was yummy as well.  Service was great.
author: Reena S.

description: I had the combination paella and the shrimp. Both were absolutely delicious. I think that the paella at Fresca is a bit more delicious but this restaurant has such a sweet/homey feel that I didn't really care.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Best tapas in SF, by far!!!  In fact, I love Spanish tapas so much that I used to travel to Spain whenever I could just to have some.  
Since I found Alegrias, I feel I don't have to!
author: Nancy K.

description:
3.5 Stars

Quiet little restaurant, casual but good service, a little tacky on the decor (flowery drapes covering the chairs) but yummy food. Some dishes were really good (Zarzuela de Mariscos), others were not as good as Bocadillos (tripe stew), and portions were good for the appetizers but too small for the main dishes. 

Sauteed Spinach- Lots of garlic, golden raisins, pine nuts, and sauteed apple chunks- sweet and savory--surprisingly good. Nice green addition to the mostly meat/fish and potato-based menu.

Tripe- Yummy but only if you really like tripe and it does have an intestine-ish smell so if you are skirmish about that stuff I wouldn't recommend this dish. I really like tripe and this was a pretty good version of a Spanish tripe stew--tomato based sauce, blood sausage pieces. But I would say that Bocadillos' tripe stew isbetter. 

Frog Leg's- batttered, seasoned, and fried until crispy and delicious! Perfectly cooked and well-seasoned.

Zarzuela de Mariscos- A delicious seafood stew with chunks of white fish, shrimp, and mussels-- great tomato-based broth with subtle white wine flavor. Very well flavored, lots of seafood flavor.  Only issue with this is that it's a main plate for 21.95  but it was pretty darn small.  

Altogether a casual and kind of charming place with pretty yummy tapas, though I wouldn't say the best I've ever had.
author: amy k.

description: We got there promptly at 5:30 on a Saturday night, for a birthday celebration.  They had just opened the door, and promptly seated our party of 5, then brought menus and water for all, and we began to order many tapas.  There was no delay in delivering the first of our choices.  Each choice of ours was nicely prepared, and fresh to boot.  Our waitperson (Laueano) delivered each dish with a nice pace, so our group could sample each one and then order another (or a repeat of one just finished).  One Yelper -- I read -- complained about the Sangria being "watery".  We had a pitcher, for us four adults, and it was fresh and flavorful.  It should not be a strong drink, but refreshing.  We all had desserts too, and mine was called "cream Catalan", kind of like a creme brulee, but infused with orange spices.  Wonderful.  We finished our meal with a very satisfied feeling.  I would have given 5 stars just for the food and the experience, but the seemingly high prices, for us, was a little steep plus the portions are a little small so we ordered 9 tapas in all, plus the four desserts.  We are from Sonoma county, and are not used to City pricing or cuisine.  Overall, they did a great job and it was a fun evening for us.
author: Marshall W.

description:
First of all I have to say that I have been going to this place for about 8 years now.  It has never disappointed.  The food is delicious and the staff is very very friendly.  The owners are very nice people who are always ready to please.  The food, is excellent and the prices are fair for the type of food you are getting.  Last time we went we had the Empanadillas, Hamon Serrano, the calamari, the Manchego Flambeado, and the Aceitunas for tapas.  Then we followed by Ordering Sarsuela de Mariscos, Paella a la Valenciana, and the Rib Eye.  Needless to say everything was delicious.  This is authentic Spanish food served with high attention to detail.  If you are thinking of going for dessert, then try the panqueque the dulce de leche.  Outstanding!

The place itself is also very inviting.  It is very welcoming and low key.  Nothing extravagant.  It focuses on a warm ambiance and an inviting environment. 

Great Place!
author: Ruben V.

description: Ambiance was dim & cozy which is how I like it.  Tasty Spanish food with sangria if you are feeling it tonight.
author: Branden B.

description:
If you love Sangria, make sure you go here. It's amazing! I ended up having 3 glasses...

I started with the Ensalada de la Casa which was really good. The Sherry Vinagrette was tasty. We also ordered a number of tapas to taste and really enjoyed all of them. We had the Tortilla a la Española, Gambas al Ajillo, Manchego Flambeado, and Patatas Alioli. I wouldn't recommend the Gambas al Ajillo because it was a bit bland. I'm sure there are more interesting tapas to try. However the Patatas Alioli was DELICIOUS! Best thing we ordered. 

For dessert we tasted the rice pudding which was good but nothing out of the ordinary. 

It wasn't that busy so getting a table was quick. The waiter was very attentive. I will definitely go back here. A cute little restaurant with character.
author: Jeanette L.

description:
ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS!

We had a party of 8 and had dinner here the night before we left the city.  Reservations were a cinch with Opentable.  Only drawback ... they only have one "L" in their name [and I am a very bad spaller]. 

We ordered about 12 - 15 Tapas.  Our favorites:  Rabbit, Serrano Ham, Little Fishes, Some kind of Cheese that was set on Fire, and Tripe!  All of the flavors were wonderfully done.  Not over salted like at some other places.  We also had the empanada's de carne; but it was a little sweet [which I think might be the proper way of doing it] for us.

We also ordered the Paella with the Spanish Chorizo's.  It was perfectly cooked.  We have been hesitant to eat Paella at Zarzuela's [we love Zarzuela's too, but their paella is not good]; but at Alegrias, I think the Paella was definitely a highlight.  The chicken in the Paella was tender and juicy ... somewhat shocking as Western cuisine typically uses white breast meat that tends to be too dry.

We ordered two pitchers of Sangria.  That was great too as it wasn't watered down by the ice.  I think that Alegria probably chills the wine before they mix it with the fruit juices and ice so that the ice does not excessively melt.  PROPER!

We ordered the crepe with caramel for dessert.  It was only so-so because the caramel was a bit sweet for us [but I think that's our fault for not being dessert people].  One of the people in my party really enjoyed the Flan; i think I probably should have gotten that.

Service was great, they did not harass you with excessive attention, but also did not ignore us.  Overall a near perfect night ... we were the only ones there by the end of that Sunday night.

I will definitely be coming back.  The only knock is that it is not as convenient to get to [for a tourist like myself] as say, Zarzuela.  But it is definitely worth the effort.
author: Hung P.

description: Great food and excellent service. My favorite was Arroz Negro and the Frog Legs, perfectly cooked. Super authentic tapas with a great Argentinian touch as the Empanadas de Carne are superb as well as the tri-tip brochette.  The desserts were terrific, Panqueque con Dulce de Leche, Budín de Pan y Arroz con Leche, all fabulous.
author: Axel M.

description:
Very good sangria, I am told by my fellow diners.  The food was unremarkable.  We tried the manchego, conejo (rabbit), pimientos rellenos con cordero (lamb stuffed peppers), gambas, and paella con todo.  The cheese was, having been flambeed, tough.  I think it's better just raw.  The rabbit was tasty but unrefined and not freshly prepared, which, I suppose, you can't expect from a stew.  The peppers were good.  I didn't try the shrimp.  The paella was generally good, though the shrimp looked dry.  The rice could have used more texture from my perspective.  I tried a mussel, and it was good.  The chorizo was excellent.

Service is very good, and they keep the bread coming, which is critical.  We got to try 5 different things between 4 people and ended up paying $20 for food and tip, which, I think, it a good deal, but I was really kind of hoping to be amazed with flavors, and I didn't get that here.
author: Joe H.

description: Just got back from Spain and amazing food there, esp the tapas. So, this was our first place to try to see if we can get something as good. Serve was very good, food came out hot and fresh. We had a party of 8 and were able to try many dishes. We would definitely go back when we're in the mood for tapas again!
author: Kim F.

description: I was really not impressed.  The food was very mediocre.  It was totally edible, but just not anything special.  The staff were nice enough, although we did have to wait an unbelievably long time to get the check after dessert.  With so many great restaurants just around the corner on Chestnut Street, I won't be going back any time soon.  Or ever.
author: Emily H.

description: I wanted to find a really good paella, and I was very pleased! This hole in the wall isn't very attractive from the outside, but is well worth it. We shared 3 tapas; crab cakes, garlic shrimp and garlic mushrooms. Probably could have done without the mushrooms, but the other two were wonderful. Sangria was also very good. We had one of the specials for dessert. It was a dark chocolate ice cream with an almond brittle on top. Delicious. Our waiter confessed that he makes it and that it is always the special on the nights he works.
author: Denise C.

description: The place is so cute! The decor is gorgeous!  We were a group about 6-7 and they got a table for us really quickly.  The paella is one of the best paella I have tasted.  Besides being a loud, drunk, obnoxious group they were very catering and understanding.  Everything I tasted was YUMS!
author: H H.

description: Cool spot for a quiet adult dinner. Had the house salad, crab cakes and paella with seafood, chicken and chorizo. Perfect for two. Sangria was great as well (had a pitcher). Total bill was $75 after tax and tip. Worth a repeat visit. The smells from the kitchen must mean there are other things on the menu that are just as tasty. And dessert sounded worthwhile had we skipped a serving of dinner.
author: Andria W.

description:
We had:
Ensalada de la casa - Very good
Croquettes del dia (Prawn and serrano ham) - Excellent
Gambas al ajillo - Ok nothing special.
Snails & Manilla Clams - Very good, sauce was perfect.
Paella a la marinera - Very good, fish was obviously very fresh, my only minor complaint was the clams had quite a bit of sand and grit.
Flan - My wife loved it.

The service was very prompt and the staff were friendly. Overall it is a great place for a date.
author: Nathan J.

description:
We came here on a week night, so there wasn't a lot of people.
Food was delicious! We had the empanadillas de carne which were great. The gambas aj ajillo were super tasty and the platter with Spanish sausages and cheeses was small but very tasty! My favorite was the croquete, just yam!
The service was perfect, not too pushy just there when you need it.
The price is definitely a huge plus, the tapas are all between 8 and 10 dollars.
I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Paula L.

description:
Bar None, the best service I've ever had a restaurant. I can't even remember better service.

The food was great, and the desert section was equally as good. I came here with a party of 5, and all of us with the exception of one, was pretty full. (One of us was allergic to seafood). If I could do it again, I'd go with just a date, and try other things. 

I'd have to definitely recommend the paella. That was especially delicious.
author: Clinton L.

description:
First impression: it's a place for dating with dim light, quiet atmosphere and nice decorations.

I ordered:
1 hot tapas: empanadillas de carne 
1 entree: the paella with seafood (I think no. 2)

I heart the tapas. It's like Indonesian snack that I like but with a Latin twist kind of. It reminds you of Mexican food caused this has beans in it. It's delicious too. Very buttery and crispy with a blend of at least five different ingredients that will melt in your mouth with one bite. Hm~~

I like the paella too (traditional Spanish dish usually rice with seafood) but since I think I had better one last time when I visited Spain, this was an okay food for me. Nonetheless, it's great for first-timers.

I love the service. The servers were very attentive although I think there were only two servers in the restaurant. They added bread whenever it was out (yah... I think they filled it up twice) without we even asked for it. Dipped the bread in the olive oil. Yum...

I think next time I'm just going to get three tapas instead of 1 tapas and 1 entree caused I like their tapas more.

This place also has a good variety of wine too and definitely a place for dating. I spent about $16/person without alcohol.

Atmosphere: 5***** (for dating), other occassions 4****
Service: 5*****!
Food: 4**** (tapas), 3*** (paella)
author: Cliff T.

description:
This is a quaint little place with good food and service.  I came here for dinner with a party of 7 and we had the paella, rabbit, and several tapas.  The rabbit entree was delicious, with the meat very tender.  Everyone also loved the garlic fries (forgot the actual name of the tapa).

My favorite part, however, was the sangria.  I am not a big drinker of wine, including sangria, but this was the best sangria I've ever tasted.  It was sweet and fruity and perfect!  We finished two pitchers and I wouldn't have said no to more.

Our servers were friendly too.  After dinner and dessert, we sat there talking for at least another half hour or more and they never once tried to rush us.  I would definitely go again!
author: Nilar H.

description:
When your friends can't make it to your birthday party, Alegrias is one of the places where they can bring you to make up for it. Yes, it's in the Marina, but surprisingly it is a hop-skip-jump away on MUNI, and parking isn't horrific on a Sunday evening. You can catch up over sangria and tapas, reminding them of how much you bawled your eyes out without their presence that one fine evening. 

Stepping into Alegrias, you feel as if you've walked into someone's grandmother's home [note: not mine!]. Very comfortable decor - small photos up along the walls, random doodads. Yummy Spanish food that reminds you of the trip you took to Spain a little while back. The food definitely does not equivocate the wonderful dishes we had in Spain, but it was a friendly and delicious reminder. We [three eating, one pretending to eat] ordered:

- Bocadillos de Cangrejo : Crispy crab cakes 
- Croquetas Del Dia : Crispy on the outside, ooey gooey on the inside
- Gambas al Ajillo : Prawns sauteed in garlic 
- Cazuela De Queso De Cabra : Goat cheese in red sauce 
- Paella a La Marinera : Seafood paella 

When I saw the menu, I wanted to order EVERYTHING. Will update this review when I try the Patatas Bravas and the Tortilla. Those were the staple food items that the sister and I consumed during our trip.

Reservations can be made, but when you show up an hour or two later than the time reserved, don't mention that! The atmosphere can be very romantic, so I highly recommend Alegrias for a night out with someone you're trying to take home.
author: Tinna H.

description:
I'm a true sucker for tapas. It may have something to do with the plates being small, which makes it all seem healthier. Or maybe it brings back memories of my trip to Spain, one of the most spectacular vacations ever. Either way, say tapas, and I'm in.
Alegrias was a lovely, pleasant surprise. 'Cos really, it's not much to look at from the outside. But once you open the door, it's like being in a friendly family home. Once the tapas start rolling out, you are ready to declare undying love. 
Oh, and most importantly, these guys give us vegetarians the respect we deserve with a real fair representation on the menu. Empanadas, spinach with raisins, tortilla espanola, even paella. And all tasty enough to lure even the meat eaters at the table. Citrusy Crema Catalana to finish. And a lively pitcher of sangria to tide us over through it all. Just wonderful.
author: Purnima M.

description:
The paella is fantastic good however the rabbit stew was not my favorite type since is submerge in tomato sauce. Their olive oil and jamon serrano are really authentic and made me feel I was eating in Madrid again. The gambas al ajillo were superb and their sangria is potent!!!!  
I will go back again definitely and hopefully they change the rabbit stew ;)
author: Karina W.

description:
My first time at a Spanish Tapas restaurant. It was awesome. Good food, wine, friends! Great times! I had some old college friends visiting town for the first time. We were able to find a table for 7 without any problems on a Saturday night. 

We got a Pitcher of yummy Sangria, and were also recommended a bottle of Pampano Inspiracion by the waiter, the white wine smelled like guavas, that was really good.

I don't even remember all the things we got, we ate a lot. I loved the fact that almost half of the tapas menu was vegetarian, bonus points in my book! I loved the patatas bravas, and the veggie empanadillas, and the flambe manchego, and the goat cheese in tomato sauce. The meat eaters in our group loved what they got as well. 

This would definitely be the top place to go to again when there is a large-ish group of friends and a fun occaision. The more people you got the more tapas you can try! :)
author: Kaushal P.

description:
I like this place, it's very cozy. Great dining place for bringing your significant other or catch up with dear friends.

Service was great, something about family owned restaurant I found comforting. 

I love their Sangrias, we ordered Paella a la Valenciana con Chorizo, Calamares and Patatas Bravas, very yummy. Averaged tab per person including tips about $35. Pretty good :)
author: jubi l.

description: This place is outstanding and I've eaten here many times. Larry, Josephine and Juan all do an outstanding job waiting on your table. I find they are friendly, personable, and attentive w/out overdoing it. The food is excellent, I've been to spain and found their entrees and tapas to be excellent and flavorful. I love the empanada's, the potato's, steak and the cheese app. Also, the wine list is excellent, there are so many great deals on spanish wines there. Last, I like to finish my meal w/ a glass of sherry and they must have one of the largest sherry collections in the U.S. Thank you and I will see you again! rew
author: Rew C.

description:
After a great time at the Pinot festival we came here for dinner.
The service was excellent and the food very good and authentic Spanish cuisine.

The hubby enjoyed a couple of bottles of Saison Dupont...which is one of his favorites.  He was happy to see it on the menu!

Between the three of us we ordered the following:
Bocadillos de cangrejo-awesome
Calamares fritos-very good & not greasy
Cazuela Caracoles-My Favorite ;-)
Pimientos piquillo-very good
Paella Marinera-very good & the rice was cooked perfectly
Quesos y chorizos-very good

We'll definitely return to this great restaurant!
author: Lizete S.

description: Great tapas! I went with a group of friends and we were definitely the youngest table in the restaurant, surprising given its location in the Marina. Anytime I'm craving Spanish food in SF, I'll come here. Standouts were the croquettas, setas, and paella.
author: Emma Y.

description: pretty good quality tapas and great service, but the menu was a bit more limited than i expected and its more of a family restaurant . the cheese flambé was great, but over all i still prefer zarazuela
author: Lisa H.

description:
For how romantic this place is - intimate decor, shared food and wonderful atmosphere - the times I've been here have hardly been dates.

I took my mom here once and discovered the excellent sangria and tried just about every little dish on the menu. It was really a wonderful evening. The second time I came with a good friend and we spent half the time on my phone playing pranks on someone via text message. In both cases the service was extremely friendly and helpful. You feel welcomed by a friend when you come to this restaurant.

The seafood paella is really quite good. It's so fresh that even my friend, who doesn't really eat seafood, loved it. I would also try the Tortilla a la Espanola (potato and onion wrap) and the Cazuela de Queso de Cabra (goat cheese and sauce). But really, it's hard to go wrong with much on this menu.

Really wonderful.
author: Ryan V.

description:
3.5 stars.

Tapas.
 
I love, love, LOVE Tapas!!!
 
On this night, late at night (10:40 pm or so), we headed to Alegria.  Though they were closing at 11 pm, they made everything but the paella available to us and sat us.
+1 immediately.
 
Then the food came pouring out.
Bread was a mediocre, but then they brought a "baked goat cheese" thing we had ordered, based on the waiter's recommendation.  If it weren't so damn hot - - I'd have jumped in and licked the plate clean.  It was AMAZING.  We also ordered gambas (large shrimp) which was fantastic - - and lightly floured calamari - -  very good.  They had something called "empanadilla" or something (spelling?) that was SOOOOOO good.  Cripsy fried on the outside, and a nice, tasty mix of beef, etc. on the inside.  HOT and flavor explosion!
 
Of the food that I didn't like - - - the anchovies we ordered was pretty basic, nothing special.  The grilled octopus was too chewy and lacked flavor.  
 
The sangria was cold and good - -  but not quite the best I've had.  Cha Cha Cha and Fresca have better Sangria than this.
 
The decor is a bit more formal than normal "tapas" places - - which was a nice change.
 
Service was excellent here from the owners down to the busboy, and our waiter was terrific.  Though we had come in so late - - we never felt rushed, and nobody's expression ever showed a moment of displeasure, which we so appreciated.
 
If someone asked me for tapas recommendations - - this place would be on my list, though not on top.  But the taste is quite authentically Spanish, perhaps more so than other joints that I'd recommend first  - - and that, with the good service, makes Alegria a nice spot at which to have dinner.  The food, however, is not tastier than other places, more authentic or not.
 
Good times!!!  Gracias!
author: Grace K.

description:
I wouldn't go out of my way for it, but I'd definitely come back if someone had a hankering for some well-priced, tasty tapas. I felt the dishes were hit or miss, but I'd chalk that up to personal preference rather than the failings of Alegrias. So 3.5 stars, really.

Great intimate space, good for couples or groups. Awkward, low-foot-traffic location near motels on a busy street. It's far more straight-up and honest about its food, its culture and its atmosphere. This was a nice, stark contrast from the trendier tiny-plate places. Bells and whistles usually make me think something's wrong with the food.

Oh, the food?

Empanadillas, Croquetas, Bocadillos de Cangrejo (crab cakes with NOM sauce) and sangria were all good.

Tortilla de Chorizo, Patatas Bravas and Pulpitos Fritos were alright. The pulpitos were saved from blandness by that sauce! What is in that sauce? Yum.

Panqueque de dulce de leche was a bit overcooked, as was the DdL itself. It being DdL, I hoovered it down anyway.
author: Tara R.

description: The kind of casual but elegant restaurant that's perfect to bring a date to. Cute, quaint, relaxed and fun but still warm and fuzzy ,maybe even romantic. The staff was attentive and everything we ordered was absolutely perfect. Sangria - yummers.
author: M C.

description:
I recently went here for the first time (on a friend's recommendation), and it definitely lived up to the hype...

We came for paella, so we only tried two of their tapas...the Gambas al Ajillo (prawns sauteed with garlic, parsley, and wine) and the Empanadillas de Carne (Spanish-style turnovers stuffed with beef, green onions, olives, raisins, and herbs)...both were quite good, and the prawns were especially tasty!

Now on to the paella...the Paella a la Valenciana (saffron-flavored Spanish rice with chicken and seafood) was fantastic! It reminded me of the paella I enjoyed when I went to Spain many moons ago, and it even tasted great the next day (those who know me know I'm not a huge leftover fan...but I definitely made an exception here).

The dessert we had (whose name I can't remember, but it was similar to a creme brulee) and their sangria were also good, but like several other reviewers, their sangria didn't really hit me at all...

The restaurant has a nice, cozy feel, and I'll definitely go back here for their paella! Sounds like some of their other tapas are also worth trying out...
author: Art D.

description:
listen to omid. he speaks the truth. based on its name alone, i associated alegrias with the allegro pieces i used to play on the piano. lively and cheerful. and alegrias was a little bit of both.

even on a tuesday, all the tables in the front room were taken. we sat at a more intimate table in the back. and the staff couldn't be more warm and welcoming. and pretty much everything on the menu looked like winners. we decided on a select few. the few i'd order again next time would be the beef empanadillas (with deceptively flaky shells), the croquetas (perfectly crispy on the outside and deliciously creamy on the inside), and the paella (you can't eat spanish without paella). and the pacing was just right. even though we ordered a bunch of items, i didn't end up feeling overly stuffed. would definitely come back.
author: spiff e.

description:
I recently went for dinner and I was not really impressed with this place. I have visited spain and also have done my fair share of tapas bars locally. This one was just alright. 
The portions were reallllllllly tiny. I know that is what people  usually expect with Tapas, but in spain they are not that small and my other favorite tapas bar, SABOR OF SPAIN in SAN RAFAEL is WAYYY better than this place! They have bigger plates and also the prices are far more fair.
I wouldnt go back here. Honestly there wasnt too much to choose from on their menu. Check out Sabor of Spain instead!
author: Alana C.

description:
Alegrias resembles someone's grandmother's house, with knick-knacks and small pictures all over. This persons grandmother has nephews that wear matching black shirts with aprons around their waist and walk around welcoming strangers and pouring water for them. 

They're good at deep frying here; both the croquettes and the crab cakes are done to the right crispness. They have a croquette of the day here, which is cool because anyone will give you a soup of the day, but I've never been to another place that will find something new to deep fry for you each day of the week. The crab cakes are sweet and tender underneath the deep fried goodness.

Imagine you started to make lasagna but forgot to buy noodles or meat or parmesan cheese and you ended up baking some ricotta cheese in pasta sauce; that's about what the baked goat cheese was like. Not at all goaty like I was expecting. The shrimp is not bad, but not a must have either.

The seafood paella is rich and moist and generous with the seafood. Get it unless you're allergic to seafood or you mainly just order paella for the rice. 

I didn't have a Spanish grandmother; I had a stern WASPy grandmother and a perfectly stereotypical Jewish grandmother. Alegrias makes for an acceptable substitute.
author: matthew r.

description:
***Alegrias serves good Spanish tapas in a cozy atmosphere that helps you to forget you're in the Marina.  While its food is representative of Spanish food, our experience did not merit ranking Alegrias among the best tapas restaurants in the city.  The price to value ratio is a bit high.  Zarzuela is a better bet.***
__________________________________________________

My wife and I went to Alegrias last night for dinner and sat in the table for two in the front of the restaurant.  The curtains over the window mostly hid the the lovely neon parking garage across Lombard.  Our ordering was a bit on the tame side as I'm avoiding meat in an effort to lose some of the  subcutaneous insulation I built up over the holidays.  
Our menu consisted of:

*Tortilla De Chorizo  $9.95
Classic Spanish potato, caramelized onion, and Spanish chorizo omelette.
-- Pretty standard, though at the bottom of the "standard" range.  Pretty clearly reheated prior to serving.  A bit dry?

*Calamares Fritos con Alioli $9.95
Fried calamari with aioli sauce.
--Great aioli.  We took the little ramekin of aioli off of the plate and made good use of it until the sauce was no more.  The calamari was good and crispy, not terribly oily.

*Patatas Bravas $6.95
Crisp potatoes with spicy red sauce.
--Unlike any patatas bravas I've ever had.  Totally lame cubes of potato (like the kind that is served with corned beef hash), fried, and served with what was basically a marinara sauce.  Lame; especially since we paid nearly $7 dollars for this mound of disappointment...

*Espinacas a la Catalana $7.50
Sauteed spinach with garlic, raisins, apple, and pine nuts.
-- This was one of the better dishes, though I felt the spinach was a bit over-cooked and the pine nuts would have benefited from a bit of toasting.  A good mix of flavors.

*Mejillones Alegrias $8.95
Steamed Mussels in a white wine, garlic, and parsley sauce.
--This was a highlight.  Though the mussels were a bit on the small side for the West Coast, the broth they were served in was very good.  If I weren't trying to restrict my caloric intake I would have savaged the bread plate and mopped up every last drop of liquid goodness in the bowl.  Then again, I'm like that when it comes to mussels.

*Pimientos Del Piqullo Rellenos  $9.95
Con Cordero Spanish piquillo peppers stuffed with lamb.
-- The texture on this dish was great, though sadly the lamb was chopped fine (like hamburger) and the flavor was way, way in the background.  Did they rinse the meat after cooking?  The sauce didn't add much to the dish, and had the consistency of melted Velveeta.  This dish fell far short of my expectations.

My wife had a glass of sangria which was perfect- sweet and with a nice kick, and I started with a glass of fino sherry followed by a nice big balloon glass full of Rioja.  Rioja is one of my favorite wines, and I loved this one.  I wish I could remember what it was, but I think it was the 2003 Bodegas y Viedos Pujanza Rioja.  For reviews see: http://www.cellartracker.com/wine.asp?iWine=275384 

Our service was good and well-paced, though we were asked if we were ready to order after having our menus for two minutes, and a few times I found myself searching for our waiter.  The atmosphere has Spanish accents and is homey, though as we sat in the far front we didn't get to see the rest of the place.  It looked like there was a back room which had more atmosphere.  If I had to do it again, I would sit farther back in the restaurant. 

As a silly aside, the people sitting at the table next to us, a couple in their late 40s had a series of increasingly ridiculous conversations that would have made Woody Allen proud.  They covered Tibetan antiques and their worth to thieves, culminating in a conversation about whether the phrase "Indian-giving" might be offensive and where it could have come from.  Our conversation was far more pedestrian by comparison.
author: Chad T.

description: Tapas were delicious. Ordered the patatas, mushroom, veggie empanadas and a few others. They were all pleasantly delicious. I'm a huge fan of tapas and have had the signature patatas. Alegrias is different and unique in that the potatoes are diced smaller. The atmosphere is romantic and would be a nice place to take a date. Service was super friendly and attentive. Both the host and waitress were very sweet. Only complaint would be the free bread - was a bit stale.
author: Monica S.

description: We got their Bocadillos de Cangrejo, Gambas al Ajillo, Espinacas a la Catalana, Tortilla de Chorizo and Paella. All were delicious. A very romantic restaurant - low lighting, great service. Their decorations is not my type - the chairs reminded me of grandma furniture. I prefer modern, stylish sorta design.
author: Catherine T.

description:
The pitchers of sangria flowed, and after that everything was sublime. Food tasted great, sparkling conversation, service was perfect. Our evening was made. On our waiter's suggestion we went for the prix fixe, with a few changes for the vegetarians and non-pork eaters in our group. Our waiter was extremely accommodating and not once did we have to crane our necks to look for him, he was always discreetly there!

Good value for $47 - included drinks food and gratuity.
author: M G.

description: This place was where I had my first tapas some decade ago and it remains as my favorite place to go to for tapas.  Living in Oakland, this place is a bit far for me to go to for tapas, but their tapas are very good.  They care deeply about their food, they are proud of the food they do put out, and the waiter was very attentive.  I even threw my sister a surprise dinner party there for her birthday.  It is a nice quiet restuarant in general and the food is good.
author: jae c.

description:
My wonderful experience at Alegrias last Friday night not only reminded me that I need to come to this gem more often, but also prompted me to write my first Yelp review!

In a town always brimming with the latest, greatest and coolest new restaurants, it was very refreshing to enjoy true old-school ambiance and the kind of welcome that only a family run restaurant can provide.

The focus here is on perfectly prepared, very authentic Spanish tapas.  We started with Escalivada, a perfect mix of grilled eggplant, peppers and onions with a sherry vinegar reduction.  The balance of flavors was just right. Oh, and we enjoyed a simple, yet very refreshing Rioja blanco which was a nice complement. Our waiter, Wilko from Mallorca was very friendly and his service was top-notch.  

Next up was a series of winners, from the nicely spicy and addictive  Patatas Bravas, to the Pinchos Morunos (pork skewers in some sort of awesome Moorish marinade), the ham and chicken Croquetas (which were perfectly crispy and non-oily, yet keeping the hot oozing wonder inside)....and finally, the stand-out dish, the Espinicas a la Catalana - a very creative take on sauteed spinach with garlic, raisins, apple and pine nuts providing a great sweet/savory mix.

Though not a dessert fan, we tried their bread pudding with a berry sauce which was definitely a highlight and will be a must order when I return. Oh, and I had a 5-year Madeira which matched really well.

We had brought our own wine as I had a special bottle of Spanish wine I wanted to drink and they were very gracious and immediately decanted it. We even had the chef Cesar (also the owner) come out and try the wine as I'd met him on past visits and he's a big wine lover.  More importantly, he spent at least 5 minutes chatting with us in the middle of a busy Sat. night.  Though I had not been there in well over one year, he immediately remembered me as 'the wine guy'.  

Ask to meet the Cesar, chef/owner on your next visit.  The food is superb, authentic and memorable....made even better that it is an unpretentious, casual atmosphere.

If you want some of the best Spanish food in all of the city, definitely check out Alegrias. And yes, it's a homey, slightly-dated feel, but that's also part of it's charm and I urge you to look beyond that and try the food and experience a real family restaurant.
author: Don D.

description: Good tapas place, which are hard to find these days!  Since Laiola shut down, there are not too many other options--I think this is the best one in the Marina area.  They don't get enough foot traffic because of the location, but it is actually really close and definitely worth venturing one block off Chestnut.  It is just one block, come on people!
author: Mike G.

description:
I had dinner with my boyfriend here since we have both been wanting to try this restaurant for a while. Here's my rating:

Food/Quality: 
We ordered the following items:
- House Salad - It was a basic mixed greens salad. The dressing was a bit too sweet so I'm glad I ordered it on the side and used a light drizzle of olive oil instead.
-Pimientos Piquillo - These were just ok. The quantity of lamb meat included was less than expected and the sauce didn't have any special flavors that I would expect.
-Cazuela De Queso - This was the best dish to me, but that's because I love goat cheese!
-Patatas Alioli - My boyfriend enjoyed this dish the best - the potatoes definitely had a lot of flavor.
-Paella Verduras - As the entree, it was sad that we both picked at it and left more behind on the plate than we ate. 

Service:
The service was friendly. Although near the end it took a while to find someone to clear the table and ask for a check.

Atmosphere: 
It is a small, cozy place - dishes and photographs cover the walls, floor length chair covers dress the chairs, and a small votive candle dances on each table.

Price:
As others mentioned, the price range is $35 or so per person not including drinks and tip.

Overall, I wasn't as impressed with this place as I thought I would. 
Tip: If you want good tapas in this neighborhood, try Isa's.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
In general most Tapas restaurant in SF are average at best, and Alegrias is in my opinion bottom of the ladder.

A better place would be Soif (but that is all the way in Santa Cruz). In SF, of the seven other places I have been to (Ramblas, Picaros, Esperpento, Illuna basque, and Bocadillos, cafe Arguello). Each have one or two unique dishes worth visiting for but in general it never matches up to the expectations once you have to tripped around spain/catalan.
author: An u.

description:
Okay, Okay, I know I shouldn't do this, but I've been dying to go here since I moved to San Francisco.  I walk by it all the time. I have been told by many friends that it's great.  It's been too long, Alegrias. Too long.

I am determined to come here ASAP and will update my review.
author: Lauren C.

description:
The best tapas in the city! A perfect place for a romantic date or special dinner with a small group of friends!

We just moved to DC - I'm going to miss going to Alegrias! This is definitely my favorite restaurant in SF!
author: Jessica O.

description:
I love Spanish food... and Spanish wine... and Spain. And now, I also love Alegrias.

Atmosphere is warm and I enjoyed the decorations on the walls (including the swords used by bullfighters...).  I recommend the croquetas del dia and the pimientos.  There is great variety on the tapas menu, and an extensive wine list. Enjoy!!
author: Flora B.

description:
Went here for a birthday party with a group of people.  We got their fixed-menu for a group, which was actually a pretty great value.  For $25 you can have a salad and an assortment of tapas, and for $30 (the one we got), which added the paella also.  

We started w/ some nice warm bread and olive oil, it was good and enough to load up on some carbs before the tapas.  The salad was mixed greens w/ a balsamic-type dressing and walnuts, pretty good.  We then got some olives, sauteed mushrooms, tortilla a la espanola (like a fritata), grilled eggplant, prawns, fried potatoes, pork skewers, sauteed spinach, and chorizos.  My favorites were the chorizos, torta, and the pork (especially with the cubed potatoes, they're kind of like little tiny square french fries).  I liked the mushrooms, but I prefer it when they sautee them whole as opposed to cut up like they did since it's juicier that way.  The paella was great, and it was just the thing to finish the meal off...without it, we might have been hungry since it was mostly veggie tapas, but after having the paella I felt full and satisfied.

The sangria isn't bad...would have preferred it to be a tad stronger/more alcoholic, especially w/ dinner.  We started w/ it then switched later to some wine which went a lot better.  I think I'd like to come back someday and have some of their richer, non-veggie tapas...especially the meat and cheese ones.  

This place is a much better value than the tapas places I've been to in the south bay...will definitely come back!
author: Arlene M.

description:
Not too crowded on a Sat. night but it had the perfect ambience for a drizzly night.  Great service, great atmosphere - it's very cozy despite being a fairly large restaurant and you forget you're on Lombard St.

We ordered a pitcher of Sangria (yum!), empanadillos with meat, sauteed mushrooms, tortilla a la espanola with chorizo, and calamari.  For 3 people this was actually very filling.  The tortilla was GREAT.  Highly recommended.  The empanadillos were crispy and delicious as well.  The calamari was tasty but not crispy or crunchy, I prefer to have them more on the crispy side, but still good and I couldn't stop dipping them into the aioli sauce.  The mushroom dish was kind of bland, but the other dishes made up for it.  I really want to go back for the tortilla - it was so good! Highly recommended - overall a cute, cozy tapas restaurant with excellent service and great food.
author: Emiko M.

description:
I went here for my girlfriends birthday on Saturday Night. Half of our group got there before me and ordered two pitchers of their sangria and 2 orders of the marinated olives.

The Olives were tasty and to salty perfection. We shared about 7 different dishes and I can safely save right now this is what you order (Bare with me... after several glasses of sangria my Spanish gets even poorer so I'm going to give you the poor mans version):

OBVIOUSLY the Sangria
Warm Goat cheese (so warm and fuzzy we ordered seconds)
Mushrooms (even better after is dipping you bread in the delicious sauce)
Potatoes in Spicy sauce or the Potatoes ailioli (we had both and it was a fight to the finish on them)
Crab Cakes

Just OK: The Spinach, the pork lion, and the prawns

My god there was probably more. But long story short... 9 very full/drunk girls and a bill less than $200. 

4 stars because the service was a little too slow. When we asked them to bring menus, our food or the check they looked at us like we speaking gibberish (Me might have, but who knows?)
author: Nancy B.

description: The oxtail stew special was yummy as were the carne empanadas. We were in a rush and the service was really fast.
author: Matt V.

description: Excellent!  Excellent food, excellent service and excellent that you can make a reservation online too!!!  My husband brought me here for my birthday in November and we had an incredible time, savoring each tapas dish we ordered, along with a superb bottle of red wine (thanks to our server - who was most helpful in that department).  We set our appointment early so we would have enough time to enjoy our meal, but also have enough time to make a show.  Because of this, we were given the choice to pick our own table.  So we did, right next to the front window.  It was perfect!  And the lighting helped set the mood.  We were incredibly happy with our experience and will most definitely be back.  Thank you Alegrias!
author: Christina C.

description:
Nothing bad, but nothing really good either.

Everything was tasty, but nothing really that hit the spot.  The place does have a romantic vibe, but I don't know if I want to come back.
The paella was too expensive and not that great.  Seriously had better.
author: AhLin C.

description:
This was a brief review I wrote for Amanda who told me to post this up on yelp, sooo here it is. 

The place is family owned and operated and has been so since I've been going there back in the mid-90's.  Funny little history about the place, it used to be the garage for the building its in.  I took an older friend there once who used to live in the building and would always have to avoid the center post (in the back room) to park her car.

I always request to sit in the back room when possible because I like the ambiance.  I've taken friends from Spain there and they LOVED it.  My favorite server is Lorenzo (Larry) he's the little odd looking guy but is sweet as can be (as are the owners, look for the old spanish lady dressed up or the white haired guy with the potbelly).  Usually a guitar player is there on weekends.
 
I always start with the bowl of spanish olives, tortilla espanola, gambas (garlic prawns are great for dipping bread), mushrooms,  and then move onto the chicken lamb and beef (I don't recall which ones are stewwed and which are skewered, but its all pretty good.  If you're feeling brave, try the octopus, its supposed to be excellent.  If they have the empanadas I'd suggest trying them.  You can't go wrong with a pitcher of their sangria or their crema caramel crepe for dessert.
 
AVOID the paella, it takes forever and is disappointing.  The salads are meh, so also avoid.
author: Martin M.

description:
Of all the 'tapas-style' restaurants in the area, this is my fave for serving actual Spanish tapas... where else you can get tripe, done well, and washed down immediately with an extremely well-priced bottle of rioja? as well as other great snackalicious items, including an excellent tortilla. 

Tip: if you want the paella, order as soon as you sit down -- it takes a while.  

Additional tip: Do not fill up on the crusty bread.  You will need it and the belly space to sop up the delicious sauces from the dishes to follow.

I'll give you that the atmosphere is a little weird, what with the entrance right off of Lombard, and the interior sort of decorated like the parlor of a little old lady that doesn't get out much.
author: Sasha R.

description:
We went to Alegrias for a low-key dinner on Friday night, and were more than pleasantly surprised.

We ordered several tapas, and the vegetarian paella. The stewed rabbit was awesome, although a bit of work was required to get to the meat (rabbits are bony animals, as our server reminded us). We also ordered a special that consisted of suasages cooked with apples and onions. We needed to order more bread just to soak up the delicious broth.

The best tapas we ordered was the spanish peppers stuffed with lamb. They were small and soft, with an intense pepper flavor (but not spicy), in a suiza-like sauce.

But the hands-down winner was definitely the paella. The veggies were freshly-sauteed, hot and still a little crunchy. The rice was heavy with saffron, and the dish was served in a cast-iron pan. We were so stuffed that we ended up eating most of the paella as leftovers...

Our server made the dining experience even more enjoyable, even though he pressured us with vigilance to get the meat paella. Wilko was knowledgeable and opinionated about the wine, and chose a great bottle for us.

We enjoyed our meal and sevice so much that we felt compelled to relay our feelings to the manager, who was very flattered and invited us back.

We may be back as soon as next week!
author: Michael F.

description:
Because I am a loser, I demand to come to places that I am not invited to, using my girlfriend as an all access card.  I basically invited myself to an all girl's birthday party dinner and stole the show with my gluttony and thievery, most most importantly, my wit and charm.  I felt the close knitness of this all girl troupe was rather apocryphal until I was there, solidifying the last and most important member of the group.  My dear comrade who I have codenamed Huckleberry, had her birthday at this venue.  Parking was typical Marina, however we were fortunate to find a VIP spot right across the street.

Walking in, I was a bit surprised.  It seemed pretty upscale with the clientele well dressed and devoid of creeps.  The restaurant was dimly lit, having an aura of rustic romance.  We were immediately led to our reserved table in the back and the waiters were very attentive, always giving us bread and watchful of our sangria pitcher.  We ordered:

1.  assortment of cheese and sausage (goat, sheep, cow) - the sausages reminded me of lap cheurng (chinese sausages)  the sheep cheese was the best

2.  crab cakes with jalapenos sauce - i usually don't eat crab but it was pretty good

3.  steamed mussels in white wine sauce- mussels taste like nothing to me...its like eating air in object form

4.  oven cooked goat cheese - very rich and very delicious

5.  tripe- didn't touch

6.  sauteed spinach-this was okay...just your basic spinach

7.  crisp fried potatoes in alioli sauce -basically diced french fries...DELICIOUS...order 3-4 plates of this!!!

8.  stewed rabbit - the rabbit was good, however, I didn't like the sauce that it was with

9.  veggie empanadillas-tasted like an 8th grade taco pocket or chimmychaunga

10. tortilla a la espanola-it tasted like quiche...i don't like quiche

11.  paella with chicken and seafood- specialty but didn't like.  I don't know if it was the saffron or what, but it overpowered everything

The ambiance is very fun.  We went during a bunch of birthday celebrations so the night turned into the battle of the birthdays.  Basically one table would sing their obligatories, followed by ours, followed by another and we would try to top one another by who could sing in higher octaves and decibels.  I kilt it with the vocals btw.  Our table was a little cramped, especially when you have 10+ dishes, however, our waiter was very helpful and genuine.
