The sangria was good, however, I went through a franzia phase which pretty much destroyed my taste for wine.  A sip of red wine just transports me to Chicago when all we had was franzia in coffee cups and nothing to wash the foul taste with.  It was a very dark time for me.  The bread was plentiful to break over, however, it seemed a little stale.  BOTTOM LINE, THE BEST DISH IS THE FRIED POTATOES.  They are french fries in minced form...so good.  I was hogging it from everyone and I do not regret it one bit.  Because I am a male, tapas doesn't do it for me when you have to share with 7 others.  I just view them as threats, little laughing hyenas.  Come here with one significant other, i emphasize, ONE other.  The price is very decent...about 28 bucks a person for 8 so I cannot complain.  In my estimation, the food is very ordinary, however the ambiance and the potatoes make up for it.
author: Brian V.

description:
My family is huge.  Duh...I'm Mexican AND I'm Catholic.  For my aunt's 60th birthday two of my cousins (there are 14 on my mom's side) and I wanted to take her out for her birthday just the three of us.  We came here and had a beautiful dinner.  They even turned off the ambient music so she could hear a special birthday phone call come in.   

The tapas were delicious, the paella was delicate yet flavorful.  The sangria was just right, too.  The waiters joked with us and came in with a crepe flambe as a birthday dessert for her.  

It's a cute litte place.  They are very welcoming and quick to serve.  Definitely go with a small group or a romantic dinner for two.
author: Jay H.

description:
Service was awesome.  Very relaxing enviornment.  Food was amazing, very authentic.  Go with the pitcher of sangria and any of the specials and you wont go wrong.

Food: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Ambiance: 3/5
author: M R.

description:
Yum. YUM!

It's easy to miss this unassuming place on Lombard Street, flanked by hotels, dime a dozen restaurants and whatnot. But once you're inside, you feel like you have stepped into an oasis of sorts, dim (and from time to time the lights flicker thanks to a fridge), romantic and definitely very homey, in a good way. The food is simple, unassuming, and definitely won't get all weird and fusiony on you the way some restaurants do to get that "flair" to it. What you see is what you get, and you'll enjoy your meal for sure.

I was there one before, but tonight I remember the menu: setas al ajillo, empanadillas vegetarianas, patatas bravas, and this crazy spinach/garlic/raisin/apple/pine nuts thing that was THE bomb, son! I am not down with spinach, but the server turned me onto it, and hell, you only live once, so why not throw it down the gullet? It works, people. We also had the panqueque manzanas for dessert, an apple crepe set ablaze with some massive rum that will get your motor runnin. That fire did not go out for a while. Hm. Tipsy much? Why yes!

Good date place, good family place, and definitely a good place for your out of towners. Parking is a bitch, but there's a lot across the street (on Lombard). But the sangria that awaits you makes circling blocks should you want to try and find that elusive free spot makes it all worth while.
author: Charlene L.

description: I've never had Spanish food until I ate at this restaurant and I'm hooked!  The meat that they use is incredible and the service is relatively fast.  All the people who work there are really nice and the ambiance is great.  It's a good place to have an intimate dinner with friends and family or go out on a date. But the great thing is that you don't have to dress up to go there.  My favorite dishes there (I forget the Spanish names) are the tripe, chorizo, and paella. What I like about Alegrias is that it's more authentic than some of the other Spanish restaurants that I've been to.  Instead of trying to cater to people who are used to California cuisine, Alegrias seems to stay true to Spanish cuisine which makes eating there not only more enjoyable, but educational to people who have never been to Spain.  When I want to eat out in San Francisco, Alegrias is one of my go-to places.
author: Astrid H.

description:
Excellent food and a surprisingly quiet and comfortable dinning room, as it is located right on the busy Lombard Street. Three of us shared a selection of hot and cold tapas and one order of Paella.

The Gambas al Ajillo, Shrimp with garlic, parsley and white Rioja Wine, the Espinacas a la Catalana, spinach with raisins, apple, and pine nuts and the Manchego Flambeado, Manchego cheese flamed with brandy were all excellent. There are a few variations of Paella on the menu and the Paella a la Valenciana, with chicken and seafood, that we ordered merits special praise for it's subtle saffron taste (not just yellow rice), well balanced seasoning and combination of ingredients including perfectly prepared mussels, clams and shrimp. Elsewhere I have been served larger versions of Paella, but that's mostly meant more rice. Alegrias' version is packed with seafood and chicken and was still plenty to share after a selection of tapas.

The service was friendly, relaxed, but timely.
author: David L.

description:
I went their based on some other Yelp reviews and was not disappointed!
The wine list was great and the food was very good. I went with my bofriend and father, and we ended up sharing the prawns (which had a great white wine sauce to dip bread into), the Manchego Flambeado - which was flaming when it came to our table - this was also a good choice - but I love cheese so that was no surprise :) We also had the cured ham. 
Then Paella for the main course - this was the highlight! It was rich with flavor and contained a wide array of meat - shellfish, squid, chorizo, chicken... It was very good and when you combine that with the excellent service and nice ambiance, we had a great time!
I will definitely have to go back so I can try more of the tapas!
author: Dash H.

description:
A sharp contrast to Cha Cha Cha's informal, New Orlean's style, Alegrias is quieter and cozier. While also serving tapas, the style is a little different, in terms of food prep. Six of us converged for dinner on a Saturday night, beating the dinner rush by about 30 minutes. Highlights included:

- Seafood paella w/ chorizo - heavy on the seafood, a light on the rice. It was nice being able to add the chorizo, though it was as spicy as I had hoped for.
- Beef empanadillas - golden-fried on the outside, chock full of flavorful beef. Definitely good stuff and medium-sized, but only 2 per order.
- Tortilla espanola w/ chorizo - it was interesting having tortilla espanola served warm, but I liked it. Thin slices of potato with chorizo mixed in, I also liked the red sauce that came on top.
- Patatas de alioli - instead of the almost-steak-cut fries that I'm used to getting, these potatoes came out almost like home fries, small cubes with a really tasty alioli sauce.
- Calamares fritos con alioli - fried food is always good, even better when the calamari is accompanied by alioli sauce.

Other stuff included manchego flambeado (flaming cheese a la Greek saganaki) and gambas al ajillo (shrimp sauteed w/ white wine and garlic). The sangria was pretty good and a little cheaper than Cha Cha Cha.

Overall, I liked it. More intimate atmosphere with tasty food and worth coming back for more.

- Gambas al ajillo.
author: Albert C.

description: Very tasty food served in a comfortable setting and friendly attentive staff.  Gambas were cooked in a delicious sauce that I kept sopping up with bread, the empanadas had a flavorful filling and crispy crust, seafood paella was a generous portion with a variety of fish and shellfish.  The crema catalan was excellent.
author: Ash A.

description: I took my girlfriend here for NYE dinner, and it was amazing. Great food, excellent wait staff, great decor. I recommend this place to anyone.
author: Peter C.

description:
A group of 5 of us ate here on a really busy Sunday night when most restaurants simply required a very long wait. We were in the area and decided that tapas sounded good and as Alegrias got good reviews we went for it. 
On entering we were not really in love with the feel of the place as it is somewhat dated but the service, cleanliness and food proved to be fantastic.
We got a good spread of tapas including garlic shrimp, sheep cheese, the tortilla, asparagus and a few other things. Since we were pretty hungry with thought that adding a paella to our order would help. Usually the paella at Spanish restuarants tends to have rice that is undercooked or overcooked, or the seafood doesn't seem fresh, however at Alegrias that was not the case. While the paella is not necessarily exactly what you might find in a fine restaurant in Spain, it is certainly very good. In fact it may be one of the best ones I have had in the US.
We also got some Spanish wine which our waiter recommended and it was truly good. In order to finish out our great dinner we got a nice spread of desserts. The flan, pancakes with apples, pancakes with dulce de leche and some chocolate cake. The flan was pretty good but everything else was just average so perhaps save your dessert appetite for another establishment. 
So all in all if you are looking for a carefully prepared tapas dinner with great ingredients don't hesitate to come to this restaurant.
author: Nadia S.

description:
I loved how quaint this place tries to be.  When you have some of the best, hard to find Spanish wines - you ain't a mom and pop shop, but they stay so down to earth and friendly here, it's kinda amazing.

More on the romantic side, candle style lighting and smaller tables, might be awkward if you're planning on a business dinner.

Loved their Spanish wines, ended up polishing off a couple bottles with my man - hey, it was our anniversary (since I'm Spanish my bf will try to like find secret Spanish places to surprise me with now and then - very cute).

They have this goat cheese, Cazuela de Queso de Cabra, not to be confused with the manchego cheese dish, that was amazing - I ate too much and felt farty afterwords so beware.  The manchego cheese dish came out on fire at a table across the way from us, that looked great too, but we didn't order it.

The rabbit stew was good, but I got a couple tiny bones and it creeped me the fuck out so I had to stop eating it.

Alegria's was the first tapas restaurant I've been to in the city that can actually be called Spanish tapas, all the traditional Spanish flavors and care went into the food and everything came out delectable.

The empanadillas de carne were great, and the Gambas al Ajillo were delicioso - I love the tiger prawns at Bossa Nova and these were cooked very similar in a heavy wine sauce.

My bf didn't really care too much for the Tortilla a la Espanola, but it totally reminded me of Spain and I loved it, it was fluffy and flavorful, not heavy like most American Spanish restaurants tend to do.

I will definitely go back on another romantic dinner for the wine and tapas, they were so good I don't know if I'll ever make it to the actual entrees.
author: Lauren G.

description:
A fellow Yelper directed me here when a different tapas place had too long of a wait for my impatient belly.  What a pleasant surprise.  My date and I were definitely NOT disappointed.  We ate the following:
- Tabla de Quesos y Chorizos Espanoles (assortment of cheese & cured sausage)
- Bocadillos de Cangrejo (crab cakes)
- Gambas al Ajillo (garlic prawns)
- Pimientos del Piquillo Rellenos con Cordero (lamb stuffed peppers)
- Shrimp and Prosciutto croquette of the day

ALL of it was great.  The various sheep cheeses were awesome, the crab cakes were the best I've ever had, and the croquettes were deliciously light and fluffy.  

Not to mention, the atmosphere was romantic and elegant, and the service was top notch.  We'll definitely make a repeat visit.
author: Lil B.

description:
Atmosphere:  Cozy but not noisy and Lovely

Tapas:  Price is right and all good (but the crab cakes are not like other yelpers' high rating, it is good but not like ***** kind of good)

Drinks:  Sangria is authentic and generous

Main Course:  Paella is authentic and tasty

I will come back again to try other dishes next time.
author: Flora C.

description:
I came home from work and strangely wanted paella. I didn't know that was an actual craving - but I had it and needed to satisfy.

We got here early around sixish, and it was quiet and nearly empty. Taking a look at the menu, the paella (as stated before) was a given, but we also picked 2 tapas: the warm goat cheese in red sauce, and the patatas bravas.

This is an actual quote from me while eating these tapas:
"This cheese tastes like la la la, and these potatoes taste like lo lo lo and when I eat them together it's like a symphony playing in  heaven. I'm in heaven right now."

Does that make sense? Translation: best tapas ever!

The paella was fantastic: chicken, calamari, mussels, rice, peas, peppers. And it was placed with care and purpose on our plates by our waiter (who was also a delight)

Great and quiet dinner. I couldn't even look at the dessert menu. Will definitely come back for that goat cheese. Wow. Just...wow.
author: Alicia C.

description:
Alegrias Will Make You Alegre!

I love this spot. I've been going here for about 10 years and each meal is as good as the last.

The breadth of tapas choices is superb and the paella is wonderful. The staff is very friendly and it adds an aura of authenticity that many are from Spain or Latin America. This is a family owned and run business and it truly has that feel.

Alegrias is also perfect for large groups, because they have an excellent backroom. I've celebrated 2 birthdays there with about 15 guests and we all had an amazing time. Oh, and did I mention that the sangria is perfect?!

Frankly, Alegrias doesn't need the accolades, because once you visit---- the food, service and atmosphere will speak for themselves. This is also a great first date spot, because it's casual, tastey and makes you feel at ease.

Ole!
author: David R.

description: I went with a couple of friends and ordered several dishes to share. None impressed. B44 is a much better tapa place if you crave tapas.
author: Cindy W.

description:
We saw this restaurant getting reviewed on Check please (on PBS), and that drew our attention. My wife and I are Tapas lovers and we went absolutely tapas-happy when we went to Spain a couple of years ago - so needless to say our standards were pretty high!

Alegrias did not disappoint us at all. To summarize

Ambience-  they have a great cozy decor (perfect for dates). 
Drinks - Their Sangria is easily one of the best we've ever tasted - amazingly sweet
Food - awesome awesome - loved the tapas and loads of veggie options, and not too expensive. Their veggie/seafood paella was really good as well.
Coffee - Best cafe con leche we've had outside of spain and argentina - 'nuff said
Service - very attentive and friendly service.

Good times!!
author: Sid A.

description: My bf took me here on my 22nd birthday. The place is small and very home-like. It is decorated nicely and has a peaceful atmosphere. We ended up getting a bunch of small tapas and all of them were very delicious. The sangria was good as well. Overall, great place!! Definitely Recommend to go.
author: Karina A.

description:
Soo good!  If you want Paella then this is your place to GO!!  I had the Paella with chorizo and it came out phenomenal!  We also had the potatoes with the aioli  sauce mmmmm!  

I've been to other spots that claim to have the best Paella but I believe Alegrias has the best (so far).  Past Paellas that I've had usually comes out greasy but not here!
author: Maria E.

description:
We went last night.  We've been to Spain.  Sangria was good, olives were good... everything else was pretty bad.  The tortilla espanola was soggy and greasy. The pulpo was chalky and over cooked. Anchovies, which are sometimes soaked in water to limit saltiness or oil, were bland and flavorless.

We were also sat at the table at the very front which was cramped, cold, and my wife hated.

We won't be going back.

They did comp us on the Sangria because we obviously were not enjoying ourselves.
author: Chris A.

description:
It doesn't look like much from the outside, and it's on that busy, charmless stretch of Lombard, but the inside of the restaurant is cozy and the staff is very friendly.  The paella servings are huge - best to split it with someone (along with a few plates of tapas, of course).  And don't forget the sangria!

I went with a friend who had just returned from a vacation in Barcelona and he really liked it, so I think that's a good sign.
author: DD B.

description:
One of my marina-based friends has been wanting to try Alegrias for awhile but has insisted on waiting for me. I recently visited Alegrias for the 3rd time and it has never failed to disappoint. 

Of all of the Spanish places I've been to, incl. Cafe Iberico in Chicago, this continues to impress with solid food, fast and attentive service (the kind you'd expect of a tapas restaurant) and a cozy well decorated environment and should be considered among the best.

On a wet windy night we were relieved to step inside Alegrias where it was nice and warm and cozy - this felt like what it means to come inside from the storm. Even with a 7pm reservation the place was relative empty at 6:45 when we showed up so they were able to seat us right away. The restaurant is set up with a front and back room, the front containing the bar area. The walls are adorned with scenes from Spain, including photos of bullfight arenas. There are also various kinds of pottery and other flora around meant to reveal aspects of Iberian culture.

I wouldn't consider myself a big Sangria drinker but that was the first thing we ordered and it came out promptly. I'd say it was sweet, but perhaps that's my uneducated Sangria palate. You could also taste the other ingredients, the brandy and citrus. I'd order it again, but I'd probably opt for a Rioja to go with my Spanish food first.

We went for the Tortilla de chorizo, patatas bravas, pinchos morunos (pork skewers), cetas al ajillo (mushrooms in garlic), and the Empanadas de Carne. All came out fairly swiftly and no single dish disappointed. The empanadas had many ingredients to compliment the meat, all of which went very well together. The pinchos morunos were moist and flavorful. I'm not a big mushroom guy but the garlic sauce made them worthwhile to me. For the next round we got the empanads de verdura ( vegetarian) and the gambas (prawns in garlic). I'm not big into shrimp but I was a big fan of these.

For dessert we had the Crema Catalan which was essentially a citrus infused Creme Brulee which was awesome! Our friends had the bread pudding - i'm not a bread pudding aficionado but i knew this tasted good and I'd highly recommend both.

About an hour into the meal the place began to fill up but the noise level never got offensive and the service did not drop off.

I've not had dinner at Zarzuella, and I'm hesitant to call Thirsty Bear authentic Spanish food but until such time I will call Alegrias my standard for tapas in the Bay Area.
author: Ross R.

description:
My dad chose this restaurant for Mother's Day which made me really happy because I've always wanted to check this place out. 

The restaurant is small and cozy. You feel like you're dining at someone's house, with all the floral accents and Spanish decor on the wall (from traditional plates and the bullfighting spears). 

Our server was very friendly and answered any questions about the menu items. Because this is a tapas style resto, we ordered a lot of different things to try: crab cakes, patatas bravas, garlic shrimp, calamari, mussels, the marinated anchovies (ZOMG, the best thing EVAR) and two orders of paella a la valenciana con chorizo espanol. I'm not a big paella fan (unlike my dad who tends to make it for big parties at home) but their paella was pretty tasty and the saffron flavor came through as well. 

Along with a bottle of some '97 Spanish cab (yikes, the name escapes me at the moment), it made for a pretty fantastic dinner. 

Dessert was good too, the bread pudding was good and you can really taste the rum in the apple crepes.
author: kristin e.

description:
When I used to live in San Francisco, this was one of my favorite restaurants. I make it a point to eat here every time I am in town. If I could afford it, I would order one of every single thing on the menu and taste them all, because all dishes have been delicious. 

The service is great, the atmosphere is great, the food is divine.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Lovely service, yummy food, tasty sangria.  PLUS they were able to seat 5 of us as walk-ins on a Friday evening at 8pm.  

The tortilla a la espagnola was about the best I've tried in the City.  PLUS MAJOR BONUS Points.  They made a special paella with vegetable stock for us yesterday after the chef personally made an effort to visit our table and ensure that the person allergic to fish (aka "me") wouldn't suffer anaphylactic shock.    He was gracious and I knew that I'd be ok.  And the paella was super yummy.

Would come back again in a heartbeat.
author: Jane A.

description:
Good enough food.  Decent service.  Nice space.  Random location though, right on Lombard.  I went here for a friend's birthday and the pris fixe was perfect for our group.  They gave us more food than we could have dreamt of eating, which is great because I know some people (aka my beau) can leave tapas restaurants still hungry.

Generally speaking though, I'm kind of over tapas...
author: Alyssa W.

description: Best experience I had for Spanish food. You guys are hella awesome. ¡Muchimás graciás!
author: Jeffrey G.

description:
Good service and easily got a reservation.

The bottle of Rioja we ordered was excellent.

I like the Patatas Bravas at Iberia (in Menlo Park) much better, Alegrias's version is small sliced spicy potatoes. The goat cheese with tomato sauce was excellent too.
author: Sumit C.

description: My favorite Spanish Restaurant!  Always excellent service.  I love their mix paella and squid ink paella.  The croquettas are amazing.  Shrimp tapas are a must.  Creme brûlée is amazing.  Never a disappointment.  Thank you!
author: Elena H.

description: Delicious appetizers, sangria & seafood paella. Great find; a tapas gem in the Marina.
author: Gregg M.

description:
Blah.  We should have gone to Zarzuela.  
I took my best friend here for her birthday, and I found it very disappointing.  The food was pedestrian (I found the paella particularly dull), and the service was slooow, unenthusiastic, and inattentive.  The two bright spots were the sangria, and the flamin' apple crepey-thingy our waiter brought to the birthday girl for dessert, but really...they weren't that bright.
author: Miss N.

description:
I absolutely love this place!  They have the best tapas and paella.  Their sauteed mushrooms are so good we always order 2.  They also have really good sangria.

It's a quaint little place and the service is always warm and friendly.  We've taken all our out-of-town friends here and they all love it.  This place is also very kid friendly - We came here with my cousin and her 4 year old daughter - they gave her a coloring book and crayons to keep her busy so  the adults can chat and have dinner in peace.
author: Maggie Y.

description:
Went here for a birthday party and it was just lovely.  Sweet little place with very friendly service and great food.  

The tapas were great - i especially liked the octopus and the goat cheese + marina sauce, which was kind of like a soup.  The vegetarian paella was a completely tasteless waste of perfectly good paella pan space, but I guess we had to please everyone.  Probably not the best place to go if you don't eat meat or seafood.

It's on the pricey side, and the servings could have been bigger.
author: Cassandra W.

description:
3.5 stars

Came here with my boyfriend last night for his bday dinner. He lived in Spain from age 8-19 so he's had a few tapas to compare this meal to.

We ordered:
Quesos y Chorizos (cheese and sausage plate)
Tortilla with potatoes (like a potatoe pancake of sorts-includes egg)
Gambas (prawns with garlic sauce)
Paella Valancencia (I probably butchered the names of all of these)

Everything was delicious but not WOW like. The Paella was my favorite and the risotto was done perfectly, not too al dente and not too soft. It was packed with seafood and had a creamy sauce-the dish was also huge.

The rest of the tapas we ordered were ok, I wasn't expecting the cheese plate to be just cheese, so it was a heavy and filling way to start the meal-probably our fault for that since we had more of a Corsica plate in mind-with different kinds of sausages and cheese...this was 3 blocks of cheese with a few pieces of dried chorizo-still really good but just not the right plate to start with. The Gambas were good too, but missing something-I can't help but compare them to the creamy cajun shimp dish at Cha Cha Cha's...i shouldn't, totally different tapas. The tortilla was great, something I think I could probably try to do at home for us-just no sparks in my mouth as I ate it.

Overall, this is a great place to have a warm, intimate dinner. The Sangria is delicious and the service was prompt-could have been friendlier but I understand what customer service can do to people. At the end of the day, this place warrants another visit (and more Paella for me).
author: nina B.

description: It was my first time having Spanish food, so I would say it's pretty good. I ordered Garlic Shrimps, Ham and Shrimps croquettes, and Seafood paella. Food and service was good.
author: Emily R.

description:
Overall pretty good! Nice homey ambiance and we were seated immediately.  Ok now to the food.... we tried:
1. Tortilla a la Espanola: tasty spanish frittata
2. Manchego Flameado: wow talk about presentation!! they had a large wedge of manchego cheese sitting in brandy which they lit on fire to give it a really nice melt.... this was delicious on bread and with the frittata
3. Espinacas a la Catalana: Yummy spinach dish with raisins and pine nuts,,, I must try to duplicate this at home
4. Pimientos de Piquillos Rellenos con Cordero: peppers stuffed with lamb: eh ok, but I wouldn't order this again.
5. Setaj al ajillo: sauteed mushrooms --- REALLY plain and something I could make at home.  
6. For dessert, the flambeed apple crepe.... pretty good! Again, the playing with fire made it more impressive.  

Oh and of course, the sangria was awesome....
author: Grace M.

description: This place has good food, great service, but nothing to come back for or rave about when you have unlimited options in SF. We had 4 dishes; Tortilla Espanola, Poached Octopus with potatoes, and Shrimp croquettes, and Crap cakes. The only thing I would come back here for is the Shrimp croquettes. This was really creamy and tasty! Octopus was my second fav, this was flavored well, served on the sliced potato. Portion was very small (yes, knowing that it is tapas). Crab cake was kind of too dense, hard and heavy. Tortilla Espanola, which is the famous Spanish potato pancake that I always get at any tapas place, was really just mediocre. Overall, I had way better tapas anywhere else in the city for better prices. Oh, the sangria was pretty good, but Chachacha is better ;P Maybe the extra $$ goes for the Marina location and the excellent service, but I'm all set on that.
author: Cartman P.

description:
Some people are ga ga for this place.  I thought the waitstaff was very professional, and the overall service was great.  For the decor, it's kind of old and rustic on the inside -- has a grandmothery feel to it.

The menu is eclectic - with rabbit, lamb, snails, etc.  But, nothing really stood out.
author: Tim G.

description:
I lived in Fuengirola, Spain until I was 7. I think at that time I was more concerned about playing marbles in the dirt and eating five cent candy than finding the most delicious paella with the freshest seafood or  the most refreshing sangria... But I do have some memories of some golden paella topped with mussels and shrimp as well as some tomato conejo.

Alegrias really brought back those memories. Down to the huge succulant shrimp and mussels on top of the paella. The decor also brought back some of that rustic white commonly seen in Spanish walls. The sangria was exceptionally good. Beat out my previous favorite from Cha Cha Cha's.  The food was very good. In anticipation, I think in my mind I hyped myself up over the paella and was expecting too much.... The paella turned out to the "filler", while the tapas were the stars. The calamari was exceptional, as were the mussels in white wine. For the dessert, the flan was delicious as well.
author: Scuba X.

description:
Great paella and tapas that remind me of my vacations in Spain.

I came here for a bday dinner so there were 6 of us that ate family style.  We went through a couple of pitchers of sangria which was really good.  There were about 20 tapas to choose from and they were all yummy.  My faves out of the 8-10 that we got was: 
- patatas aioli - potatoes were nice and crispy and the sauce was delicious
- crab cakes
- empanadillas de carne
- mussels
- calimari
They were all good.  Then we got a seafood paella that topped off the meal nicely.  It was really delicious.  

Each tapas plate was about $6-$9 and the paella was about $18 each.  A pitcher of sangria was like $18.

The atmosphere was really homey with lots of photos hanging on the walls.  Good location - you can park in the Lombardt parking lot right across the street.  Also walkable distance to some bars afterwards.  I would definitely come back - the food was so yummy!
author: Doris L.

description:
So I studied abroad in spain last summer.. it was AMAZING. the cuisine however, did not quite live up to expectations as they're food is mostly bland, fried, or over loaded with carbs and no spices. 

Alegrias had a quaint and genuine vibe that brought me back to my spain days. Dimly lit and despite the limited menu, I did not have trouble finding multiple items that sparked my taste buds. I immediately knew I wanted to order the conejos con aceltunas-- stewed rabbit cooked in red wine with tomatoes and olives, served with potatoes.  Absolutely AMAZING! The rabbit was so tender and well seasoned, not to mention my love for stewed tomatoes! My mom got the Pescado del Dia.. i think it was a rainbow trout but that was really good as well. We also ordered croquettes del dia (bomb.com), potatas bravas, empanadillas de carne, and tortilla espanola of course! The croquettes were ham and cheese and just like those is spain. Crumbly crunch with every bite and hot, tasty, creamy inside! The potatas bravas were nice but not too big of a fan of potatoes in general. The aioli sauce that comes on top of it def adds a the touch it needs. The tortilla espanola was a little diff from the kind my senora back in spain would make.. The texture of the kind served here was a little diff and had a more spongey tamago feel to it--meh. The Empanadillas however were soooooo good!!! I def would highly recommend those!! 

Overall, pretty good service, nice ambiance, great food but def a little overpriced. Tapas are small little appetizer dishes... the fact that they charge 9$ for tapas blow my mind. Based on portion size and ingredients.. those tapas shouldn't exceed more than  $5-6.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Came here last night for our monthly dinner with the girls.

The atmosphere is quaint and very intimate. It looks small when you enter but it's a decent sized restaurant. The waiters were very attentive and never missed a beat when it came to refilling drinks and giving the table more bread. 

The food was very good. My favorites are the Patatas Bravas, the Croquettes and the Carne Empanadas!!! YUMMO. The desserts we got were the Crema Catalana and the Dulce de Leche..another yummo. For a drink the sangria was very tasty.

I would come again. It was a very pleasant experience.
author: Jazmine S.

description:
Service 4.5 stars, food 4 stars, decor 4 stars

Came here on Monday night and we were very pleased of the experience.
Our server, an Argentinian lady (sorry we didn't get the name) and her server assistant gentleman both were very professional and personable at the same time. We loved their service.

We had albarino, rioja and their sangria.  While both of their wines were excellent and great with their food, sangria I questioned. It didn't go with food at all.

We ordered 4 tapas items and paella. Tapas items were all excellent. Special of the day fish cheek, cured meat, anchovy and octopus and potatoes. All amazing.

Paella and dessert bread pudding, not as amazing. I would expect the same chef who put those tapas out to be better at the rest of the menu too. If we do come back we are sticking to wine and tapas only.
author: Kokoro I.

description:
Not bad, but definitely overpriced. Paella was overcooked and rice was burned and attached to the pan. Being in so many tapas places, I am definitely not impressed. 
Next time I would head to Andalu or Ramblas again.
author: Julia A.

description: Went there a few weeks ago for my birthday. The sangria is as tasty as everyone says and the seafood paella is great! The tapas we tried were all pretty tasty as well. We had the spicy potatoes, potatoes with aiolli, mushrooms, shrimp in garlic sauce, calamari. The tapas choices are pretty standard but well executed. I would say the highlight of the meal is the paella and the sangria with the tapas making a nice accompaniment. The desserts were also good. We had the flan and some sort of flambe dessert.
author: Dani D.

description:
I just don't know what the buzz is about this place. We were let down. And we felt cheated.

The tapas were just OK. We followed the yelp recommendations and didn't order mains, just filled ourselves with tapas.

We had the patatas bravas (soggy and drenched in sauce- this was a mess), the sauteed spinach (was perfectly OK), the gambas (like rubber and barely edible) , the croquettes (very mushy, inside and out), and the crab cakes (my favorite of the poor choices). We may have had a few others but they were that unmemorable that I forgot them.

The sangria was fine and enjoyable. That saved this place from getting 1 star.

The meal was $90 all in and not worth it at all. We;re not going back.

For tapas, Bocadillos is 10 times better. Go there. Or Iluna Basque. Skip this place.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Great for a group dinner - this way you can try everything :) The portions are decent, it's ~$10 per plate.

Not quite the same as what I had in Spain, but still quite good :) The patatas bravas were really good - different, but tasty. Also, get the garlic mushrooms - they were so good we got a second order. The gambas were also good. 

Only sadness was the jamon serrano - not very aged and such a small plate... you kinda just wanted more. 

The goat cheese was really clutch - great with the (free) bread. 

Overall, good ambiance, easy to get a table, & the wait staff was incredible (I've never seen such fast service... before we even ran out of bread, we were getting refills & my water glass was always full).
author: linda t.

description: Love this place for authentic tapas.  It has a relaxed atmosphere.  It isn't super trendy or fancy, but the food is good and that keeps us coming back.  Love the goat cheese & empanadas.
author: Melissa G.

description:
Alegrias Tapas Restaurant is delightful, especially after a long day at work. The food is delicious, atmosphere charming, soothing with its soft lighting and service is good. 

Meter parking outside the restaurant is available but not easy to find since Lombard Street is always busy with traffic. Alegrias specializes in Spanish cuisine and while it is the custom of Spain to eat dinner late into the night, Alegrias closes at 10 PM.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Ter-ri-ble. We ordered a number of dishes that went from bad to worse, the absolute worst being a sausage dish that tasted like ballpark hotdogs gone wrong. (I love ballpark hotdogs, and guess what? They don't belong in tapas.)

Sangria was so light we doubted there was any wine in it whatsoever. Only switching to a glass of wine got me through this dinner. 

Decor is... cheap. They cover vinyl chairs with cloth in order to disguise this poorly. Just invest in some cloth table cloths! Linen service can't be prohibitive. 

The fact that the bill, with a pitcher of Sangria, my glass of wine, and nearly every appealing-LOOKING dish on the menu, was around $100 didin't make up for the experience.
author: Simone E.

description:
I will preface this by saying that on the whole I don't think I really "get" tapas. I think most people like tapas because it seems somehow special or perhaps a little festive, but whenever I have tapas it just feels like less food for the same price.

The food here doesn't seem like anything special to me. We had the Empanadillas, the shrimp, mussels, and goat cheese in red sauce. The empanadillas were good, but nothing else stood out. The shrimp was fairly simple and tasted like something I could make at home. I've had better mussels ... pretty much anywhere else I've had mussels. The goat cheese was good but pretty much tasted like cheesy pasta sauce. Overall 3 star food.

The above, with one beer and one sangria came out to $60. Minus 1 star for the slightly high price.
author: Tim C.

description:
Everything you've read is true.  The food at Alegrias is excellent!  I had a glass of sangria, paella valenciana, the ham and cheese croquettes, the steak, and bread pudding for dessert.  (Please note:  I was not alone...I shared these dishes with my husband and sister)  Everything was excellent!!  

I ordered the calamares as well, which were good, but weren't anything special.  I would definitely try another app on my next visit.

In addition, the atmosphere of the restaurant was nice and the service was good.
author: Dexters Parents p.

description: Been going to this place for years.  My favorite Spanish place in the bay area.  Romantic atmosphere.  The service is fantastic, and the food excellent.   Check it out!
author: Rafael M.

description: An excellent meal all around. Great service. Nice selection of Tapas. Squid and Lamb specials very nice. Rabbit excellent. Small selection of mostly Spanish wines very reasonably priced.
author: Brian K.

description:
Very good tapas menu.  I don't think we ate anything we didn't like here... mushrooms were good, potatoes alioli were AMAZING, pork skewers were heavenly, the Tortillas we had we delicious... well I am running out of adjectives and you get the point.   I only wish that I had room to have eaten more.  Desert was also quite good.  The wine by the glass selection is limited [3 reds] but the Rioja was quite good so it worked out in the end.  

I must eat here again.
author: Alured P.

description:
This place is excellent!  Went here to celebrate my parents' wedding anniversary and this place did not fail to impress.  Great setting, excellent presentation, friendly and cordial waiters, and excellent food.  The tapas were absolutely the bomb.  Got a little carried away with the Sangria but it's cool, I wasn't driving.  The only thing that got me was that 3 people in my group, including myself unfortunately, were plagued with stomach problems.  I'm betting it was the paella, which was excellent by the way, since all 3 of us are unfortunately in the LIC club (lactose intolerant crew).

Overall, a great experience.  I'm definitely coming back a second time, but I may pass on the paella.
author: Joe V.

description: My wife and I were looking for a place to have a nice quiet dinner on a Friday night. We are big fans of Spanish food, so I looked up Alegrias and headed over there. The food was just flavorful and delicious, specially the rabbit tapa, I would go back there just for that. And ofcourse, the sangria ;)
author: Motaz H.

description:
I love this restaurant! 

I've been here several times and each time, the food and service do not disappoint.  My husband and I went to Spain on our honeymoon and the food here brings back wonderful memories of that trip.

We love the sangria, chorizo tortilla, patatas bravas, calamari, gambas al ajillo, jamon serrano, and especially the croquettes.  The croquettes change, but they are always good.  I crave them all the time!

The last time we went was for our friend's birthday and she received a free apple crepe, which they doused in alcohol and set on fire at the table.  It was good, but I think it would have been better if they used a lighter hand with the alcohol.  

Overall, it's become a regular dinner spot for us and I can't wait to go back!
author: Jessica H.

description: Great Spanish atmosphere, very authentic art pieces. The food was okay- the sangria was mediocre. Although the lamb chops were DELICIOUS, as was the chorizo tortilla!! Worth a shot but not the best tapas place.
author: Lissette L.

description: What a wonderful meal.  The five of us had a great meal, ordering a paella of seafood and chorizo.  While the kitchen was preparing our dish we ordered five or six tapas.  The Spanish ham, a cold tapa, was a standout, as were the steamed mussels.  The garlic prawns were also very good.  We were a little unsure if our 11-year old son would be able to find something on the menu he would like, but he was happy with the fried calamari and potatoes.  We had really nice service throughout our meal.  We will definitely be coming back.
author: David S.

description:
Alegrias was a cute, intimate restaurant that offered good food with good service. The decor was alright, but it felt relaxed and quite romantic. I went there for dinner with two friends and the dinner was not spectacular, yet memorable.

We ordered a couple of their tapas. The Escalivada was a great dish to start with. It was Grilled eggplant, peppers & onions drizzled with a Spanish sherry vinegar reduction. The vegetable tasted very sweet with a little tang and brightness from the sauce. We had also their Espinacas a la Catalana, which is Sautéed spinach with garlic, raisins, apple, and pine nuts. I am a big fan of all the ingredients, but have never imagined putting them all together for a dish. It was quite interesting and I enjoyed it a lot. Another tapa that we liked was the Patatas Alioli. It was crisp fried potatoes tossed with a traditional aioli sauce. The sauce was a nice flavorful compliment to the potatoes. We finally had their Paella a la Valenciana con Chorizo Español - a paella with chicken, seafood and Spanish chorizo. It was full of flavor and delicious. It was totally worth the wait.

Alegrias was a bit on the pricey side. The experience was not bad, including the food, the service, the ambiance.
author: Jose K.

description: Mellow little spanish tapas joint in the Marina. The quiet and romantic atmosphere makes it a good date place but the big spacious rooms make it excellent for big groups and parties. The tapas come quick so you can order more if you are left hungry after the first round. The seafood paella was a highlight.  I also enjoyed the snails and the tripe.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Just went there this weekend.  Had tapas.  Pretty good I suppose, but I was a little late meeting friends there so everything was  a little cold.  My bad.  

Tried snails for the first time.  I'll pass. Fried squid - good.  Potatoes - good.  Tripe - for someone who's not crazy about tripe, pretty good.

Dessert - Crema Catalana - really good.  More like pudding than custard.  Maybe it's supposed to be like that.  

The Sangria didn't sneak up and hit  me later so, I guess it's watered down - I guess that's a good thing.

Over all still not as good as being in Spain, but pretty close.

I'll agree with Daisy, "never crowded" for a place that's in the Marina.  Hope it doesn't go outta business.
author: greg e.

description:
Sangria?! You bet cha!

You have probably driven by this place a couple (hundred) times without even noticing it's there, or even thinking its worth stopping for, (you know who you are) but every time you have passed it, you have passed Sangria and Tapas greatness.

Family run, and quiet (depending on how much Sangria is going around) atmosphere lends itself well to an array of great tapas, from Gambas al Ajillo (Garlic Shrimp) to the  Manchego Flambeado (flambe manchego cheese with brandy) to their Paella (any of their varieties are great- and huge)

So instead of passing them by again, why not stop in and check them out (yes you)?
author: Sara Ann S.

description:
A friend of mine was oh-so-sweet enough to help plan the celebrations of the anniversary of the beginning of my life, so we were debating quite a few places before settling on Alegrias.  I mainly chose it becase I love tapas, and because other people raved about the pre-fixed meal for a birthday celebration.

I definitely have to agree with the prior assessments of the place.  The pre-fixed meal made things very easy, very filling, and they were even patient enough to wait until everybody arrived.  The sangria was deeeelicious (elongated for emPHAsis) and the food was great.  There was a salad, potatoes, pork chops, spinach with pine nuts, an eggplant dish, and more.

I felt a bit bad because it was pretty pricey for all my friends, but everybody was in good spirits and it was a wonderful dinner.  They accommodated 15 people with no fuss, no muss, no problem.

If you're looking for a birthday place, definitely book it here and tip generously.
author: Shay F.

description:
Everyone has a friend like this - the friend that's well traveled, has been damn near everywhere in the world, and has settled his heart one place that he loves so much. The place he would move to if he could get a visa. The place he can't frikkin' stop talking about no matter how much you roll your eyes or make fun of him.


 I'm that guy, and my place is Spain. I freakin' love Spain.


 And if you spend much time around me, you'll hear sentences that begin with, There aren't any places we can get real tapas They don't know how to properly make The wines we get here aren't as good as The last decent paella I had was way back when Annoying, isn't it?


 Well, it all ends here.


 Here being Alegrias.


 As much as I dislike the Marina district, I might just have to renounce all the bad things I've said about it. Because the closer I am to Alegrias, the more likely I am to just shut the hell up about Spain already. Which, believe me, a lot of people would like me to do.


 They've got the wines. Some good ones. Even some of the same ones I drank regularly in you-know-where. They've got tapas. Good tapas. Sure, the patatas bravas aren't quite the same as what I got accustomed to, but these guys hit a home run with everything else. And the paella. ¡Dios mio! Give me more of that paella. I could probably eat about six of those in one sitting. Not just because the pan is a bit smaller than what you'd get at most places here (and more like the size you get you-know-where), but because it's muuuuuuy sabrosa.


 You'll hear a lot of Hispanophiles (is that a word?) bitching and moaning about the state of tapas and paella in San Francisco, largely because of craptacularly trendy places like Andalu or Ramblas or Cha Cha Cha.


 If you don't wanna hear it anymore, here's a hint: STOP GOING TO THOSE POSEUR PIG TROUGHS.


 Get over to Alegrias and not only will you shut your annoying friend up, but you might get a hint of what they're all ga-ga about.
author: Omid T.

description:
The Wifey decided we go here after her long day of rest and my long day of work.  All we knew about the place was the good reviews on Yelp and that they had Paella and Kat was craving Paella.

Nice little intimate, family owned restaurant. Expecting a casual dining experience, we were pleasantly surprised with a very fine dining with out the uppity feeling experience. Juan our server was very proper and precise which was surprising. Very attentive with out hovering.  Very intimate spanish decor'. 

The Sangria was smooth and tasty, without the tart after taste of some other tapas restaurants. The Crab cakes were crisp and tasty.  The Empanidillas de Carne were decent. Was a little afraid of the portion sizes, thinking I would be hungry afterwards, but when we received the Paella, (totally devoured it) we were stuffed.  The Paella was full of flavor.  
The flan was standard except that they use real vanilla bean instead of extract which was sort of noticeable.  

5 stars for service and food. Highly recommend. Easier parking and more intimate during weekdays.
author: Charles M.

description: Very good-small Tapas, just a bit overprice :)
author: Cyprus N.

description:
For the longest time, my BF has resisted accompanying me to a tapas restaurant.  But last night, I had my revenge!  His mother came in to town for a surprise visit (she lives in England) and I cunningly made dinner reservations and "took care of all the arrangements so as to make the visit more enjoyable."  Guess what restaurant I picked?

We found parking on the other side of Lombard, the side away from Union.  Only one block away.

One the menu, I found my prize: Marinated anchovies.  Were they delicious?  The BF's mum doesn't eat seafood.  But she slurped this beauty down with a pleasant murmur and agreeable nods of the head.

Jamon Serrano: Good.  Dried, salty, thin slices.  Not too fatty.

Potatoes with aioli sauce: Yum.  This dish went over very well with the English folk who are fond of their chips.

Crabcakes: small.  But I guess the size prevented it from getting mushy and disgusting like some.

spinach: highlight of the meal and I'll try this at home.  It had bits of apply and raisins or currants.

Mushrooms: very small portion.  I know this is tapas but there was not enough for each person (4 total) to get a spoonful.  That must translate in to 1.5 small mushrooms each.  for $9.  

Paella with chirozo and seafood:  This was nicely flavored though next time I think I'll opt out of the chirozo.  On second evaluation of this dish, I'm not sure I like chirozo.  It came at the end of the meal and we were all a bit stuffed.  Overall, it was a bit salty for my taste.

But I loved the marinated anchovies.  I want to marry them.
author: Christina C.

description:
The service was incredible, the entire wait staff was friendly, attentive and courteous. We never once had to ask for water, someone was always there filling up our glasses. Our knowledge of wine is limited to CA, their entire menu was made up of Spanish and Argentinean wines. Their sommelier was very accommodating in letting us try different wines from their menu to select a couple bottles for the table. 

We ordered the paella as the main course and while waiting for it, they brought the tapas out one by one. The paella was delicious, ok sized portion for the cost. All of the shellfish was cooked perfectly, not over done. It was rich in flavor and I believe they served it in the same cast iron it was cooked in. Some would balk at the burnt rice at the bottom, personally I like that thin layer of crust.  

In regards to tapas, the steamed mussels were really good. Enjoyed dipping the bread in the both. The goat cheese in a red sauce had a lot of positive reviews so we decided to try it. I'm not a big fan of goat cheese, but I could definitely eat it like this. This would be a good dish to serve at a wine party, except I would use garlic bread or a seeded baguette. The empanadas were nice and flaky, not too doughy and packed with filling. They did a really nice job on the calamari, although I thought the batter could have used some Spanish seasoning to differentiate it from the typical calamari you can find at most seafood restaurants - but they cooked it too perfection. They also use real baby calamari with the tentacles, not the big calamari steaks which come out like chewy onion rings. The only dish that was slightly overcooked was the asparagus with manchego cheese, nice grill marks, but I prefer my veggies with a little crunch.

Overall great dining experience, highly recommend.
author: Francis A.

description:
It was my mom's birthday and I wanted to take her somewhere different so I thought spanish food! Alegria's popped into my head because I work in the Marina and always see it and I've read the yelp reviews.

The service took a little long and it wasn't even packed. For a min I thought we were being ignored. The waiter came over and we already knew we wanted sangria. OMG it was soo delicious!! I savored every sip. Then came our tapas. I thought they would serve a little more and since there was four of us we only got one piece from each tapa. The beef empanada was the best one! It did take a while for the paella to come but it was so worth it. We ordered the paella with seafood, chicken and chorizo.  We all decided to get the same paella and one each so instead of bringing each one our plate, they combined all four plates into one giant paella.

It was so worth the wait because it was amazing. We were kinda full with all the tapas and bread but we had to eat it.  The way the waiter served each of us was so mesmerizing to watch. My friends had these facial expressions as they ate that was saying I'm in heaven.  At the end of dinner they brought a flan with a candle for my mom and we sang happy birthday to her, she loved it and was absolutely surprised! For dessert we got flan, amazing! Also some caramel crepe but it was too sweet. My friend said he'll be coming with us to all of the dinners because he loved it! 

I'll definitely come back!!
author: Yvonne S.

description:
Alegrias' setas al ajillo brought me back to the day I arrived in Spain.  Barcelona to be exact.  Around the corner from my hotel was a tapas bar.  The first thing I ordered and my first taste of Spain was setas al ajillo.  

Alegrias' setas made me a little misty eyed.  I got very quiet.  It is amazing how food can do that to you.  It can take you to the very first time you tasted it.  It was all very surreal.

If you want a trendy tapas bar which are very chic these days... a place to see and to been seen, then this isn't the place to be.  If you want a nice evening with your loved one(s), then is this a nice place.
author: Theresa M.

description: Pretty good.  I'm a fan of this place for sure.  Interesting plates and wonderful Sangria.  Just go for it when ordering.  It's hard to not like something on the menu.  Although, some will make you think twice.
author: jeff o.

description:
This place is wonderful.  It truly is little bit of Spain in the the middle of the Marina.

However, why did I pick this place?  Was it because I was looking for Tapas?  (no) Was it because I read yelp reviews?  (wish i could say yes)  Was there any shred of intention at all? (no)  I chose to try this place because when driving by I was completely unable to read the name of the restaurant from the sign and was therefore curious. :)

In the words of Elder Brother from Indiana Jones, I chose wisely.  In my mind, it's really hard to screw up tapas, but it's equally hard to make them exceptional.  Most places rely on copious amounts of sangria to make the normally satisfactory blend of flavors into something truly special.  But this place succeeded in completely surprising me while I was enjoy a dry evening.

I had the calamari, sauteed mushrooms (don't let them take away this plate before you soak up all the excess sauce), sauteed spinach, flaming goat cheese, and the biggest surprise of all the vegetarian empanadillas (save this for last).  I swear there's so much flavor in this dish that they have to be sneaking meat in there.  Add on a glass of sangria, and you've got the perfect tapas meal.

As one of my friends pointed out, you can tell this place is going to be good simply based off of the number of people in there speaking Spanish.  But the staff really does put in the extra effort to be both attentive and accommodating.  For example, when I was there last Thursday night, they were fine with my friend and I staying past 11 to continue enjoying a great conversation, when they technically closed at 10.

Next time I want tapas, or a comfortable, intimate restaurant, this will be my destination.
author: Miller H.

description:
My husband and I were hankering for some tapas today, and since there is a lack of good tapas in the East Bay, we headed over to the city.  

Alegrias turned out to be a wonderful little find - we've been to Spain twice in the last three years, and thought that the atmosphere and decor were spot on.  The food was very tasty and seasoned quite well.  My favorites were the empanadillas de carne and tortilla de espanola, while my husband absolutely salivated over the jamon serrano.  Their aioli sauce is quite garlicky (which is how I like it!).  Deserts were also yummy, and their crema catalana had a nice orange finish to it.  

We ended our meal with cafe con leche, just like how we ended our meals at the little Seville and Barcelona lunch places.  We'll definitely go again!
author: Valerie V.

description:
Excellent tapas.  My wife and I love going here.  The decor is okay, but I never count this factor into my reviews. It's all about the food, baby!

The menu isn't great in terms of selection, but I'm comparing them to some of my favorite places in Chicago and NYC.  What they do have on their menu is good to great.  Very tasty choices for you tapas lovers in the Bay Area.
author: Bernard M.

description:
Alegrias is a great place to celebrate a birthday.  We went here two years ago and had a wonderful time.  I couldn't believe that we were one of 2 other customers, but it was a Wednesday night and there are TONS of other tapas restaurants in the city.   But none, in my opinion, as good as Alegrias.

Having just dished out tons of quarters in a parking meter---7 minutes for a quarter, are you kidding me?!  I arrived not too happy.  My friends had not yet arrived, but I was shown to our big table.  All the frustration from the past 15 minutes disappeared as I gazed at the decorations on the walls, sipped my glass of Rioja, and relaxed even more from the Spanish music playing...

I can't remember exactly what we ordered---(see suggestions from other reviewers of this place because they all sound familiar) but we were all very satisfied.

It wasn't at all like my awful experience at Cesar on Piedmont.  The dishes were made with a lot of care and the owner from Argentina (her grandmother is from Spain) is a lovely woman.

I would definitely come back here--either for a romantic dinner, with a group, or with guests from out of town.
author: Penny P.

description:
Greatest food I had since I'm in the States (2 years). I haven't tried their Paella yet. Really good sangria too
Their tapas are just "delicieuses". When I'm homesick, it feels good to go there and have authentic spanish cuisine, in an authentic atmosphere. The decoration of this place reminds me of my aunt appartment in Alicante. And the service is also great, waiters are perfect.

For those of you that went to Spain, this place will remind you of this fabulous time. 

I hope you ll have the same experience as me.
author: Meryl C.

description:
I love me some tapas! Alegrias delivers in what we exactly were looking for on a weekend night - a low-key and tasty dining experience. Upon entering, you get this warm and cozy feeling - as if you're entering a friend's house and about to eat a homemade meal. The wait staff was extremely friendly and attentive, which makes for a better experience.

What we ordered - tortillo de chorizo (spanish omelette), gambas al ajillo (prawns sauteed in garlic), patatas bravas (fried potatoes in red sauce),  pinchos morunos (pork loin skewers), and paella a la valenciana con chorizo Espanol. The skewers were a bit dry, but everything else was pretty good. For dessert, we had an apple crepe which might have had too much brandy. But overall, we definitely liked our dinner and are likely to go back again.
author: buggy b.

description:
Have you ever dined at a restaurant that made you feel like you were dining at home...?
The service and atmosphere here is unlike any other.
Very friendly and welcoming staff with great food to match.
You have to love drinking sangria all night and then keeping the restaurant open an hour or so past the last diners =D...

Make a meal out of the tapas, especially the patatas with alioli... and again drink lots of sangria...

enough said...
author: Florio M.

description:
The service was excellent and they refill bread. The stewed rabbit with vegetables I had was very tender and tasty. My cousin and I split the seafood/chicken/chorizo paella - everything in it was really well-cooked and it had a really seafood-y taste. For dessert I had the vanilla ice cream with candied walnuts and sherry poured over it and that was pretty amazing. 

On a  side note: This restaurant looks way nicer on the inside than the outside.
author: Micaela G.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday party, and while I enjoyed the food, it was quite expensive for tapas, so -2 stars.

We had a fixed menu so they kept bringing more food upon more food, but it wasn't the most innovative or inventive, standard fare like spanish ham, olives, mussles, paella, etc.  The quality was good, but the choices weren't too innovative.

I would rather do down-and-dirty tapas in the Mission.
author: Mary M.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco last weekend and my friend suggested this place. I checked it on Yelp and the rating was good so I was all about it.

The vibe is nice...low light, white tablecloth, etc. 

We were a party of 4 so each of us ordered 2 choices of tapas. I can only remember a few of them. The ones I can recommend are the stewed rabbit, crab cakes and calamari rings. All three were excellent! My friends also enjoyed mussels, but I hate those so didn't try them.

Based on my choices and how much my friends enjoyed the other choices, I can definitely recommend this place. The price was pretty good and the service was great. I thought I would have to eat in another few hours, but I was surprised at how full I got from that. I think we paid $25/person(for 2 tapas and soda each)

Next time, I think we'll try the big plates of Paella!
author: scott b.

description: Good food, cute atmosphere, friendly service! I loved the calamari, crab cakes, and goat cheese tapas, and turnovers. Not so cheap, but for tapas i guess that reasonable. Great place for a date. and again, i really loved the food! i'll go again for sure.
author: Mel M.

description: There are many wonderful things about Alegrias, but the BEST is that it's totally authentic.  My boyfriend and I went for our anniversary and ended up reminiscing over the time we spent in Spain the entire night.  I recommend the croquettas and the patatas with alioli.  The sangria is an absolute must.  The empanadillas I could have done without, unfortunately.  But seriously, if you want a romantic getaway but can't actually leave town, definitely head over to Algerias.
author: Nina B.

description: WOW! What an experience. Just around the corner from my house, celebrated a birthday here with my parents who are adventurous eaters. Decided on Alegrias and was not disappointed. From the decor to the food it was delicious and very reasonably priced. Definitely a treat for anyone who grows tired of sushi, salad, sandwiches.
author: Nelson C.

description:
I have to second Jeffrey on this, the 
Spanish ham
Calamari
Potatoes fried in alioli sauce
Paella with chicken, seafood and chorizo

are terrific!

But I may need a few more sangrias to dig into frog legs.
author: Mic D.

description: Great overall experience. Make a reservation on weekends, as the place is small and service isn't fast. Everything we ate was delicious: trio of cheese and meats, beef empanadillas, lobster croquettes, flaming cheese, sangria, flan, and Lavazza coffee. This was plenty of food for 2 people. All in all, a relaxing, slow delicious meal in a busy and fun little restaurant. Will definitely be back soon.
author: Alison S.

description:
Huge fan of this little place on Lombard.  The service was amazing, incredibly attentive and friendly but not overbearing.  Cozy ambiance.  Some of my favorite tapas were the empandillos, crab cakes, and mushrooms.  We got the caramel apple crepe for dessert with ice cream and coated in a rum-based syrup, it came out on fire, who can pass up a flaming dessert!
I have driven by this place a dozen times and am soooooo glad I finally stopped in and tried it.
author: Katie P.

description:
Alegrias is "maravilloso." We love the place so darn much we come once a week..

When you step inside the restaurant, you'll notice a romantic atmosphere.

Family-owned and operated with a delightful, cozy atmosphere. The food is very tasty, with a good selection of tapas. They have more than 20 kinds of tapas!  One of my favorite is the escalivada, which is grilled eggplant, peppers and onions drizzled with olive oil.  Wash it all down with cold sangria poured from stone jugs.  

You know what they say: Vamos.
author: Nestle L.

description:
Went for a belated birthday celebration on a Sunday and were the first to arrive around 6 p.m. (they open at 5:30---something impossible in Spain were you start around 11:00 p.m. with dinner!).

Very friendly family-run place, the husband cooks, the son is one of the waiting stuff, and the mother runs the place.

We started with a pitcher of Sangria (who can only drink one glass anyway?) while I tried the Sauvignon Blanc by the glass which was delightfully refreshing.

The olive oil on each table tastes so good that I ate three pieces of (the rather bland white) bread soaked even before the food came.

We started with Green Olives and Calamari. I usually prefer the black olives, but these were yummy. The Calamari were in a light batter and came with a pink Aioli. We added a bit of salt and they were very nice.

Then we had the Hot Goats Cheese on Tomato sauce (the size of a pack of cigarettes), succulent! We continued with a pot of Clams and Snails in a thick (Saffran?) sauce, very tasty and mouthwateringly spiced. Finally, the Stuffed Pepper with Lamb, coming in a winey-creamy sauce that was devine. These three small pieces were gone in a min...

And the crown: Crema Catalana! The best I've had (and I had it in Barcelona!) with a hint of orange, cream, custard and a generous caramel layer on top. I almost licked out the bowl...

With tip, the whole evening went for a well-spent $94 which left us two totally satisfied.

Very attentive service; the decor is a tad overloaded for my taste, but this is a perfect family restaurant that takes pride in what they do.

I will recommend Alegrias whole-heartedly to all my friends! I will be a regular...
author: Wolfgang S.

description:
Found this place on yelp when organizing a catch up session with friends I made on an overseas vacation a year ago.  I wasn't sure if people would show up on time (everyone was commuting from the east or south bay during rush hour, and parking is a bitch in the marina), so I thought tapas would be a good idea since we could get started even if someone was running late. 

Great sangria, and the majority of tapas were very tasty.  Its kind of a quiet place with half the tables empty, so I'm sure our lively group was considered loud to others.
author: Ali G.

description:
This is yummy *authentic* comida espanola at this little family-run establishment.  Good wine selection.  Decor made me feel like I was in Spain again.  Tapas were all great.  I highly recommend the cheese and chorizo sampler plate, pork skewers and tortilla de patata.  Service was fantastic.  We realized we over-ordered when we were groaning from food and still had one tapa yet to arrive (patatas bravas).  Not only did the waiter say, "no problem" when we asked if we could remove it, but he insisted to bring the sauce so we could still enjoy the flavor with the potatoes that came with the pork skewers.  Very impressive and refreshing to see such genuine pleasure and pride in the food that they serve.

My one wish - that they would add albondigas con tomate to the tapas menu.  If everyone who goes there asks, maybe they will!  C'mon yelpers, unite!
author: Dani B.

description:
After having spent 5 weeks in Madrid, Alegrias is the one restaurant I've found in SF that replicates the dining experience of that time.

Even though my wife and I have moved all the way to the other side of the city, we still make the 20-25 minute drive to Alegrias 4-5 times a year.
author: John R.

description: I've been here several times. Service is always attentive with an old world charm about it. Food can be inconsistent at times, but it's never not good. The seafood components to dishes are usually really well executed. It's our favorite relax sort of date place.
author: Jeannie G.

description:
Came here last night for dinner, ambiance was nice, I believe the restaurant was divided into two smaller rooms which made it feel really cozy. We had reservations for two and got seated right away. They served us some french bread when we sat down, I thought the bread was a bit tough and tasted almost stale...but didn't really care to eat too much of it because I wanted to save my stomach for the main dishes!! =) From the Hot Topas menu we tried the Empanadillas de Carne (Spanish style turnovers stuffed with beef, green onions, olives, raisins, and herbs) which was really REALLY good, came out perfect...nice and warm, crispy outside, when I first poked my fork into it to break it open the aroma smelled so delicious!!! The texture was really good you can see and taste the beef and it was nice and juicy but not to the point where it was drippy. It was SOOoooo GOOOD!! We also had the Tabla de Quesos y Chorizos Españoles (Assortment of cheese and cured sausage imported from Spain) from the Cold Topas menu. I am not a cheese connoisseur, but I love cheese. We had a variety of sheep, goat, and cow cheese. They were all pretty good, but my favorite was the sheep cheese can't really describe why, but it was yummier. Each came in two pretty big slices for each flavor. Would have probably tasted even better if paired with some wine. It also came with some cold Chorizos which was a bit salty for my taste but still pretty tasty. And for our main dishes we had the Chuletillas de Cordero con Patatas a lo Pobre (Grilled lamb chops with poor man potatoes and vegetables) & the Paella a la Valenciana con Chorizo Español (Classic saffron flavored Spanish rice with chicken and seafood and imported Spanish chorizo). The lamb chops were really yummy!! They made it so that it was lightly crispy on the outer edges (not crispy burnt but yummy crispy!). The seasoning was perfect, not overly seasoned so you could still taste the yummy meat. Wanted to pick up the lamb chop bones and start chewing on the meat that was still stuck on there...but didn't want to look rude, hehehe. But it was definitely finger licking good! The veggies were also just as good, loved the green beans... and the potatoes were delicious, nicely seasoned and was very smooth. I didn't know Poor man potatoes can be so good! The Paella came out last (they warned us that it was going to take 20-30mins), but we were still working on our lamb chops when it came out so it was right on-time. This tasted like a seafood pasta except with rice. It had lots of seafood: mussels, clams, shrimps, calamari...with a few pieces of white chicken meat and the sausages. The white chicken meat was a bit dry...over all the dish was ok. I'm not a big fan of pasta...nothing too spectacular about this dish. 
Pros: Good Service, food came out pretty quick, nice ambiance (but we were sitting next to a pretty big crowd and it got a bit too noisy).
Cons: No parking (but you're in SF so...good luck), bread tasted stale...not a big deal but I love bread so it would have been nice if it was better.

Tips: Order wine with your food. =)

Gave 4 stars because I would definitely come back for the Empanadillas de Carne & lamb chops!! Might want to come back to try all the other Topas too!!
author: Amy L.

description:
This place is wonderful.  The waiters are all very friendly and helpful.  

I went with my boyfriend and a friend, all of us love to eat.  We only ordered tapas, about 12 plates, all of which were delicious.  The two pitchers of sangria went down quite smooth!

If you're looking for tapas and sangria this place is prefect.  One thing that  really makes this place stand; as soon as you finish your bread they offer to bring more, so you can soak up all the yummy sauces.  EVERY time the bread runs out!  I practically have to fight the waiters at Cha Cha Cha to get more than one serving of bread!
author: Paige B.

description: I am so happy I stumbled upon this restaurant while looking for a bite to eat with some friends. We ended up ordering a bunch of tapas and a couple pitchers of sangria to share. Everything we got was delicious, I especially loved the baked goat cheese. 8 different tapas for 4 hungry people was plenty of food and not too expensive. I've had a hard time finding a tapas restaurant that resembles those in Spain, but Alegias definitely hit the spot.
author: Linnea B.

description: A friend suggested we have dinner at Alegrias, so this evening we did just that, we were lucky with the parking. We had the Halibut, it was very tasty, and the menu was great, would have liked to have quite a few of the things, will certainly make this a "must do again" place to eat, like the cosy atmosphere.  We were there early so had no problem getting a table, but it soon filled up.
author: Scraggy W.

description: Everything is good here. Service was great. Nice, romantic setting with white table cloths and tons of choices for you to choose from.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Having lived in Spain, I get my cravings for Spanish tapas.  Not "small plates" that can be found at many trendy places around the city, but authentic, delicious, I feel like Im back in Madrid tapas.  

Alegrias is the one place I recommend, hands down, for Spanish food.  Ive tried many places in the city, and while good, they cannot match the food and unexpectedly quaint, comforting atmosphere that is Alegrias.

If you know, love and appreciate Spanish food, you will love Alegrias, os prometo!
author: Kristin K.

description:
I love tapas and I had been meaning to check this place out for some time. It was just two of us, so I didn't get to experiment with a wide variety of tapas, but the three or four we had were pretty good. The empanadillas were great, and their cold tapas were creative and reasonably good. In addition, Alegrias has some of the best Paella I've ever had. Great combination of flavors and very moist rice. This is probably the biggest reason I would go back. 

The prices were pretty reasonable, especially for the neighborhood, but you could easily rack it up fast with the tapas which are maybe a bit minimal for their price. 

The service was also quite good, with a very friendly waiter, and attentive staff. As someone else mentioned, the decor is somewhat "homey" and not very modern, but I found it to be pretty comfortable.
author: Jon W.

description:
Dined with group of Eight, 
Excellent wines selected, 
Potatoes Bravas!
author: Brian J.

description:
It's very small, but cute.  Inside is decorated with a very traditional spanish decor.  

The Jamon Serrano was very tasty.  Salty and flavorful...I liked eating it with a little bit of the bread they give.  

The manchego cheese I've had twice.  It comes out flaming and is a nice presentation.  The first time was very good and tasted lovely.  It was slightly chewy, yet warm and melted...The second time, it had way too much brandy or whatever liquor they poured in...because that was all I could taste...and it was disgusting.  

The potatoes are yummy!  They're diced up, sauteed, and seasoned...and I think it has a sauce.  They're perfectly cooked and tasted yummy.  

The shrimp dish called..gambas...something.  The shrimp was overcooked and dry.  The sauce it came in was a bit too salty.  Not a fan of this dish.  

The Sangria was yummy.  It was sweet but tart at the same time.  Also tried Madiera...it was a dessert wine I believe.  It was a little too thick for me..and a little too strong in taste.  

Overall...cute and casual place for dinner date.  Staff is kind of a hit and miss.  My first time, they were very helpful and kind...second time, my waiter was very opposite of helpful/kind.
author: Jenny K.

description: I truly enjoy the foods here.  We ordered several little plates and the Paella (seafood, chicken and chorizo) for entree.  The paella was very delicious.  The other small plates were croquetas, sauteed prawns, mushroom, snails & manila clams in red sauce, crispy potatoes, manchego cheese flambe.  All of these small plates were great.  The only plate that fell short was the sauteed prawns which I think was kind of bland and the sauce was bit too thin and no flavor.  But overall both my boyfriend and I really enjoyed the place.  Cute casual small restaurant with spanish decor.  We would definitely come back to try out the other plates on the menu.
author: elle n.

description: Very good food. Eveyone else eating there was Spanish so I'm guessing the cuisine is pretty authentic. Nice atmosphere too.
author: Co W.

description:
I've been to Alegrias 4 or 5 times, and I really enjoy this place. The atmosphere is cozy, and has a family feel to it, as does the service. The paella is delicious, sangria is very good, tapas are tasty.

I've usually come here with groups of several people and we've always had a festive time with great food.
author: Paddy P.

description:
I recently came to Alegrias with a group of friends and walked out feeling like I had discovered a neighborhood gem. 

THE GOOD 
- Nice ambiance. Super cute for a girls night out and flattering lighting for date night. 
- Espanadillas de Carne 
- Croquetas del dia 
- Mejillones Alegrias 
- Patatas Alioli 
- Cazuela de Queso de Cabra -- AHHHMAZING!!!! We kissed our no carb diet goodbye and dipped tons of bread into this oven baked goat cheese goodness and didn't regret a single savoring moment of it. I highly recommend it! 

THE BAD 
- Paella: Maybe its because we got the no seafood paella option that came with chicken and chorizo, but it wasn't very good 
- Sangria: At $5/glass its reasonably priced, but bland 
- Apple flambe: Was SUPER excited to try this for dessert (esp because I had seen pictures of it on Yelp that had made my mouth water), but it looked much better than it tasted. It was just too sweet. I didn't finish my dessert, which is something that never happens. 
- I was also a bit disappointed that my glass of water was not refilled. 

Overall, I would recommend this cute Spanish restaurant with outstanding, reasonably priced tapas.
author: Sara K.

description:
yum sangria, Manchego Flambeado was amazing (came out flaming as the name implies), chicken and chorizo paella, Empanadillas Vegetarianas (olives gave it such a unique taste we ended up getting 2 more orders), prosciutto, octopus -- nothing disappointed even the octopus which i was a bit skeptical of.
