grp of 5 went and it was perfect for sharing!  Although it's no Zarzuelas it's good.  we actually ended up here because the japanese place down the street was too busy but were perfectly happy and full at the end of the meal!
author: Emm C.

description:
My friend decided to come here and it's funny because when we first saw this restaurant from the outside, I was judging it by it's appearance, which  looked like total crap so we almost decide to leave. But, you know don't judge a book by it's cover.

So we decided to go in and the setting was really nice; I would highly recommend this place for a date. Eatting here casually is fine too, the food was good and the price was reasonable.
author: Pudgy G.

description:
I've been wanting to go here since I returned from Spain 2 years ago.  I just made it the other day.  Parking was much easier than I expected.  You have to keep an eye for the yellow sign as sit is sandwiched in with other retail signage.

It was as authentic as anything I had in Spain.  The service was warm and friendly.  Although I did not ask for recommendations, they seem willing and pleased to make them.  

The prices were average and with any Tapas heavy menu, it is better to go with several people so you can try many different dishes.  On this outing I had the snails and clams in a mildly spicy red sauce.  It was excellent. The portion was fair for the price.  The snails and clams were delicious and the sauce had the very complex layered taste as if it had been cooking for days.  I also had sauted spinach with chopped apples, pinenuts and raisins.  I think it was in a light cider dressing.  Yummy and healthy, it doesn't get better than that!  The Empanadas are as good as you could find anywhere.  Go.
author: j g.

description: The food was amazing and the staff was warm, helpful and the entire experience was lovely!
author: Justine C.

description:
Spanish food is one of the things that I miss from my time in both Philippines and Europe - when I was a kid in Asia, my father and grandparents would take us out on Sundays nights for gatherings at Old Manila for croquetas, lengua (ox tongue), and sopas mariscos - and sometimes, when we're lucky and not stuffed from the food, we'd get a big wok of paella negra, which is regular seafood paella coated with squid ink.

While it does not have certain select dishes that I crave on its menu, Alegrias comes close to capturing both the atmosphere and the flavor that I remember from those times. The service is both kind and attentive - I remember calling up twice and asking for reservations to which they politely complied to, as well as our waiters being very personable during our meals.

The décor of the restaurant romanticizes the experience, or at least gives a solid enough a backdrop for my nostalgia--it's ideal for a mellow romantic date, and even if the person you're out with decides that they want to eat at the (admittedly inexpensive) Chinese restaurant in Chinatown immediately after, you'll still come out smiling.

I'm not particularly versed with their selection of wines, but their Sangria is tasty (unfortunately I haven't been there in a while so I cannot comment on this further). The one drawback that I find from the entire experience is the price relative to how much food you get. Don't get me wrong: the food is great, but you don't get as much as you would hope to in other restaurants. Appetizers are normally around $7.00 to $9.00, and the main dishes go to about $20 per plate. I'm not saying it's not worth it: I'm just saying that it's not wise to go here and expect it to be a cheap hangout (but maybe that's because I'm a student, I don't know). My suggestion is to sample as much of their tapas as you can, and order one paella dish (Paella a la Valenciana con Chorizo Español) if you want variety in your meals.

If you do decide to go to Alegrias, you'll find the experience to be pleasant. I would recommend trying the following:
1. Patatas Alioli - it's basically fried potatos bits drizzled in Alioli, but it's still very good. 
2. Cazuela de Caracoles y Almejas -  Snails and Manila clams stewed in red sauce
3. Pimientos del Piquillo Rellenos con Cordero - it's like an Indian samosa with pimiento peppers as the wrap; succulent and one of the few dishes that I find well worth its price.
4. Croquetas del dia - one time it was ham; the other time it was chicken. Both were great.
5. Tabla de Quesos y Chorizos Españoles - it's basically a sampling of cheese and sausage from Spain. Take it with wine.
6. Paella a la Valenciana con Chorizo Español - this is, I think, my favorite paella out of the four available. It has both seafood and chicken as well as chorizos (a personal favorite).
author: Juan d.

description: Such an perfect experience - croquetas taste authentic, paella was perfect (more than enough for two), the sangria was delicious, and good ambiance... also very reasonably priced.
author: Arthur A.

description: Thoroughly mediocre. I loved the people, truly. The anchovies were nice. The paella was so over done it was just sad. I don't think I would ever go back.
author: Bob R.

description: Alegrias is a great place, excellent food, a warm, cozy atmosphere, and it is not too loud.  The calamari is amazing --  I sometime daydream of eating the perfect calamrari, and most restaurants butcher it completely.  For years I thought I was completely over calamari.... But then along came Alegrias.  Their calamari is light, crispy, tender, and goes so well with a glass of sangria.  You will enjoy this place.
author: Emily B.

description: Tried both Zarzuela and Alegria in separate occasions.  The classic Gamba al Ajillo and Paellas never fails me, and I prefer Alegria much better. Empanadas a must.
author: HW H.

description: Had the paella....great stuff! The staff was very friendly as well. Highly recommended!
author: Tony M.

description: Actually 3 1/2.  The food was good but did not wow.  The paella should have been better.  The clams and mussels were overcooked and not the freshest.  The croquettes were very good.  The special dessert, chocolate with almond brittle was good. The food came out very quickly. The service was just okay.  Our server was a bit aloof.
author: george k.

description: Our first time at Alegrias.  Excellent food and service.  The Gonzalez family are warm, caring and very hospitable making their guests feel welcome.  Fantastic food - vry authentic - we had several tapas and the seafood/chicken/chorizo paella, good wine, excellent  ambiance and decor (sit at the back room), great service. We chatted quite a bit with Cesar and his son Laurgano about the food and Spain. We will be back again soon.
author: M V.

description: Nice atmosphere inside, but I was not too impressed by the tapas. They were not bad but they didn't stand out either.
author: Kem K.

description: Two things that make me return to a spanish restaurant: Sangria, and Paella. Both of them are fantastic at Alegrias! We also got the Mangego Flameado, the Tortilla a la Espanola, and the Gambas al Ajillo, all very good. The third thing that will persuade me back is the price. It's extremely reasonable.
author: Daffodil K.

description:
Nice food and nice service!
I and my husband had dinner last night, and we had a good time. I love sangria, and it was very good and nice size decanter.
We ordered garlic prawns, potatoes in red sauce, and paella with seafood, and those were very good. We also had creme brule, and it was good, too. Excellent service, as well. The wait staff was friendly and knowledgeable. Recommended!
author: Super S.

description:
This place nearly ruined my only night off. 
First off it just looks dirty.  Pulling up to the place is in the sort of location that makes you think it's just one of those conveniences for tourists staying in local hotels.  After walking into the restaurant I saw the outside definitely reflected the inside.  The pictures were a poor representation of what this place actually looked like.  The chairs were these old metal cushioned chairs you would find in a hotel banquet hall in the 70's but don't worry... they were covered by pieces of fabric probably ripped right off of your great grandmothers couches.  They were all old and torn and falling apart.  
The menu was wrinkled and torn in places and reminded me of one of those places you take your kids because you don't care what the atmosphere is as long as they get fed and the menu was incredibly limited to a majority of fried foods.  The crab cakes were generic and cold in the center... the croquettes were crab cakes shaped like cheese sticks... the bread was cold and beginning to harden from age... the potatoes they had were just tiny french fries covered in some sort of sauce and the spinach dish was basically just a handful of overcooked spinach covered in garlic because they garlic is all you could taste.  The sangria tasted horribly watered down and there were so many orange peels in the glass then covered with ice there wasn't much room left for this poor excuse of sangria.
At the end of the meal I felt like I was being held hostage.  I was already thoroughly embarrassed because I was trying to take my girlfriend on a nice date that we don't get to have too many of and I ended up taking her to this Mcdonalds version of Tapas.  I had to ask for the check 4 times within 5 minutes of each other as they just kept asking me if I wanted more food.  Finally I just gave them my credit card without getting a check in hopes that they would just come back with a receipt instead of asking me again if I would like anything else.  
Luckily my girlfriend is this wonderful woman and we recovered the night from this horrific experience.  I don't know how this place has so many glowing reviews. 
Over all Alegrias is dirty, terrible atmosphere, limited menu, terrible food, ridiculous service, and a location that just makes you cringe.  Save your money go to in and out... it's classier.
author: Chesh K.

description: Fun restaurant, family style, did well with our group of 7. Flaming cheese was fun and yummy, all desserts were excellent.
author: Christina N.

description: One of the best choices for Spanish/ Tapas in SF.  Great food with very reasonable prices.  Warm and romatic setting which was great for a date even though the place is group friendly also.  Welcoming and attentive staff.
author: Duke K.

description: Went with a biiig group, options werent great; they didnt tell us there was a special menu when we made the reservation either. Food was good. Sangria was better. Felt way too pricey for the quality. Might have been better for a smaller group. Good service tho.
author: Jaymes H.

description:
Alegrias is very tasty and very authentic tapas.  I felt like I was in Spain - and the spaniards I brought with me loved it too!  For a detailed description of the dishes I had, check out my review here:
http://lawyereats.blogspot.com/2007/07/alegrias-food-from-spain.html

If you are looking for a real spanish tapas experience, this is the place to go in SF!  Also great for kids - we had a baby with us and they were very accommodating.
author: LawyerEats S.

description:
A really lovely little unassuming restaurant on Lombard with very kind service and good Spanish food. My husband and I attended a birthday party there and sampled lots of tasty plates, but my favorites were the tortilla, chorizo, and gambas. I'm not a big red wine drinker, but the sangria tastes great and is made carefully. Ooh, and they have their own house olive oil that is seriously delicious (cold-pressed, and extra virgin) - it tastes a bit garlicky but is straight up olive oil. I'll be back for that alone.

The service here was charming - just enough attention so that you feel cared for, but not so much that you're smothered. It does feel a bit like being back in Spain....
author: Sarah G.

description:
I went to Alagrias for a friend's birthday.  We had reservations.  However, many guests, including me, came later than expected.  Still, the staff was very tolerant of people showing up late etc.
 I also appreciated the fixed menu since we had nearly 20 people in our group. Notably, it made settling the bill at the end of the night easier.  
The only drawback was the bill. We were quite blown away by the price per person - a little over $70, when the meal cost $36 per person.  The amount of Sangria and bottled water many of us drank made the bill much higher than expected.  Overall, it was more good than bad - food was great and the waiters kept our glasses full. If you go, you will like it!  Just be aware that the drink costs easily add up.
author: Kristen F.

description: We had a delightful Valentine's Day dinner here. They had prompt service despite being super busy and full of tables for two. The fixed menu was $40 and included salad, tapas appetizer, entree and dessert. Everything we had was tasty, tasteful and reminiscent of a Andalucian restaurante. Gambas al ajillo were great, lamb chops were perfectly done and the Mariscos Zarzuela had plenty of seafood and a tomato garlic sauce that was perfect for dipping bread into. Oh yeah, and light and fluffy Creme de Catalan (like a creme brulee but with hints of vanilla) for dessert. MMMMMmmmm! Couldn't have planned a better night. Sangria and Malbec was delightful too!
author: Julie D.

description: I came here for my friend's birthday. I love their Sungria. This is probably the best Sungria that I have tried so far. The service was good and the food was also tasty  with reasonable price. I will definitely come back here again for their Sungria. The flan was too sweet and mussel was ok. However, this is a cute place to drink.
author: Jenny C.

description: Dining at Alegrias was a great suggestion from Yelp! I needed a mix of vegetarian plates and meat plates for my parents and my b/f's parents to eat. Alegrias offered many assortment of dishes and the ones we had were delicious.
author: Patricia H.

description: An amazing restaurant.  My girlfriend and I ate here for our 6 month anniversary while on vacation in San Francisco.  We split the crabcakes and cold olives tapas, a generous pan of paella with seafood, chicken and sausage, and a wonderful pitcher of homemade sangria.  Quaint and romantic.  Great service...not too intrusive.  We will definitely be back next time we are in San Francisco.
author: Steven G.

description: The food was tasty and servers were attentive.  Nice decor with dim lighting, great spot to take a date.
author: Heidi F.

description: My godchildren took me to Alegrías last night for my 78th birthday. It was the best birthday dinner in my almost 50 years in the US; and I do know Spanish food!. The Croquetas de Camarones were excellent, the Empanadillas de Carne were almost as good and the Paella reminded me of the one at my favorite restaurant in Madrid. We had two fantastic desserts, a Crema Catalana and a Budín de Pan w/ vanilla ice cream. It was my best birthday in memory! The service was outstanding too.
author: Carlos F.

description:
SOOOO GOOD!

I wish I had them closer! I could eat their every day!
Empanadas... Yummy!
Panqueques de dulce de leche... You HAVE to have them!

Love IT!
author: Daniela D.

description: Great food and great service.  The ambiance was a little odd when we first walked in because there weren't many people there (despite being 8pm on a Friday) and there wasn't any music playing -- so it was just one of those places that was too quiet.  But, it actually livened up and didn't seem that way at all through the meal.  The food was great and the service was great, i would go back.
author: Jeff C.

description: I went to Alegrias for the first time a few weeks ago.  Quaint yet unpretentious.  The tapas themselves were out of this world. The Sauteed Spinach was to die for.  And of course, being a vegetarian and a potato-addict, I always try the Potato Omelet (Tortilla a la Espanola) at every tapas joint.  Simply orgasmic.  I don't know why it took me so long to become a patron.  Umm... maybe coz it's not located in the Mission.  Boy, I've got to branch out more ... definitely going back!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
was just aight.  probably wouldnt recommend it, but wouldnt tell people not to go...

went there for the paella.  was just ok.  the seafood was grossly overcooked and dry.  you can get a nice paella with juicy seafood in it, so i was pretty disappointed.

the spinach/pine nuts/raisins etc was good.  the croquette was aight.  pass on the shrimps, overcooked again.

their creme brulee (spanish version of it) was tasty.

2.5 stars, but going with 2.
author: Junglist S.

description:
Went there for my birthday.  Had 4 different Tapas and Chicken and Seafood Paella...

Everything was delicious, great service..reasonable prices...in my opinion, better than Esperpento and Zarzuela...
author: Atif Y.

description:
I have to say that this is one of may favorite restaurants in the city.  That says a lot - there must be 1,000 great restaurants in San Francisco.  The price is decent, they can accommodate big parties with only a few days notice, and they have an unbelievable wine list.  I may be a little biased because I tend not to like to commit to one meal - so the tapas idea works well for me.  It's like a sushi - I get a little taste of everything.  Tapas I would recommend:
-Aceitunas Aliñadas (assorted marinated olives)
-Bocadillos de Cangrejo (Crab cakes served with a mild creamy jalapeño sauce)
- Tortilla a la Española (potato and caramelized onion omelette)
-Gambas al Ajillo (Prawns sauteed with garlic, parsley and white Rioja wine)
-Mejillones Alegrias (Steamed mussels in a white Rioja wine, garlic, and parsley sauce)
-Manchego Flambeado (Spanish Manchego cheese flambe' with brandy)
* Setas al Ajillo (Mushrooms sauteed in garlic and white Rioja wine)
* Patatas Bravas (Crisp fried potatoes with a spicy red sauce)
* Patatas Alioli (Crisp fried potatoes tossed with a traditional aioli sauce)

Also, the service is quick, and because it's on Lombard parking is not as tough as other parts of the city.  There is a parking garage 2 blocks away.
author: Anne Marie F.

description:
i came here for my birthday party last month and while I wish I could remember every single detail of the dinner I had...I can't. Because frankly I was much too busy pounding down glasses of Sangria to remember the food. 

However I do remember a couple of things:

1. The food was quite good. It was a prix fix menu for the group and I'm assuming they choose the better dishes on their menu. I do remember liking a majority of the food and everyone being in agreement with me.  I also remember the paella just being so-so. But that doesn't concern me too much since MOST restaurants don't do this dish well. But quite honestly the food was homestyle and authentic. All the  dishes complement each other and the food comes out quick! They just keep bringing the dishes out one after another after another. 

2. The sangria was not very strong. Which is probably why were drinking them out of wine glasses like they were shots and why it's so cheap. But it's not so cheap when you keep drinking more..and more...and more...

At  the end of the night the bill was roughly $60/person. That's with drinking lots of sangria. Considering everyone was stuffed and happy, I'd say that's a pretty good deal! I'd definitely come out here again - it's great for groups and even for just two, since they have so wisely separated the loud and obnoxious groups (my group included) from those who prefer to have a "romantic" meal. Parking is great as well - there's a parking garage right across the street. This place is a MUST try!
author: Ceana K.

description: Loved the atmosphere.  I felt less stressed as soon as I walked through the door.  Tried and enjoyed most of the vegetarian items on the menu and there's a lot ot choose from.  Service was excellent. Try the panqueque de manzanas: a thick crepe with apples, ice cream and brandy, flambéd
author: Nina C.

description: Our first thought was to go to Cha Cha Cha's but I wanted an alternative to that over rated restaurant and found it with Alegrias. Spanish style food served via tapa style. Immediately walking into the place we were touched by a romantic atmosphere. We were seated in our own "private" little table. Our conversation was delightful which made better with all our mouth watering food. The service was excellent but the food was even better. You must try the Tortilla Espanola and of course the Paella. You won't be sorry it was a nice treat and very romantic. Overall... DELICIOSO!!! Thanks for reading, Silvia
author: Silvia S.

description: Great Spanish restaurant!  The food tastes just like the food the folks used to make.  Recommend sharing a paella (plenty for two) and if you're hungry, enjoy tapas and dessert.  Nice setting and friendly service.
author: Brenda P.

description: I must be hanging out with the right people because I've been taken to some awesome restaurants in town and this one is among them.  Great food, the service was excellent and the ambience is really quaint.  I love Spain and Spanish food so this place made me very happy.  The tapas was awesome, my favorites were the spinach and pork loin.  The sangria is a bit on the sweet side but still good and the desserts were heavenly.  We each got something and shared.  After all was said and done, for six people, several tapas plates,  with sangria, coffee and desserts, our bill came out to $25 a person with tip.  That was amazing.  We thought the waiter made a mistake but nope, that was our bill.  Definitely going back.
author: Magdalena ..

description: Good tapas.  Quaint and charming atmosphere.  Very nice and reasonable wine list.  Paella is very good.  I was initially concerned that it was a little too quiet for our group of six, but either the wine quickly made me forget to notice we were causing a ruckus or the place picked up a bit.  A very nice find.
author: David T.

description:
the service was awesome.  the waitor even went in the back to look something up for us on the computer as both my girlfriend and i had forgotten our iphones and blackberries.

the tapas were great.  there are so many options it was hard to choose.  the four we got were delicious, so i wonder how the others are.  we'll be back again!

ps - the sangria is good...not too sweet.  it's also very quiet and dark - perfect for a romantic evening.
author: Hammer Time H.

description: Great food, nice, friendly ambience. We tried several items on the menu and the server helped us pair the food with some great wine. More veggie-friendly than most tapas places (i.e. you can get more than patatas bravas)
author: Shweta V.

description: I've had the pleasure of eating at Alegrias many times over the course of the last few years (yes, I discovered this gem prior to my move here) and each experience has been absolutely delightful.  While, it has a prime Lombard Street location in the heart of the Marina, I can't see it being overly popular with the neighborhood demographic because it's completely unpretnentious and cozy and makes you feel like you are eating in one of your best friend's mom's kitchen.  They have a very diverse tapas menu, and the flambe is amazing!  3-4 tapas should be more than sufficient for a table of 2, and you will be stuffed.  The sangria is the beverage of choice here ad is not to be missed.  Alegrias offers up just what the Marina needs; hearty food with reasonable prices in a very cozy setting.
author: Amy Z.

description: Went here for my birthday, group of 6.  Food was really and service was really good.  I also liked the ambiance.
author: WinnJess E.

description:
Dinner for 4, last night.
Great Tapas... refreshing and not-too-sweet sangria...tasty paella (wonderful flavor with bountiful seafood, but missing that yummy crust - hence 4 instead of 5 stars)...delicious desserts...wonderful waiter...homey ambiance (quiet enough that you can talk/hear one another)...AND... best of all - a bill at the end that won't break the bank!

We will be back...
author: Susan A.

description:
Oh man, this place was delicious. Soooo good. 
We came to have dinner to this little gem of a restaurant for my husband's 30th bday. It was absolutely delicious. 
We had a group of 10 people some rowdier than others. We were also probably a little late. But no matter, they gave us the large table in the back room which they had prepared for us. One of the waiters, I don't remember his name, was incredibly attentive. No snootiness, just friendly service. He was also able to recommend some very good wines.
About the food, we each ordered 2 tapas and shared. It worked out quite nicely because everything on the menu sounded so good I really wanted to try as much as I could. And I did. I was pretty full when I agreed to dessert. And I don't regret it. I don't know what was better, the flaming cheese plate (they set it on fire before they set it on your table) or the flaming dessert caramel thing (also on fire.)

Only draw back: it's the marina and it was hard to find a decent bar for after dinner drinks.
author: Carla P.

description: I love this place! The inside of this restaurant is nice and quaint. While I was in Spain, a profesor once told me that the best paella you can have is one that is home cooked. The paella valenciana at Alegrias is the closest thing that I can compare to the best paella I have tried in Barcelona. The rice was just right and the mixture of the flavors from the meats and seafood was amazing. We also tried one of their special tapas, the tortilla espanola con chorizo and it was simply DELICIOUS! I highly recommend this place and will definitley be back for a repeat visit!
author: aimee a.

description: This charming, family-run Spanish restaurant is fantastic.  It's never too crowded even on a Saturday night. The sangria is so yummy and the food is delicious!! It's my favorite tapas restaurant in SF.
author: Lisa F.

description: Boring Place, Boring food.  Went there with my partner and two friends.  The cheese plate was good, the chorizo tortilla tasted like nothing, the gambas with garlic were tasteless and overcooked, and the beef empandillas were drab and greasy.  Probably the worst Spanish food I've ever had.  Ceasar's in Berkeley and Barlata in Oakland are much better.  The decor inside is unimaginative and boring.
author: Rod S.

description: To me the marina might as well be a leper colony: i just don't go there.  Even with the threat of lepersy i have a hard time turning down sangria and tapas.  The sangria was delicious, so delicious i don't remember anything about the food.
author: kate l.

description:
thanks fellow yelpers for helping me find this place.  i'd hate to repeat all of the good stuff people have already said, so i'll just talk about what we ordered...

- Tabla de Quesos y Chorizos Espanoles (assortment of cheese & cured sausage)
- Bocadillos de Cangrejo (crab cakes)
- Patatas Alioli (potatoes with an aioli sauce)
- Chuleton en Salsa de Cabrales (Rib-eye steak grilled over an open flame with Cabrales blue cheese sauce)

all the food tasted great.  the steak was cooked perfectly to order.  if there were a downside, it would be that my glass of sangria was a bit small.  otherwise, alegrias has a new fan.
author: dan a.

description: I was sooo disappointed that we had our anniversary dinner here.  I expected it to be booming and even anticipated having to wait to get in, but instead it was so quiet in the middle dining room by the bar--everyone was put here, I think 3 tables had diners--that the sound of dishes and glasses clattering at the bar was unnerving.  We ordered garlic shrimp, a favorite of ours, and it was tasteless.  It did have garlic in it, but we couldn't taste it.  The little red peppers stuffed with lamb were also tasteless and half-cold to boot.  And the patatas with aioli were the oddest I've ever had--tiny little squares, homefries basically, that were tossed with the sauce (I guess so no need to dip.)  The sangria was also disappointing; I didn't even finish it.  I did feel they kept trying to get us to order more, but my instincts from the beginning were to try a few dishes and then order more if we liked them.  We didn't like them, so we left with a light bill and a lot of disappointment.  In fact, it was so bad that we decided to go out again the next night and make THAT our anniversary dinner.  Also, though the walls are decorated in a charming manner, the chair covers seem tired and nothing is going to fix that limp atmosphere.
author: Carole M.

description: I came here with a group of friends for my Birthday dinner celebration. We had 8 people in our party and they were really accommodating. My bestie made the reservation and I highly recommend that reservations are made because this place is pretty small. We opted to do the prix fix menu and man was there a ton of food. There were so many different tapas plates that kept coming out, I was overwhelmed and excited. Everything was REALLY good. My favorite was their garlic potatoes...so delish. And their paella was good too. Since we had 8 people, they brought 2 of each tapas plate so that everyone could have some. Also, with the paella, since one of our guests doesn't eat meat, they offered to make one paella with everything and another paella with just seafood, which was really nice. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone who wants Spanish cuisine...it's good for large parties and also good for a date night.
author: Leah A.

description: Had a fabulous time and the food was incredible!   The paella and mushroom tapas was delicious!  We had sangria and desserts....everything was great!  Service was excellent and even though we were late, they accommodated us with grace.....Thank you for a wonder evening.....the birthday girl was very impressed!
author: Lisa J.

description: You wouldn't even know that you are in the Marina once you step foot into this place. Alegrias has a very authetic and quaint Spanish feel, and the food is right on. I lived in Spain for 5 months, and I was transported back to the bars of La Juderia, Cordoba.
author: Misha F.

description:
kind of like a quieter, more mature, less caribbean, pricier cha cha cha with MUCH better food.

the wine list seemed very expensive, so we chose the sangria.  (can you really go wrong with wine & fruit?)

we opted for a few hot tapas items :

tortilla a la espanola (classic spanish potato and caramelized onion omelete), gambas al ajillo (prawns sauteed with garlic, parsley and wine), manchego flambeado (spanish manchego cheese flambe' with brandy), patatas bravas con alioli (crisp potatoes with aioli sauce).

all dishes we had were stellar.  not one bad choice.

we'll definitely return if near the area ... and paella next time, i think ... 

would have given 5 stars but prices seemed a touch too much.
author: Noah C.

description: I enjoyed myself on Friday night! 10 of us came in for a friends birthday and everything was great! We opted to try the prefixed menu which allowed us all to try the main things on the menu. We also added a few paella's (sp??) to our order. We had TONS of food and the service was great. The Sangria was tasty, and a decent wine list, with reasonable prices. All and all a great experience. The didn't spend money on Decor, which is fine by me...everyone in there was just having a good time and enjoying themselves! I highly recommend it, oh and it doesn't break the bank. I left pleasantly full and a perfect drunk :)
author: Lisa K.

description: The place is eh.  It seems kind of pricy for what it is. The food was a little bland for my liking. I had the frog legs and snails that were on special, on the regular menu i think i had the shrimp, snails, mussels and a few more tapas i can't recall right now. None of them were that great, so i can't recommend anything on the regular menu that i have had. I expected better given that this place had a four star rating. I don't think the prices and food justify another visit. It was a decent meal i suppose, but I think i had better for cheaper.
author: Bennie H.

description: I felt like I was at a restaurant in Barcelona...The tapas were out of this world, but I didn't feel buzzed at all by the Sangria (like most people who reviewed this restaurant).  The atmosphere is lovely, pretty quiet, but ok for a well behaved big group.  We had about 8 people total.  Tapas that were fabulous that we ordered included the goat cheese, rabbit, and octopus...We also ordered the vegetable paella, which had tons of veggies and was out of this world.  They could've been more generous w/ their portion sizes, but hey, it's a TAPAS place...
author: Jenny W.

description: Great service! I really enjoyed the tapas and the wine.  Not a big fan of the paella - my mom makes it better :)  Try the Manchego Flambeado if you're a cheese fan.  The Tortilla Espanola con Chorizo is also a good choice.
author: Angela T.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants.  Good food and the service is impeccable.  Best place for paella!  Atmosphere intimate and romantic.  One of the few restaurants where you can actually have a quiet conversation and you don't have to shout over the din.  Prices aren't over the top either.
author: Madlyne P.

description: Had a wonderful meal tonight at Alegrias.  Sauteed mushrooms to start and a fine Zarzuela that while different than the one I loved in the SoHo Spanish restaurant in New York over 35 years ago, was just as good.  Fish and shellfish in a delicious tomato-based broth that I could not stop eating.  Soaked the very last of it into the thinly sliced bread.  Hmmmm.....  Wonderful service that was spot-on.  Enjoyed a glass of sangria that was $5.50 as I recall.  More than a fair price and not too sweet.  Also treated myself to a dessert of vanilla ice cream soaked in either sweet port or sherry with toasted pecans on top.  Just the right ending to a wonderful dinner.  Have been staying away from rice and other carbs, despite the small amount of bread I ate and dessert I succumbed to.  (:  Couldn't resist.  I'll be back...  By the way, I ate fairly early, around 7:00, and the two rooms were about 2/3 full.  When I left most of the tables were taken and more people were arriving.  Definitely a winner in my opinion.
author: Joshua C.

description: This is one of my favorite spots to munch in the city.  I always go with at least one other person, and stick to the tapas menu.  Do I even need to tell you how much fun it is to say 'manchego flambeado' five times fast?  The creamy jalapeno croquettes of godliness and the pork skewers basted in fairy dust are also huge favs.  My only real problem with their food is the bread they serve, which seems to always be stale.  But you didn't come for the bread...  Give the spot a taste test, and make reservations for the dinner hours (past 7ish) on a weekend.  ...I might hafta go in again tonight, just talking about Alegrias is stoking a craving.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Great food, cozy atmosphere, and reasonable price.  What else can you ask for in the Marina.  Its refreshing to see a family restaurant still providing great service and making their guest feel special.  

Nice job!
author: Josh C.

description:
Food is great, wine is great, service is outstanding, but the atmosphere is Blah. 

I love this place and go all the time, anytime we are in a large group becuase they ROCK at dealing with larger parties...

My only complaint is that the space is not very interesting....kind reminds me of a 1990's kitchen, i think it has to do with the bar....BUT, in reality I go here for the food, and MAN is the food great!
author: Dillon G.

description: I can't say enough about this charming family-run tapas restaurant on Lombard St. The atmosphere is cozy yet lively, so it's a great spot for a date as well as a birthday party.  Everything I've had so far has been tasty but the tortilla espanola is unbeatable.
author: shoba d.

description: Very tasty tapas! Sangria was easy to drink. The stools at the bar were sorta uncomfortable. It was dark inside. The women's bathroom was very clean. The recipe for the torta was the lady's grandmother's recipe who served us. Fast service. Allow 30 minutes for Paella orders. Quiet, roomy and dark atmosphere which allowed me to enjoy my tapas.
author: Full T.

description: This is a quiet place in what can be an obnoxious flip flop w/ jeans and groups walking to "get wasted"  neighborhood.  I'm just being honest!  The Marina is such a beautiful neighborhood but after years of living near by and having done all the bars it was SO refreshing to have dinner at Alegrias.  Quiet and walks that delicate line of being ok for small group and a little noise and good date spot.  The paella as others noted is tasty and the overall cuisine was pretty good.  Go try it but please wear shoes with your jeans :-)
author: Terence D.

description: Wonderful Spanish restaurant, the tapas are delicious, and the ambience is quiet and quaint.  Enough veggie tapas options to make me quite happy, and the veggie paella was great.  The non-veggie options have been drooled over by the others I've gone with too.  Get a pitcher of sangria...you'll want more than one glass.
author: Emily K.

description: We were happy to find a more calm and laid-back ambiance in a place in contrast to some of the other noisy ones on the street (maybe it was just that it was Superbowl Sunday.) The tapas were delicious, and getting six of them for four people was just enough to satiate us. The sangria wasn't the best I'd had (since you could taste that it was made with cheap wine), but the food made us forget that. We had the calamari with aioli sauce, the goat cheese and red wine sauce, the meat empanadas, and the shrimp with garlic white wine sauce, all which were were very tasty. I also liked that the service made us feel like we could take our time and not be rushed, even though they were attentive to us.
author: Shannon R.

description: Went here with a friend who I hadn't seen in forever to do some serious eating, drinking, and catching up. The wine they recommended for us was very reasonable and delicious. We probably got more food than we needed -- I would recommend ordering 2-3 plates to start with and then ordering more depending how hungry you are. The food is VERY rich and filling, which my friend and I underestimated. The staff is really terrific, can't say enough good things about them, we were very well taken care of.
author: Celine P.

description:
Alegrias gets a 4 star rating.  Overall the food was very good.  We ordered a mix of tapas: the tortilla, papas with ajillo, eggplant dish, empanadas, machengo, rabbit stew (flavored to perfection with the right spices, not too oily, and tender) , paella, and the croquettes.  My only disappointment for the food was the croquettes which had way too much cheese to taste any of the meat. But it was fried to perfection.    We got 2 paellas-- one seafood and one vegetarian.  Both were consistent for the flavor in the rice.  I wish the vegetarian had the veggies cut up a bit more.



While we were there, we didn't seem to have a consistent server, but it didn't matter because everyone there responded promptly to our requests for more water, sangria, the coffee menu, etc.  The staff was very friendly -- we went for my friend's birthday and I made her a cake.  The staff brought out the cake on a plate with a doilie--- far beyond my expecation and even put candles on it (even though I had brought my own.)   They were friendly  and wonderful about the whole thing and didn't bat an eye over the fact that I brought in my own dessert.  And our coffee was served fairly quickly after ordering. 

The sangria was fair.  Personally I think the one I make is better. (Probably b/c I don't water it down as much.)

Parking is extremely difficult-- but what do you expect from Marina/Cow Hollow district.
author: A P.

description: I totally love this restaurant.  We ordered tons of tapas and they were fantastic (warm goat cheese was amongst the favorites) in addition to getting paella.  They have a great selection so the meat lovers and the vegetarians in our group were both satisfied plus the sangria was top notch.  I will definetly be making a return visit.
author: Jenn K.

description:
went here for a bite...i have to say it was horrible.  bland food and needed to ask them for the habanero sauce to liven things up.   the sangria was good as always and the goat cheese was amazing.  like lasagna without the la.  we used it like fondue since everything tonite needed some of it.  we liked the server - good guy with cool stories about Sevilla.




this place is good...tasty sangria...didnt knock my socks off...I prefer esperpento or cha cha cha
author: Rob C.

description: Great tapas, cozy atmosphere, prompt seating, good service. I tried their paella and it wasn't as fantastic, but whatever.
author: Inbae L.

description: We went to Alegrias tonight.  Atmosphere was nice, server was nice as well.   He was helpful in giving us advice on the menu. We ordered 2 tapas and the paella.  The chorizo was good, as well as the potatos.  The paella was veggie, and we added chorizo.  Everything A-OK!!
author: Steve and Alex C.

description: One of the best places in SF.   We had a small (70 people) reception here - the family that owns this place did absolutely everything they could to make it perfect.  The food is superb, the service is exceptional.
author: Dave B.

description: Great selection, great service. Had a large party that was late on a Friday night but the staff were very patient and servic-oriented.  Selection was excellent and the sangria was great
author: Marc L.

description: This is the best Spanish restaurant I have found in SF! I brought a friend from Spain with an incredibly picky palate to eat there, and he gave it a raised eyebrow and an "It's okay." Translation: as close to real Spanish cooking as I'm willing to admit.
author: Sylvia H.

description: This is a great little place for Spanish tapas! I can't believe I've never been here until now. It's not too hard to get a reservation nor was it that crowded on a Saturday night when I went. The sangria kicks butt, as does the food. I especially loved loved the dulce de leche crepes for dessert...mmmmmmmm!
author: Fern D.

description: Good tapas and a nice vegetarian selection.  The vegetable paella is darn tasty.
author: Sharon P.

description: a bit shocked this place has 4 stars.  it's just ehhh.  somehow in our wanderings through the marina we ended up here.  i would only go back for the empanadas and their chicken and shrimp croquettes.  everything else is just ehh.
author: Mao K.

description: Great place! Came here for a friend's birthday dinner. The food was very tasty, a great variety of tapas to choose from and share. Also, the pitcher of sangria was perfect for the three of us to go with dinner! The decor looked very good too -- it might seem small from the outside, but has plenty of space inside. I saw several larger parties sitting not too far away from us. Overall, really enjoyed the dinner and overall atmosphere at Alegrias!
author: O A.

description:
I think this is my first 2-star rating.  I just didn't like this place.  Maybe I didn't like what we ordered...?  

Came here a year ago (on the 4th of July).  We were looking for a new place in the Marina.  Their website says "romantic" but I wasn't getting those vibes at all (unless you consider that the tables are pretty tiny which might make it easier to play footsie).  The service was good, but the food was a lick less than "okay."  I am not normally too fussy about food, but nothing on the menu really screamed "try me."  We ended up ordering 2 or 3 small plates, and a couple of main dishes to share.  We did get a good caramel dessert and the sangria was also good, but overall, went home unimpressed.  And of course, since this place happens to have the zip code 94123, dinner here is going to cost you more than you'd really like.

I think I'd rather try a different tapas place than return to Alegrias to "try again."
author: Lindsay M.

description: I'm biased b/c this is the place that I had my first dinner with the guy who is now my husband. There is a parking structure right across the street, making it really easy and pleasant from the start. Either in a group or as a couple, the atmosphere is so cozy and nice here that it always make me happy after a dinner at Alegrias. I think I tried close to 80% of the dishes through my visits with my friends and husband and the only dish so far that didn't wow me was the Paella - it was tasty but not super-impressive like the other dishes. No way I can pick my favorite dish - everything is REALLY good here.
author: Sue C.

description: I havent had good authentic spanish food in awhile mmm good. I had croquettas di jamon, bocadillos cangrejo and paella valenciana con chorizo whew I actually wanted some conejo (rabbit) but I was too full to eat anymore. The sangria was just right not too sweet by the way the callos was jus like my grandmother makes it sooo good. we had dulce de leche in a crepe to end the evening ahhh decadent but good. I will definetly come back with more family soon
author: augusto c.

description: I had a sudden urge for tapas one night thinking about when I travelled to Spain. Alegrias was good. I have no real complaints about it. It was a really dim kind of dramatic setting. It didn't feel very Spanish to me. The tapas were really good. I can't recall what exactly we had, but they were good. The paella was ok. It was good enough to satisfy the craving, but not extraordinary.
author: Karen F.

description:
One of my favorite go-to places for Spanish tapas. Good food, good service, and it's walking distance for me.

The environment is super quaint and home-y. They've got a back room that can hold large groups of people.

You need to order:
1) a pitcher of sangria
2) paella
3) empanadas
4) whatever else looks good to you

Can't really go wrong at this place.
author: Angela T.

description: I love frequenting this place.  My partner and I absolutely love the food, ambiance, and the fact that it's family owned and very unpretentious - a rarity when trying to find a decent dining experience.  The owners put a lot of love into the food they serve.  The little knick knacks on the wall are diverting in a good way.  The food, service and SANGRIA are excellent.  My idea of a great date place.
author: Emma W.

description: Tapas and Thai are the pretty standard choices for birthday dinners with friends. This place was very very good and having been my third time, I'd say the food has been consistently good. The tapas were very authentic, and of the 9 we tried, all were excellent. The paella, both vegetarian and everything in it were excellent. We had a member of our group who was allergic to tomatoes, eggplant and bell pepper. They were lovely about finding tapas and a main dish she could eat and even exchanged some sauces so she wouldn't get sick. They were so nice and laid back about it. I really loved the relaxed atmosphere and the food for a big group out for some fun.
author: Kat C.

description:
Organized the bfs bday dinner here. It's the perfect place for a group dinner (there were 13 of us). It's intimate enough that we didn't need to shout at each other and lively enough that we didn't feel like we were making a ruckus in the restuarant. The best part is that they have a prifixe menu for groups. We had salad...almost a gazillion tapas (like seriously) and paella...all for $36 a person pretax/tip. What a deal! 

Standouts of the night:
1) aioli: That creamy spicy goodness served with the tortas was delicious, and I'm sure anything else that would be served with it would be just as yummy
2) sangria: crisp, refreshing, on the sweet side but not overwhelming
3) paella: sooooo good...I was so stuffed with the 10 plates of tapas that I thought I might burst when the plates of paella came...but I ate the whole plate!

Good tapas, good atmosphere, solid service: all in all a great experience.
author: Emily W.

description: very decent tapas.  very similar to those ive had in spain.  i liked the jamon and the potatoes.  the sangria is pretty good, i think it needs more alcohol though.  but I always thinks things need more alcohol.  :)
author: Janet S.

description: I love this place!  I had a birthday dinner here a few years ago and have been going back ever since.  The food is amazing!  I have never had to wait for a table which I can't figure out why.  The parking is not the best in this area but defiantly worth it!
author: Michelle M.

description: I love this place!  It's so romantic and homey, and the food and service are both amazing.  I really wanted the paella, but didn't have time, so we got the prawns and sea bass instead.  The food tasted delicious, and was filling, but not too heavy.  The sangria's the best I've had - you have to get it, and the overall experience was charming.   Can't wait to try the paella!
author: Samantha B.

description:
I don't understand the good reviews.  The restaurant isn't awful, but extraordinarily average for San Francisco and downright disappointing given its proximity to the fabulous creative spaces on Chestnut St. and Union St.

The food and service is far better than the rundown decor would suggest.  There are a lot of restaurants nearby that experiment with their dishes.  This didn't seem to be one of those restaurants.

We took out-of-town guests based on these reviews and we were all disappointed.
author: george o.

description: Callos and stuffed peppers were good.  Paella Valencia was ok also.  Is it suppose to be greasy though?  Overall good for romantic dates.
author: J W.

description: I found Alegrias to be good, but not amazing. There are many wonderful Spanish restaurants around the city that are more reasonable and fun. At the same time, it's a good option for a group of people as it has cute decor and big portions.
author: Sara W.

description: We went here for a quiet birthday and it was wonderful! Great Paella and loved the snails! :)
author: Elizabeth B.

description: Although this place lacks the festive atmosphere of Cha Cha Cha and Esperpento, the food and sangria make up for it!  I would have to say this is some of the best damn sangria I've ever had!  And the tapas, the most delicious I've tried so far-and I'm a tapas fanatic! We had the crabcakes that were very crisp on the outside-just the way I like them. The sauteed mushrooms were non-greasy with a very nice sherry flavor and not too garlicky.  The empanadas were also perfecty executed with just the right amount of crispiness with a savory filling. With the dim lighting and white tablecloths, this place is ideal for a romantic meal.
author: anne m.

description: I have been here twice recently and both times have been consistently excellent. The food is tasty, ambiance is nice, keep the sangia coming, and at the end you have a pleasantly modest check by San Francisco standards ($30ish per person for dinner, drinks, dessert, tax, tip). The food is very good, traditional tapas without any surprises on the menu. There are enough vegetarian options for everyone to have a variety of dishes. The ambiance is nice yet relaxed. I have enjoyed dinner there both times immensely and will be back for sure in the future!
author: Erin H.

description: Very homey and causal spanish restaurant. I loved the stewed rabbit with wine sauce and carrots. The cold tapas of grilled vegetables was delicious with their homemade olive oil. The garlic prawns were okay.. prawns looked more like shrimps... The warm bread pudding with ice cream wasn't too impressive. The food was pretty good, but I felt like the service wasn't that great. The restaurant wasn't even packed and we waited forever for our ice cream, which the waiter forgot to put on top of our bread pudding. I've had better tapas in the Mission.
author: Denise L.

description: Great ambiance, very attentive staff and good food...pricey but good.
author: MrsNIFTY G.

description: So cute and warm inside. Romantic with the white draping and lovely dim (but not too dim) lighting. Love the owners, sweet as can be. Staff is right on too. Food is definitely right on!!! Spanish food that knows what it's doing. I've been to Spain 3x, so I can say I sort of know.
author: Angel S.

description:
Brought a few friends here for dinner since we were hanging out in the Marina area that night. I've been here once before for a restaurant experience project for my food & wine class. Had an excellent time and had a good talk with the owner for about half an hour about him and the restaurant. I love the fact that it's a family owned restaurant and the whole family works there. Very friendly people and they are truly from Basque country.

The atmosphere is very cozy. They can accommodate large groups or a table for two. The decor is simple and elegant with a homelike feel to it. Their bar is lined with hundreds of bottles of wine. The service was very attentive and friendly. As soon as we finished a dish, someone came by to swoop up the empty plate. They also refilled our waters quite often and we never had a dry glass. Even though we stayed and chatted after we finished dinner, we never felt like they pushed us to leave like other restaurants sometimes do. However, they weren't that busy that night anyways so I guess it didn't matter if we were lingering.

The food was excellent for the most part. We ordered the skewers that came with some good tiny french fry like potatoes. The crab cakes were also good and a pretty good portion for $10 (you get 2 which are about 2 inch in diameter). The snails & clams were delicious in the semi spicy red sauce. The mushrooms tasted like any other tapas place. We also got the fried cheese which was nothing special besides the fact that it comes flaming. We ordered the seafood paella which was enough for the 4 of us since we ordered tapas too. We were surprised at how much seafood they actually give you, which makes it well worth it. The seasonings/sauce was really good although the rice portion could have been more. For dessert we got the flaming apple crepe with ice cream. The burnt sugar sticks to your teeth, but other than that it was good. We also ordered a pitcher of the sangria which was excellent and doesn't have the bad after taste finish that I've experienced with others.

Great family owned authentic Spanish restaurant with a cozy atmosphere. Delicious food in a convenient location. Only cons are the portions are a little bit small even though they are tapas and it's a bit pricier than other places, but still good.
author: Linda C.

description:
This is a cozy, little restaurant that's not overly gaudy or pretentious as other places.  Parking wasn't too terrible here and it took me about 15 minutes before I found a spot a couple blocks away in the Marina district.  I came here for a birthday dinner and I was about an hour late due to work and not because I'm a lagger... really.

Stepping inside, I didn't think we could get a table to fit the 15+ people there in our group, but they had a back room and combined several tables together to let us all fit.  I didn't decide on my orders because we went with a pre-fixed menu and by the time I got there, the food was just starting to come out.  I don't know whether they're just slow with the food or it took some time before everyone was seated.  I was too hungry at the time to care at that point.  So they brought out each of the tapas dishes pretty quickly one after another (I think there were around 8 dishes or so).  The portions were just about right and the food was elegant.  I enjoyed every dish they brought out and there wasn't too much to really complain about the place.  This is a very solid tapas restaurant.  We also ordered a pitcher of sangria and it was alcoholic and sweet as it should be.  At the end of the night, we each paid roughly $40 also paying for the birthday girl, so it wasn't too shabby.  It was a good choice for a restaurant and I would definitely go back if I'm in the tapas mood.
author: David Y.

description: Being of Spanish decent, and also a frequent traveler, Alegrias does their Tapas right!  The food was very well prepared and fresh.  The emapanadillas de carne were my favorite.  Everything had the homemade taste.  Even the restaurant's service was Spanish style, meaning they do not hover over your plates waiting for you to finish and they dont rush you out by bringing the bill right away.  My girlfriend and I sat, ate, drank, and were there for almost two hours without any push for us to give up our table.  This is a great spot to take a date beofre a night out in the City.
author: Mike D.

description: Caught a quick dinner here before heading over to Yoshis SF.  Started with the Tortilla de Chorizo (omelette) and Gambas al Ajillo (garlic sauteed prawns) and finished with the Chuletillas de Cordero con Patatas a lo Pobre (lamb chops).  The flavors were powerful, fragrant and everything was well-seasoned.  Couldn't get enough of the jus from the prawns - the bread soaked it up perfectly.  Service was quick and the waiter would come by to check on us but never interrupted our conversation.  The perfect portions for 2.
author: Aubergine R.

description: This is a great spot; I'll definitely be back.  The decor is a little 70s, though the food is very good.  Didn't try the paella, but the tapas list is long and everything tasted authentic.  Great selection of very affordable wines from Spain, Italy, and South America.  Would have given 5 stars if only they had ox tail!
author: Daniel D.

description: Great food, I went tonight to celebrate my getting a raise. Was seated by the window in the front. Very good tapas, not so good service. I can't understand why damn near everyone seems to think that I should speak Spanish (no hablo espaol only gets one so far in this world). Anyway, the house rioja was excellent as was the chocolate mousse. The tapas portions are small and not too filling individually, and I burnt the tongue several times taking the empanadas. So, one star off for that temperature and the language issue. For fsck's sake, this is America, speak English! The final bill was $54 including tip -- inflation's only 4% my arse! A $5 parking tariff later and I was done.  Cheers -- H
author: Hasan D.

description: Maybe I should let my wife write this review (she grew up in Madrid courtesy of the Air Force). She knows good Spanish food (her mom makes a mean Paella and Tortilla) and loves it when it's done right. Alegrias, evidently does it right. Went here for our Anniversary and were blown away. The place is very small (don't drive by) and very romantic. We started with a variety of excellent tapas, both hot and cold, with the Camarones Diabla taking the cake. We decided on the Paella Valencia and were not disappointed. This dish was absolute heaven! We've never had a Paella this good, and the best part is we were there on a Thursday night and had the place practically to ourselves (OK, there were other people there). It didn't hurt that the Sangia was incredible too. Finished off everything with an excellent Flan, and staggered back to our hotel completely satisfied (we walked, OK!). Alegrias is a gem that you must try if you like the cuisine of Spain/Portugal.
author: Jeff K.

description: One of the best places I know for decent paellas. B44 doesn't quite match up to this restaurant's flavors.
author: Miles G.

description: You cannot find a restaurant with better service or ambiance than Alegrias. If your woman doesn't give you nookie after taking her here, next time try the Apple Crepe.  I nearly orgasmed by the second bite.  I'm going  back next week.
author: Mrsdubyah W.

description: I like checking places out on Lombard because no one ever wants to go to them.  The food is good, very reasonably priced, and the service is excellent.  These are tapas, so it's no surprise that the portions are small.  I'm going back soon!
author: Spice O.

description:
Awesome, awesome tapas.  

Forget about the rest of the menu and order 5-6 of their tapas dishes for two and you're set.  All of them were excellent,  but a couple of them definitely stood out.  The goat cheese in tomato sauce, pulpo (octopus), vegetarian empanada and their jamon were all outstanding.  All that they're missing are a couple of jamon hooves hanging from the ceiling and your immediately transformed to a small tapas bar in Spain.

I also liked the laid back atmosphere without all the hustle and bustle of other trendy tapas restaurants in SF.  Definitely will be going back when that urge for pulpo surfaces again.
author: Andy S.

description:
yay! i love Alegrias! the hubby and i celebrated our anniversary there this weekend and had a great time. everything we had was scrumptious -- the paella was a perfect size and very authentic. in fact, everything reminded me of real food from Spain -- i actually felt like i was there in Espana. ay, la vida es buena. i had sangria (very tasty indeed, and with oranges only, nothing unnecessary added) and some alhambra negra beer and, of course, crema catalana for dessert. that was the only so-so thing -- it was torched quite well on top, but the flavor was a little off... maybe the mix is a bit too strong? i know, i'm totally a crema catalana snob. :-)

otherwise, super-yum. it's the best spanish restaurant i've been to in san francisco -- Las Ramblas in the mission is fun for tapas -- but Alegrias is where you go for something a little more special.

it is in a semi-random part of the city on Lombard, but i believe that adds to its charm -- and makes it a bit more of a challenge -- you have to really want it... or just jump in a cab and get there within 10 minutes, like everything else in the city. i do miss that 7x7 miles, man.

xoxo, Alegrias!
author: karen p.

description:
Disclaimer: Just because I gave five stars does not mean that I equivocate this food to the AMAZING food I had in Espana last summer. 

This past wknd came with a group of 13 folks and just had an amazing, well organized, good service, good food, etc. experience. This night could have had many opportunities to turn into a disaster with so many people here, but it turned out great! Thanks to Larry our waiter (and a few others). We were originally supposed to have a smaller group but they were accomodating to increase our group size. (Some last minute folks joined in...people RSVP please...!!!!! A possible nightmare on a Friday  night)

As a result of having at least 12 people there, we had to go with the pre fixe - which I believe is a salad and 8 tapas (per group of 4). For $28/person not a bad deal (probably more food than we needed to order and I haven't done the math exactly, but it was probably priced about right (although I'm sure I could have ordered a lot less and been just as happy/full). The kitchen was nice enough to allow us to substitute two of the tapas on the pre fixe menu, as we weren't exactly the biggest fan of cold tapas (I myself am a fan generally of caliente tapas). In addition, they were super nice about letting us bring in a cake for our friend's birthday - I think they do normally charge a fee for this.

We had the escalivadas, aceitunas alinada (olives), empanadillas de carne (beef empanadas), croquettas del dia (chicken croquettes - or whatever is of the day), gambas al ajillo (shrimp), setas al ajillo (mushrooms), patatas bravas (potatoes), pinchos morunos (pork loins), ensalada de casa (house salad). 

Winners: Olives (if you like olives), empanadlilas, croquettas el dia, setas al ajillo, pinchos morunos, ensalada de casa (if you feel you need some fiber). Personally loved the empanadas as I like most turnover like pastries, LOVED mushrooms probably related to my most recent mushroom kick, and of course the pork loin mostly because I do like pork but it really meshed well with the croquettas because I used the potatoes on the bottom and took the aioli from the croquettas and mixed them together - I assume this would obviously be the same thing as if we had just ordered patatas aioli which we didn't - but I would next time. Not sure though I would be a fan of them putting the aioli on top vs. dipping. Loved the aioli though. OH Sangria is good, but not as good at the one in Zarzuela.

Non - winners: The shrimp was a bust for me because I love fresh shrimp (as a result of my Texan roots), and this was def frozen shellfish that was overcooked. I do like my rioja sauce though...Patatas bravas just can never be good as in Espana. 

Overall a great experience, ESPECIALLY for large groups. They nicely put you in a back room and you can actually hear your neighbors. It's just a matter if you want to pay that much after all the sangria.
author: Jeannette L.

description:
umm...delish! my favorite items were definitely the bocadillos de cangrejo (crabcakes with a creamy jalapeno sauce) and croquetas (fluffy fried mashed potatoes). we also had the patatas alioli and empanadillas de carne which were pretty yummy as well.

a cute, calm and cozy place - perfect ambiance for couples and pairs of great friends.

throw in a pitcher of sangria and it's a fabulous dinner spot.
author: Yulimar C.

description: you feel welcomed and at home once you walk into alegria's.  i brought some out of town vegetarian friends to this place and we all really enjoyed it.  a great assortment of dishes (with fair amount of vegetarian options besides the usual patatas bravas and tortilla espanol).
author: Helen T.

description: I had so much sangria and I didn't get buzzed. I think I drank some other stuff and I finally started to get drunk...which may have influenced how I felt about the food.  It was pretty good- very fresh.  Subtle flavors and really really expensive with the sangria.  $60/ person after we were all said and done.  I was starving afterwards too.  I think I might need to try it again but I don't have $60.  Stay tuned.
author: Yvonne Y.

description: I thought this place was average.  The food was mediocre but I thought the Sangria was delicious.  The service was a bit slow.
author: Toni C.

description:
alegrias has just reconfirmed my fears, that there are a few decent tapas places in the city but none that are actually really good. 

the best thing there was the sauteed spinach.  it was homey but interesting.   the sauteed prawns were grossly overcooked though the sauce was tasty.  tried the tortilla omelet.  meh.

paella had the same overcooked shrimps.  it was alright but i've definitely had much better.  it was nice they let us leave out the calamari tho.

yummy sangria.  olive oil for the bread was awesome.

overall, everything was reasonably priced.  i was pleasantly surprised how cheap it was considering how much food we got.  had lots of leftovers to take home.

decor reminds me of japantown denny's.   nicer though, obviously.  it's not that it's ghetto, it's just kind of bizarre.

watch out, it is impossible to find parking in this area.  if i lived in the neighborhood, i'd probably eat here again.  but right now, i don't think i'll be coming back.
author: Miss K.

description: If you've been to Spain, you'll like this place.  Surely the best paella in the City, which is large enough to be shared by two.  Great appetizers, excellent deserts, good wine list and genuinely friendly staff.  I like this place very much.
author: Ken W.

description: I've only been to Alegrias once, but it was a great experience. We met some friends before going to an improv show in Fort Mason. The food was great, as was the atmosphere. Good place for sharing and trying a variety of dishes. Parking can be a little tricky, but if you have a little time to walk there is always space at Ft. Mason.
author: Tracy L.

description: This was a really quaint yet classy restaurant.  The staff was very professional and accomodating (they turned the air up immediately when we asked to be moved from under the air conditioning vent), the tapas were extremely tasty and not overpriced ($8.00 on average per tapa), and I only wish we had had room for paella (around $15-20), but we'll do that next time.  The Sangria was also reasonably priced and tasty.  This seems like a nice place for a personal event, like an anniversary or a small family gathering, or, as someone else mentioned, a small birthday celebration.  I won't be back often, but if I'm ever in the mood for a touch of class and some great tapas (with an adequate amount of options for vegetarians), I will go here.
author: Christine G.

description:
cutesy little place with a deceiving sketchy-looking storefront. 

My B-friend and I ordered 4 Tapas Calientes: shrimp in white wine sauce, beef turnover, spicy patatas, and pork tenderloin. Turnover was crispy on the outside, and very tender on the inside. 

Each tapa plate ranges from $6-11, very reasonable tapa prices, especially with the quaint and homey decor inside.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
A perfectly acceptable dinner.

However, it pales in comparison to Zarzuela.  The one thing that Alegrias understands well is how to do garlic broth.  On the prawn and on the fish, the garlic broth was just wonderful.  However, the fish itself was a very low cost item, and I couldn't help but wonder how nice the dish could have been with cod, sea bass, or some other nicer fish.  

Some of the other tapas were fine and the decor and service were all quite nice.

However, I keep comparing this place in my mind to Zarzuela, and the octopus at Alegrias is not close to the same class nor is the sangria (which tastes more like fruit punch at Alegrias).

In any event, since both places are about the same distance from my house, I have no doubt that Zarzuela will always be my choice over Alegrias whenever tapas come to mind.
author: Richard P.

description: I went with my boyfriend on a Monday night. It was lovely. The food was good, service was attentive, atmosphere was warm and comfortable, and prices were moderate. I give the place 3 stars because the sangria was disappointing.
author: Angel K.

description: Small & cozy & the price is right. Croquettes are delish! The seafood paella was pretty good and came with a ton of seafood. Hate it when restaurants are sheisty with the proteins. Sangria was tasty, but I like my sangria with a variety of fruit - this only had oranges, so it was a little boring.
author: Jeannie C.

description: Tasty sangria, excellent empanadillas de carne, and good cheese flambe.  Good atmosphere, overall experience was well above average.
author: Matt A.

description:
Four years ago, when I moved to SF, I treated all my friends who helped me move to a nice dinner at Alegria's.  I have to say each and everyone of them definitely enjoyed their meal (and the drink too - lol).

If you are looking to take a big group out for Spanish tapas this is the place to go.  Unlike most of the tapas restaurants in the city - this place actually has room to host big groups.

It's a family owned and operated place and man does it show!  The food here is amazing and as about authentic Spanish as you can get in SF.  I really can't say anything bad about this place.  Just give it a try!!
author: Mike A.

description: Decent tapas and sangria, but nothing spectacular - there are better tasting tapas to be had (likely in other cities).. in particular, the sangria gets rave reviews here but it tasted diluted with little wine/alcohol backbone (though it did have lots of fruit flavor).
author: Justin S.

description:
I've walked by Alegrias so many times and never really thought about going  there. But I had a craving for tapas and figured why not? Doesn't look like much from the outside, but inside is very warm and cozy. I was in Barcelona last year and it really did feel like an authentic Spanish restaurant, minus the view of the Lombard parking garage across the street. We walked in without a reservation and they managed to seat us within 10 minutes - on a Friday night. But it didn't take long for the restaurant to become packed and buzzing.

The food was delicious. We had a variety of tapas: olives, meat and cheese plate, croquettes, potatoes with aiola sauce and mussels. All excellent. But the potatoes were especially good.

My only complaint is that the food came to fast. I would've like for them to bring out the tapas a bit slower. I don't like to feel rushed. But this could be an plus to people who like to get in and get out. Me on the other hand, I like to linger. Can't blame them though, it was very busy, and we didn't have a reservation.

Definitely a new favorite of mine and I will go there again. Yum.
author: Nikki E.

description:
came here for dinner tonight.  we were 3 and decided to share a few tapas... thought that 5 tapas would be enough for the three of us so we got some eggplant, tortilla with chorizo, steamed mussels, octopus, and crab cakes.  all of them were tasty and had good flavor.  well i don't know what the tortilla tasted like since i didn't eat it.  but the other dishes i did eat and we were satisfied.  i wanted to try the pulpo (octopus) and i was impressed because it was not at all rubbery... it was really tender and melted in my mouth almost.  
the only bad thing was that 5 dishes were actually not enough for us... so we ordered the seafood/chicken paella in addition to our tapas.  the 30 minute wait was worth it and it gave us some time to sit and digest.  i guess the tortilla with chorizo was pretty filling since it had a lot of potatoes in it, but i didn't feel stuffed at all.  so when we got the paella after 30 minutes we were able to finish it all too.  we also shared a pitcher of sangria which was sweet and refreshing.
the interior is intimate, cozy, and quiet.  small tables with white table cloth with enough space separating each party.  the dining room is also divided up so it feels a lot smaller than it is... there's some spanish music softly playing in the background so people can listen to their conversations and enjoy the company they're with.
author: charlotte s.

description: A slice of Spain in the Bay Area! With tapas and Spanish restaurants popping up everywhere, this long time neighborhood gem still rates as one of the best in San Francisco. The croquetas are crispy on the outside and delicately creamy on the inside - instantly taking you back to any vacation to Spain where one often "tapear." My favorite dish, however, is the gambas al ajillo. The flavors are perfectly balanced and the shrimp cooked to the right texture. The sauce is so exquisite that it becomes the perfect partner with your bread, as you find yourself slopping up all remnants of the sauce in the earthenware dish it's presented in. Definitely a great place for a Spanish dining experience!
author: C L.

description: What a great place.  Everything was excellent, from the service to the sangria to the wine to the whole feel of the place.  Plus, cheap parking in the garage across the street.  We'll be back many times.  Super paella.  Wonderful stuff peppers. Etc. Etc.  Do yourself a favor and go there right away.
author: Kanani P.

description: Great food, nice place to spend an evening. Was there for a friend's birthday party. The spanish omelette and the potatoes in red sauce tasted really good. For some reason the shrimp dish (which i didn't taste) smelt a little weird but tasted good. On the whole, definitely a place worth going back to. I really liked the ceiling decor - almost like a cascading sail  from a boat.
author: Arnab B.

description:
I guess I don't like tapas, because I could tell it was made with quality ingredients, cooked right, but it didn't do a lot for me. Except the baked goat cheese with tomato sauce. That was delicious. But otherwise tapas seems like a Spanish version of corn dogs and hot pretzels. Oh well.

The interior is pretty strange--it felt like I was eating in someone's grandma's living room. I found that mildly disturbing, but I bet some people would really love it.
author: Dave M.

description:
great atmosphere, great service. went on my birthday and was happy, went back a week later and it was a great experience as well. some of the flavours could be a little deeper, although they are very excellent overall.

great place for a date, dinner conversation volume is perfect - even with a full house.
author: Haoming C.

description: This place is excellent-The food, the service, the atmosphere. I recommend it to everyone. The paella is just as good if not better than the best paella I had in Spain. I will definitely be going back to this place again.
author: L. S.

description: Adorable, sweet, and romantic - and a place where you can actually enjoy (and hear) your dinner companion's voice. The patatas bravas were to die for - and I've traveled to Spain. We ordered an assortment, and everything was lip-smacking, finger-lickin' good. Didn't think there would be a good tapas place in SF, but I was proven wrong.
author: Lemon S.

description:
I went to Alegrias twice so far, and was not disappointed either time! The cozy, quaint atmosphere makes it an extremely authentic-feeling Spanish restaurant. Both times I went for the tapas and enjoyed all of the various ones that I tried!

The waitstaff is attentive and very authentic, leaving you to your meal without any pressure to give you the check or get you out the door. They seem genuinely interested in your enjoyment of the meal, and are happy to help out whenever you need something.

The Sangria was also pretty fantastic!

As a whole I really enjoyed the experience of being there.. it brought me back to my semester abroad in Spain through the decor, the service, and the laidback, non-rushed atmosphere.

I would recommend this place to anyone, (ok, maybe not the most kid-friendly- mostly due to the menu) and I regularly do! :)

Check it out! Enjoy!
author: Laura S.

description:
More like a 3.5.  Had a hankerin' for octopus last night, but unfortunately Zarzuela is closed on Mondays.  Hadn't gone to Alegrías in a few years, so off we went.

Positives: Overall, the food was very good.  The following tapas were ingested:
                 Escalivada: delicious
                 Pulpo (Octopus) a la gallega: noble in flavor, frugal in quantity
                 Bunny: tender and bathed in a toothsome stew
                 Fried Calamari: good, light/clean oil tasting
                 Croquetas: nice texture, but it was hard to detect the jamón serrano and shrimp that were supposedly included in the ingredients; furthermore, the "alioli", the same dipping sauce that accompanied the calamari, looked more like a thick thousand island sauce, and while cool and refreshing, was devoid of perceptible flavor in general and of garlic in particular

Negatives:  Upon leaving I was left with an uncomfortable, unsettling spiritual sensation.  The food was decent to very good, the service was for me perfect, unhovering, dish servings well paced . . .what was the problem?  Introspection required. . .

Conclusions: For those not concerned with price/quality ratios, this is definitely a place that has plenty of pleasure-inducing dishes to choose from.  However, for those who like to poke with the consumer prod a bit, the wine we had is a good metaphor for this restaurant.  We each had a glass of 2006 CUNE Rioja, a quality wine in lovely large glasses that made the sweetest sound when clinged, but at $10 a not so generous pop, we ended up tallying $85 for 5 tapas, 2 glasses of wine, tax and tip.
