It seems that prices here have certainly gone up a level since my last visit.  I dont think there was a bottle of dinner wine available for under $35, and the very limited by the glass offerings were at the aforementioned $10.  I've decided I would love to return if someone invited me, but for me to give a hearty suggestion to go, I would like them to turn up the lights a bit, increase the portion sizes ($9 for 4 croquetas is just wrong) and turn down the prices and the preciousness.  Much is of course an esthetic personal preference, the Zarzuela mesón style as opposed to whatever this is supposed to be, but in the future I will channel my tapas cravings from Tue-Sat in order to enjoy more reasonably priced good wine in generic glasses with more numerous octopus disks.  After this dining experience, I was reminded of a few years back when I bought a baseball mitt I really liked after shopping around quite a bit, then realized after getting home that my wallet was $20 short because 2 spankin new bills had apparently stuck together and the clerk hadn't "noticed".  Same great glove, but now the joy was watered down for feeling like a victim of the okey doke.
author: Ultiminio P.

description:
love this place for tapas food. very clean, quiet, and quite romantic. service was great..attentive waiters without being too bothersome. havent been here in years but last nite's experience brought back good memories. 
i do remember the manchego flambe was awesome years ago but didnt get to try it this time but how can it go wrong? melted cheese?! mmmm....
mushrooms in white wine, the tripe, empanadillas, and patatas bravas=YUMMY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
friend & i each had a glass of sangria..delish!

prices are average for tapas...everything starts @ $6.95 and up. most expensive items on menu were actual dinner entrees & paella. so we had 4 tapas, 2 glasses of sangria, and a flan = $60 with tip & tax for 2 ppl. yea, kinda pricey but i dont get to eat tapas often. and i wanted to try more stuff...damn!

only con is parking situation..even on a wednesday--damn marina!
author: Yolanda L.

description: it was awhile back but i was looking for a tapas place to throw a friend's bday party and someone (i forgot who - sorry!) recommended this place. i have to say, most of the dishes were tasty (we ordered a LOT) or maybe it's the awesome sangria talking? from what i remember it was quite cozy and they did really well accomodating a group of 20+.
author: Jane Y.

description: i came here for a large birthday party over the weekend and this place was a total rip off.  the restaurant was clean and the service was good but the food was not.  we had a fixed menu due to our large party (15+) and it was supposed to be $28+ a head not including tax and tips.  the food was small...teeny tiny portions...possibly one bite size a plate tapas.  we had 9 small dishes: 2 diced up potatoes, potato cake, shrimp (over cooked), eggplant, pork, mushrooms, cured meat (salami etc), and others.  it was not delicious in the least.  the total came out to be $40 per person, not including drinks.  if you're planning on holding a large party here, please think otherwise for the sake of your guests.
author: amee m.

description: paella was delicious, sangria - best i've had, empanadillas had a crispy thin exterior and the filling was a delicious blend of sweet and savory ingredients, loved the garlic mushrooms, and the fried potatoes with aoli was special =)
author: Jesica M.

description: Found this place on Open Table and thought we'd give them a try.  The staff was friendly though we were left hoping for a little waiter attention at times.  The food was yummy, and a pitcher of sangria made it through over five (smaller) glasses.  Overall a good place, especially as an alternate to busier places on Chestnut.
author: Naz H.

description: This is a moderate family run business. Nice decor, moderate prices but the best Spanish food in San Francisco.  We went for our anniversary dinner and had several tapas (Iberica ham, tortilla espanol, stuffed peppers, olives, little sausages) and a Pallela Valenciana, along with the $36 bottle of Cava (sparkling white wine) and the Crema Catalan and an apple dessert.  It was all fantastic. The chef/owner really cares if you like the restaurant and puts a lot of care into the food.  The waiter (his son) gave good suggestions for the tapas and how much we needed to be full.  I'd recommend this to anyone looking for authentic Spanish cuisine and a lovely atmosphere.
author: Nicholette M.

description: We were impressed.  This is now one of our new fave tapas place.  In addition to serving some of the yummiest paella, around there are some pretty authentic tapas from the different regions of spain.  The queso flambeado (spanish manchego cheese flambe')  is so tasty.  You must also try Callos a la Madrilea (tripe prepared Madrid style) and the tortilla espanola con chorizo.  We finally finished off the meal with a wonderful Crema Catalana (like a creme brulee, but better).  The service was friendly and helpful.  If I had anything to complain about it would be that the sangria was a bit tasteless with little to no alcohol content.  I will probably just get a nice spanish red wine the next time I go.
author: Doris K.

description: This place has consistently great food.   Mussels are really good.  It has great atmosphere as well.
author: Mark D.

description: Best tapas joint in the city!  True dishes from Spain made by the owner, Cesar, who still has a thick accent even after 30 years in the states.  We left it up to him to order his specialties and were we wowed!!  The first tapa was the Conejo a la Cazuela, which turned out to be a delicious rabbit stew in a scrumptious wine sauce.  Who knew Bugs Bunny tasted so tender!  Then we had the Tortilla a la Espanola, which was a potato omelet with a yummy sauce and roasted pepper to go with.  We also had the Gambas al Ajillo, which were large prawns with huge chucks of marinated garlic.  To complement these dishes, we chose one of the Roijas, which is a spicy red wine from Spain that they pour into a decanter at your table.  With the cream custard we had for dessert, they brought us a complimentary glass of their fab sangria.  With the cozy ambiance and the unique service, I felt as if we were in a little Spanish village instead of on Lombard Street.  Go early and you'll have the whole place to yourself...a great spot to take a pause from the hustle & bustle.
author: Tara G.

description: Very quaint and charming. Friendly staff. Perfect for intimate dates or group outings. The sangria is deceptively juice like (but packs a heavy punch). The paella is not bad, but the stand out dishes are the calamari (not greasy), the mushrooms, the chicken stuffed with spinach and pine nuts and the flan.
author: Mama L.

description: This place is just ok.  Decent, reliable food, but nothing special.
author: Tom S.

description:
YUMMMMMMMM.  One of my best friends came to town and he suggested looking up tapas on yelp and we came across Alegria's.  I am almost always eating asian food, but I thought, eh, what the heck -- the pictures on yelp looked good, so let's try it.   We ordered the crab cakes - the sauce it sat on was sooo delish!  The empanadillas de carne were buttery/flakey and very tasty.  The patatas aioli made both of us soooooooo happy.  It was the "eyes rolling to the back of your head" type of good.  We also got the paella with chicken and seafood, but we didn't really care for it, actually I thought it sucked.  I don't drink much, but I loved my sangria.  Service was great and they didn't try to kick us out, even though we were the last ones there.  I would go again -- just for the patatas aioli!  Definitely a cozy, quiet, dimly lit atmosphere -- nice when you need to catch up on some conversation; you won't have to scream through the loudness of a crowd.
On top of what we ordered, friend had 2 glasses of wine and we shared bottled water -- our bill came out to about $75 (w/o tip).
author: Jere D.

description: Came here for dinner (had a deal from SF Gate Daily) on Friday night. The restaurant was very comfortable, cozy, and romantic--I liked all the decorative touches and lighting. The star of our meal was the paella with seafood and chorizo, which was delicious and we'd definitely go back just for that. My husband ordered the rib eye steak which ok, but nothing to write home about. However, we were seriously underwhelmed by the tapas (which is a total bummer b/c I LOVE tapas). We had the shrimp/ham croquettes, the manchego flambeado (manchego cheese w/brandy), and the calamari. I was really disappointed by the taste of the Manchego flambeado--it lacked flavor, and it was drowning in oil which was pretty unappetizing. The calamari was ok, but it came with the same side sauce that the croquettes came with, which was a mayo-based sauce that was pretty flavorless. I'd prefer to have a sauce that has a little more kick to it (and some acid). We had the flan for dessert, which was deliciously smooth and caramely. Service was also slow (our water was refilled maybe once the entire time we wer there). Overall, it was an OK experience with the highlights being the paella and the flan. We probably wouldn't drive all the way to the city just to eat here, but if we happen to be in the neighborhood...
author: Christine R.

description: i like this place because of the ambiance and decor.  its a very casual place but somehow they managed to decorate the place to make it romantic and intimate.  i went with a big group of people so i was able to try almost all of the tapas and the paella.  my overall impression of the food was that it was pretty average. a lot of the food was also lukewarm, not sure why that was.  the flavors were good though and the prices were decent.
author: Molly C.

description: Absolutely love this place. The food rocks. Friendly staff and never a wait. Plus unlike Zarzuella on Union & Hyde and Cha Cha the staff is appreciative of you being there and does NOT try to turn your table
author: Cow H.

description: Walked in on a Saturday night at 9pm with my boyfriend. Place looked busy and packed. We didn't have a reservation so we were nervous about the long wait. We got lucky and was seated fairly quickly. The ambiance at Alegrias is great. Very romantic--making it a great date spot. Food is a bit pricey--but it is worth every penny. The food was simply delicious. We just ordered several tapas: starting out with an assorted imported cheese platter and cured sausage from spain, then had the rabbit stew, roasted spanish, prawns, and pork skewers. We were so stuffed at the end of the meal, it was painful to walk home. This is definitely a MUST-GO.
author: Chanli S.

description: food is pretty good..I was not a big fan of decoration
author: saroj y.

description: Nice people, good food and overall a warm experience.  I've gone back to this restaurant many many times and the food never disappoint me.
author: Bella L.

description: After spending two weeks touring Spain in April, this is pretty authentic.  The tapas are good and the ambiance is good too.  Definitely worth trying if you want a true taste of Spanish tapas.
author: Karen B.

description: After reading yelp review, I decided to host my boyfriend birthday party here. I was very impressed. They have great service, food and romantic settings. Because we had 15 people, they even prepared the set menu for us that saved a lot of time thinking what to order. I had birthday cake delivered directly to the restaurant and the waiter brought it over to us after the dinner. So if you have any special request, just let them know, they will try their best to work with you and make your dinner event the best.
author: Justice B.

description: great & authentic Spanish foods served in a nice & quiet atmosphere.
author: Laurent C.

description: yum...alegrias feels & tastes like a tapas restaurant.  i always get the table in the corner by the wall of frames which is cool to look at while the food comes out.  can't go wrong w/ the mushrooms, potato omelette, bread & evoo, sangria... service always rocks.  i heart alegrias.
author: M R.
